Reviews:
A monumental game in my gaming career, Half-Life 2 was that defining experience that made me realise I was in for something next level. For the first time i picked it up on The Orange Box in 2008, and from the moment I booted it up, I knew I was in for a wild ride. It wasnâ€™t just a gameâ€”it was an event. The environments were absolutely massive, the atmosphere was unreal, and the soundtrack? Edgy as hell. Every moment felt like a cinematic journey.

In Half-Life 2, you play as Gordon Freeman, arguably one of the most reluctant action heroes in gaming. You awaken from stasis, burdened with the trauma of the previous game, and are immediately thrust into action as the figurehead of an uprising. This isnâ€™t a simple revolutionâ€”itâ€™s a battle against a multiversal alien threat, shrouded in dystopian themes and orchestrated by secretive organizations manipulating events behind the scenes.

Set in a world dominated by the Combine, an alien regime that combines interdimensional authoritarianism with advanced technology, you must navigate a planet under their control. Armed with little more than a crowbar and your signature nonverbalism, Gordon becomes the key figure in the resistance. As you progress, you'll engage in intense combat, solve puzzles, explore diverse environments, and uncover the unsettling truth that nothing in this world is as it seems.

And letâ€™s talk about The G-Manâ€”a mysterious, interdimensional CIA glowman who pops up like a bad dream and probably controls the entire charade like a cosmic puppeteer. Is he good? Is he bad? Is he just playing the long game? Who knows, but heâ€™s definitely got his hand in everything, watching Gordon like a hawk, pulling strings like an invisible god. 

Youâ€™d think itâ€™s just a sci-fi conspiracy, but after a while, you start questioning if anyone really knows what the hell is going on. Does G-Man even have a purpose, or is he just a cosmic observer who gets his kicks out of watching a man with a crowbar take on the end of the world?

The gameâ€™s narrative feels like a giant puzzle, and each step forward opens up even more questions, all while youâ€™re tearing through enemy lines, trying to get answers. And the best part? Itâ€™s not all about combatâ€”there are puzzles to solve, mysteries to uncover, and a sense of isolation that keeps you on edge, constantly wondering who or what will show up next. The pacing is incredible, making you feel like youâ€™re a tiny piece of something far larger, with consequences that span across dimensions.

Released in 2004 by Valve, it redefined what players could expect from a video game in terms of both storytelling and gameplay. The gameâ€™s narrative is immersive, unfolding without traditional cutscenes, which allows the player to feel like they are truly part of the story. The protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is a silent hero who navigates through a dystopian world filled with alien invaders and oppressive human forces. This unique approach to storytelling pulls the player into the gameâ€™s world, making every action feel meaningful.

The physics engine in "Half-Life 2" was revolutionary for its time. The way objects interact with the environment feels natural and intuitive, and it became a major part of the gameplay. From solving puzzles using physics to creatively using the environment as a weapon, it was an innovation that influenced many games that followed. The gravity gun, which allows players to manipulate objects in real-time, is still one of the most memorable and fun weapons in gaming history.

The level design in "Half-Life 2" is another standout feature. The game introduces players to varied environments, from the dark, industrial city of City 17 to the eerie, remote marshlands. Each location feels carefully crafted, with attention to detail that makes the world feel alive. The pacing is also masterful, alternating between moments of intense combat and slower, atmospheric sequences that allow the player to soak in the environment and story.

The AI in "Half-Life 2" was also ahead of its time. Enemies behave intelligently, using cover, working together, and reacting to the playerâ€™s actions in a way that makes combat more dynamic and challenging. The enemy variety, from the terrifying Combine soldiers to the creepy headcrabs, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The interactions with NPCs and the world around you help build a sense of tension and immersion, keeping you on edge throughout the experience.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Kelly Bailey, perfectly complements the atmosphere, using subtle but effective music to enhance both the action and the quieter moments. The sound design is top-notch, with ambient sounds adding to the immersion, whether you're in a busy city street or exploring a deserted warehouse.

Ultimately, "Half-Life 2" is a masterpiece that still holds up to this day. Its innovative gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievements make it a game that set a new standard for the industry. Itâ€™s a game thatâ€™s not just fun to play, but one thatâ€™s easy to appreciate for the way it shaped the future of video games. Even though itâ€™s been years since its release, "Half-Life 2" remains a classic that continues to inspire both players and developers alike.

Counter-Strike: Source (CS: Source) is the definitive version of one of the most iconic tactical shooters ever created. Built on the Source engine, it brought stunning graphics, refined mechanics, and an immersive experience that kept players engaged for years. It improved upon its predecessor, Counter-Strike 1.6, and laid the foundation for future games in the series, including Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Here's why CS: Source remains a perfect 10/10 for fans of competitive gaming.

Why Itâ€™s a Must-Play
ğŸ”« Precise Gunplay
At the core of CS: Source is its tight and rewarding gun mechanics. Every weapon in the game feels unique, with its own recoil patterns and handling characteristics. This precision-driven combat is one of the key factors that makes CS: Source such a compelling competitive experience. From the M4A4's controlled spray to the AWP's one-shot kills, every engagement requires skill and accuracy.

ğŸŒ Map Design & Tactical Depth
The iconic maps like Dust 2, Inferno, and Nuke are where the game shines brightest. Each map is meticulously designed to offer a balance of tactical positions, choke points, and strategic opportunities. Whether you're defending bomb sites or pushing through tight corridors, the map design fosters deep teamwork and careful planning.

ğŸ’¥ Gameplay Mechanics
CS: Source features smooth, fluid movement, making it easy to peek around corners, hold angles, and strafe while shooting. The buy system gives players the freedom to choose their preferred weapons and gear, while round-based gameplay forces teams to be efficient with their resources and execute well-planned strategies.

ğŸ® Vibrant Community & Modding Support
The modding community for CS: Source has been incredibly active, creating a wealth of custom content from maps to skins to even entirely new game modes. This extends the life of the game by offering nearly endless ways to enjoy the experience. The server browser lets players dive into unique community-run servers, making every session feel fresh and exciting.

ğŸ¨ Improved Visuals
Powered by the Source engine, CS: Source delivered a massive graphical leap from its predecessors, offering realistic lighting, better textures, and advanced physics. These improvements gave the game a more immersive and polished feel, while the physics engine introduced interactive objects and destructible environments, adding a layer of depth to gameplay.

What Makes It a 10/10
CS: Source isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s a tactical masterpiece thatâ€™s stood the test of time. Its emphasis on team coordination, strategy, and individual skill is unmatched. Whether playing with friends or random players, the experience fosters a strong sense of community and competition, making each match feel meaningful. The team-based objectives â€“ like bomb planting/defusal â€“ combined with tight, tactical combat is a dynamic experience that few shooters can replicate.

The longevity of CS: Source is a testament to how well it was designed. While newer titles in the series (like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive) have taken inspiration from it, the smoothness of the gameplay, iconic maps, and endless customization options keep it relevant in the competitive FPS scene.

If youâ€™re a fan of shooters and havenâ€™t experienced CS: Source, youâ€™re missing out on one of the most influential and well-rounded tactical shooters ever made. Itâ€™s a game that offers both depth and accessibility, making it suitable for casual players, yet still offering enough challenge for the competitive elite. CS: Source is a timeless classicâ€”pure, competitive, and still as enjoyable today as it was when it first released.
cleaned_review: CS: Source is a must-play for any gamer.

The gameplay is a show-off: If you dominate the techniques of bunnyhopping and strafe, you'll feel like you're voding on a map. Bunnyhopping is an art in this game.

Reviews:
Rating: 7/10

Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a multiplayer first-person shooter developed by Valve. It is a remake of the classic Half-Life deathmatch mode, utilizing the Source engine. The game combines the fast-paced action of traditional deathmatch with updated graphics and more fluid movement mechanics. While it successfully brings new life to the original concept, some mechanical issues and a niche player base prevent it from being as popular as its predecessors.

What Works Well?
ğŸ® Classic Deathmatch Gameplay
The core of Half-Life: Deathmatch is its tight, fast-paced combat. It stays true to the original deathmatch mode, offering classic weapons, high-speed action, and simple, enjoyable mechanics. The formula remains as fun today as it was when first introduced.

ğŸŒ† Updated Graphics with Source Engine
The move to the Source engine has significantly improved the visuals compared to the original. The lighting, textures, and models are much sharper, breathing new life into the iconic Half-Life universe. The environments feel more immersive, and physics interactions are more dynamic.

ğŸ”« Familiar Weapon Set
Players have access to a variety of classic weapons from the Half-Life series, including the crowbar, shotgun, and crossbow, all of which perform as expected. Each weapon has its own strategic value, and they all function well within the confines of the deathmatch setting.

ğŸ› ï¸ Modding Support and Custom Servers
As with other Source engine games, Deathmatch: Source allows for a robust modding community. Players can easily find custom servers and user-created content, from new maps to modified gameplay modes, keeping the experience fresh.

What Could Be Better?
âŒ Limited Popularity and Player Base
Despite its solid foundation, Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source suffers from a relatively small player base. As newer games in the genre continue to dominate, it can be difficult to find active matches, especially in more niche servers.

âŒ Physics Can Feel Clunky
While the Source engine improved many aspects of the game, some of the physicsâ€”especially in terms of movementâ€”can feel a little awkward compared to modern shooters. The transition to 3D space feels a bit more restrictive than anticipated, particularly when compared to the fluidity of more modern games.

âŒ No Significant Gameplay Innovation
While the updated graphics and better physics are great, Deathmatch: Source doesn't introduce any major changes to the original formula. It feels more like a polished port rather than a revolutionary step forward for the genre. Players expecting something drastically new may be disappointed.

âŒ Lack of Meaningful Progression
Like many classic deathmatch games, thereâ€™s a lack of meaningful progression or any form of unlockable content. While this keeps the focus on pure skill-based play, some players may miss the more modern systems that reward long-term engagement.

Conclusion
Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a solid multiplayer shooter for fans of the classic Half-Life experience. Its updated visuals and iconic weapons deliver the fun, high-speed action that fans love, but its small player base and lack of major innovation hold it back from achieving greater popularity. If youâ€™re looking for nostalgic deathmatch action or enjoy modding, itâ€™s a great choice, but donâ€™t expect a revolutionary experience.

Ğ¢Ğ°Ğ¼ ÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ñ…Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ° Ğ²Ñ‹ĞºÑ€ÑƒÑ‡ĞµĞ½ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°ĞºÑĞ¸Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¼. | I played many TRPGs, but this is the one I always come back to, because its simply the best one with right mods. For two decades the 1.13 mod is in development, adding tremendous amount of features, aiming to make the game as realistic a possible. If you dont mind sprite graphics and ready to spend some time learning the numerous features, hotkeys and mechanics you'll find out that it has an almost infinite replayability. The mods I use are 1.13 (latest from github repo) + Wildfire Map Pack for 1.13, plus some tweaks in the config (comes with neat app).
You get quite big campaign map, where you are free to do whatever you want, with just your end goal set - killing the tyrant. How you approach this is entirely up to you. Train your mercs, train militia, set up ambushes, do espionage, or night operations, or even raise squads from locals to help you fight or lay siege to enemy strongholds. The tyrant also doesnt sit idly - royal forces respond to your actions dynamically, actively trying to stop you. The 1.13 has numerous optional features too, for any flavor of 80's movie you want to achieve.
The combat is really thought out, and numerous tactical maneuvers you can do. Overall, recommend. | Old school, maar nog steeds een geweldig spel | Endlessly entertaining!

Reviews:
I couldn't beat it because you eventually reach a couple of levels that are REALLY annoying to go through, and I found no fun in doing so while following a guide. But, even so, I can say that the game is really fun. And maybe you're more patient than me and will end up having way more fun than I throughout.

I would say the combat is more complex than you would think at first glance (in a good way), though you will probably be kicking things most of the time (because it is a lot of fun!). Don't have too much expectations of the story, though, it's not necessarily bad but I don't think you'll find anything new or inspiring. | A hidden gem
Some of the most creative level design and puzzle solutions I've seen in a game - The combat, whilst kinda clunky at times, is also hilarious and when it clicks, can be really fun
Definitely worth trying out if you appreciate good level design or the Dishonored games, as it's very clear that foundations of that started in this game | One of the best games I ever played but is very short. Plays like Skyrim meets Postal. Physics based violence rules! | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµĞ³Ğ¾ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°! Reviews:
There are few games that manage to transcend their medium, leaving a lasting impact on the players who experience them. Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines is one of those rare gemsâ€”an immersive, darkly compelling RPG that takes you deep into a world of nightmarish intrigue, complex morality, and unforgettable characters. Released in 2004, it may have been ahead of its time, but it has since become a beloved classic, and for good reason. This is a game that not only captures the spirit of its source material but builds a world so rich, so nuanced, that it feels alive.

A World of Shadows and Secrets
From the moment you step into the shoes of a freshly turned vampire, Bloodlines introduces you to a world that is both beautifully sinister and intricately detailed. Set in modern-day Los Angeles, the game weaves a dark tale of political intrigue, personal conflict, and supernatural terror. The rich lore of the Vampire: The Masquerade tabletop RPG is brought to life in an almost seamless way, with each faction of vampiresâ€”whether it's the stoic Ventrue, the cunning Malkavians, or the fiery Brujahâ€”adding layers of complexity to the story. This is a world where nothing is ever simple, and where every decision you make carries weight.

The setting itself, the urban sprawl of LA, is a masterwork of gothic atmosphere. The gameâ€™s locationsâ€”be it the seedy alleyways of Santa Monica or the terrifying depths of the haunted asylumâ€”are meticulously crafted, with a level of detail that makes every corner feel like it holds a secret. Youâ€™re not just moving through a city; youâ€™re navigating a sprawling, living ecosystem of power struggles and hidden threats.

Immersive Role-Playing Like No Other
What truly sets Bloodlines apart from other RPGs is its depth of character interaction and role-playing opportunities. The game is all about choiceâ€”and not just in how you approach combat or quests, but in how you choose to live your life as a vampire. Will you uphold the delicate balance of the Masquerade, hiding your true nature from humanity, or will you embrace your monstrous side and sow chaos? These choices arenâ€™t just for show; they impact the way youâ€™re treated by the various factions, your relationships with other characters, and even the gameâ€™s ending. There are no easy answers here, and thatâ€™s what makes it so compelling.

The character creation system is robust, allowing you to craft a vampire that fits your playstyle. You can invest in a variety of abilities, from brutal physical combat to stealthy persuasion and hacking skills. The power of your clan also plays a significant role in how you approach different challenges, and the supernatural abilities you gain as a vampire offer a variety of ways to approach problems. Whether you want to manipulate minds, become a fearsome force in combat, or sneak past enemies unnoticed, Bloodlines gives you the freedom to build your vampire exactly how you envision them.

A Story That Binds You
But itâ€™s not just the gameplay that shinesâ€”itâ€™s the narrative. Bloodlines offers a gripping, multi-layered story that is filled with moral ambiguity, unforgettable characters, and moments of genuine emotional weight. Whether you're trying to navigate the political machinations of the vampire factions or diving into a personal quest that challenges your own morals, the plot is constantly shifting and evolving. The main story is full of twists and turns, but itâ€™s the side storiesâ€”the personal journeys of the NPCsâ€”that really elevate the game. These characters are deeply written and full of life, each with their own motivations, quirks, and tragic backstories.

The voice acting is phenomenal, bringing every character to life with nuances and emotions that make them feel real. Whether youâ€™re talking to a wise old vampire or a desperate fledgling, the dialogue is always engaging and never feels forced. The writing, sharp and often darkly humorous, helps bring out the personality of every character you encounter, from the charming yet treacherous LaCroix to the lovable, eccentric hacker, Jeanette.

Combat and Gameplay Mechanics
The combat system in Bloodlines is a bit divisive, but it offers a unique approach to RPG combat. While the shooting mechanics can feel clunky at times, the gameâ€™s strength lies in its flexibility. You can choose to avoid combat altogether, relying on your social skills to navigate tense situations or solve problems through dialogue and subterfuge. But when the fighting does come, the visceral action makes you feel the power of being a vampire, whether youâ€™re tearing through enemies with claws or using dark blood magic to overwhelm your foes.

The game also offers a range of side quests that are surprisingly rich in content, giving you more than just a diversion from the main story. Whether youâ€™re helping a fellow vampire find their lost item or delving into a creepy mystery, these quests help flesh out the world and deepen your immersion.

A Timeless Classic
Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines is a game that continues to stand the test of time. Despite its technical issues at launchâ€”many of which were patched over the yearsâ€”the story, world-building, and complex characters remain as captivating as ever. This is a game that rewards patience, allowing you to sink hours into its rich narrative and immersive world. Itâ€™s a rare gem that doesn't just entertain, but challenges you, makes you think, and makes you feel the weight of every choice.

In a gaming landscape often dominated by shallow experiences, Bloodlines is a deep, meaningful RPG that still feels like a living, breathing world full of possibilities. Itâ€™s a game that hooks you with its dark allure and doesnâ€™t let go. If you havenâ€™t experienced Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines yet, you owe it to yourself to dive into this haunting, unforgettable adventure.

cleaned_review: The game is a great experience, and the graphics are great. The game is very easy to play and the game is very well made.

Reviews:
In my humble opinion, this is the greatest ARPG ever created, enhanced by the fantastic mod support that the community has used to the fullest. The class system is amazing, allowing you to combine two out of nine mastery trees to make your own unique class with an incredible amount of customization.  You have the fully offensive, close-quarter mastery Warfare, which revolves around duel weidling weapons and becoming a whirlwind of AoE and single target damage, at the cost of defence. Ranged masteries like Hunting which allows you to deal huge amounts of damage from a distance, and debuff your enemies defences. Magic masteries such as Spirit, which allows you to drain the life from your enemies! And 6 other unique and exiting masteries.

The world is vibrant and beautiful, starting in Greece, them moving to Egypt, then China, and with the DLC, even into the domain of Hades himself! The quests while perhaps a little generic, are very fun and easy to follow, and often give satisfying rewards along with a nice chunk of EXP and Gold! Not to mention the amazing loot you will find along your journey.

All in all it is a wonderful game, one of my all time favourites, I highly reccomend checking it out. And if you enjoy it, keep an eye on Grim Dawn, a game being developed by many of the same people that made Titan Quest, it promises to be an equaly enchanting ARPG set in the Victorian times! | é‰´äºç›®å‰è¿™æ¬¾æ¸¸æˆæ­£åœ¨æ‰“æŠ˜å¹¶ä¸”æˆ‘ä¹Ÿéå¸¸å–œæ¬¢è¿™æ¬¾æ¸¸æˆ,ç‰¹æ„èŠ±äº†äº›æ—¶é—´å†™è¿™äº†ç¯‡ç©å®¶æµ‹è¯„

http://store.steampowered.com/app/475150 | Titan Quest, and its worthy expansion Immortal Throne is, imo, part of the holy trinity in ARPG's along side Diablo and Dungeon Siege. Titan Quests theme is unique, and the gameplay is so faithful to the principles that made diablo so great.
There is a massive, diverse world covered in several acts. In combination with tons of loot in the suspected qualities to keep the flow of the game intact. On top of that, the game also follows the model of increased difficulty (normal, epic, legendary), remeniscent of Diablo's normal, nightmare and hell. Each difficulty features harder monsters and better loot.

If at one point, you would get tired of the original campaign, you can try some of the fantastic mods available, especially Lilith: Battle for Jalavin (a totally newly created world which will take you up to 20 hours to complete). This mod in combination with other well known TQ mods such as Masteries mod (skill overhaul mod), gives more than enough incentive to go through the whole experience all over again with a fresh new slate.

All in all, if you are a fan of ARPG's it is a genuine crime not to have this masterpiece. The majority of the now-closed TQ studio (Iron Lore) are in the process of making a spiritual succesor named Grim Dawn (by Crate Entertainement). Given their history with TQ, this is a title to keep in mind as well and currently available through early acces on steam.

Closing advice: go spend money on this, preferably as soon as possible, you will not regret it. | ĞŸĞ¾Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»ÑƒĞ¹ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ»ÑƒÑ‡ÑˆĞ¸Ñ… Hack'n'Slash RPG. ĞšĞ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğµ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ Ğ½Ğµ ÑÑ‚Ñ‹Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ² Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½ Ñ€ÑĞ´ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğµ Ğ´Ğ²Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹ ĞºĞ°Ğº Titan Quest Ğ¸ Diablo Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº, ĞºĞ°Ğº ĞºĞ°Ğ¶Ğ´Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ… Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ»Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ ÑĞ²Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ¾ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼Ñ‹Ğ¼Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸. | Titan Quest is almost ten years old, but it's still one the best action RPGs out there.  

Pros:
Great skill system offers a TON of replayability
Good in-game mythos based on real life mythology
Excellent variety of enemies to fight
Well-balanced loot drops (not too much, not too little)
Some uber-bosses only in appear in harder difficulties giving you incentive to play through again

Cons:
No map randomization
No instanced loot in multiplayer
Game stutters once in a while even on modern computers

If you like action RPGs grab it next time it's on sale, or hell, grab it now! It's worth every cent.
cleaned_review: Titan Quest Gold is a great game, and I highly recommend it.

Reviews:
[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[th]ğŸŸ© [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]ğŸŸ¥ [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
â€¢ Excellent variety of class building possibilities thanks to dual multiclassing and a plethora of skills for each.

â€¢ Decent overall variety of enemies, most of which have different behaviors and unique abilities.

â€¢ Good diversity of locations, all well-made and consistent, with many references to mythology and philosophy.
[/td]
[td]
â€¢ Tremendously slow, unsatisfying progression, compounded with severe content bloating.

â€¢ Miserable bosses that hardly prove a challenge with any half-decent build.

â€¢ Top-tier vanilla class abilities are locked behind a DLC paywall.

â€¢ Boring exploration that features no events of any kind, limited randomization, and unrewarding secrets.

â€¢ Painfully-paced combat with outrageous cooldowns for an ARPG, unresponsive controls and ultra-jank melee.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]ğŸŸ¨ [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]ğŸ”§ [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
â€¢ Random crashes may occur when transitioning areas and make you lose progress.

â€¢ UI doesnâ€™t scale well in 4K, making many elements too small.

â€¢ Barebones loot filtering system that doesnâ€™t allow any customization past basic tier exclusion.
[/td]
[td]
â€¢ i9 13980HX
â€¢ 64GB RAM DDR5
â€¢ RTX 4090
â€¢ NvME SSD
â€¢ 3840x2160
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me, with another player in co-op, around 34 hours to complete Titan Quest on the standard difficulty (the only one available on your first run), taking extra time to finish all side quests and fully explore each area. The replay value is decent with the multi-class possibilities, however everything else stays the same on harder difficulties.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Do I recommend it?[/b][/td]
[td]No. Despite some good points, Titan Quest is, ultimately, a mind-numbing slog. It doesnâ€™t do anything that countless other ARPGs have done before or after its time, and has no specific features or qualities that set its own identity.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Conclusion[/h3][/td]
[td]An infuriatingly generic and poorly-paced ARPG: monotony and repetition soon overtake any and all enjoymentâ€”its vast class-building simply isnâ€™t enough to keep it afloat in an ocean of unambitious, boring design choices.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[quote]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41449676/]Curator[/url] and [url=https://summitreviews.biz]Website[/url] to see more high-quality reviews regularly.[/quote]

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Writing & Worldbuilding[/h3]
Titan Questâ€™s ancient Fantasy setting, spanning from Greece to African regions and even higher planes of existence such as Hades (Hell) and Elysium (Heaven), is overall detailed, consistent and well-made visually and artistically. Despite its age, the visuals hold up well enough, and the ragdoll physics add some dynamicity to an otherwise very static combat feel. If you enjoy historical settings, youâ€™ll feel right at home. 

Given that deep, meaningful plots are never a priority in this genre, efforts have been made in other iconic titles to, at least, grant a semblance of interest to the various tasks at hand, take Diablo II for example. That doesnâ€™t happen in Titan Quest, however. Whereas the main story is generic but serviceable, any and all side characters or quests are inconsequentialâ€”their middle school grade writing only worsens the dullness of tasks already repetitive by nature. Youâ€™ll find no interest whatsoever in any of the admittedly iconic characters youâ€™ll meet, such as great ancient heroes and even demigods, all stripped of any pathos or epicness they may have had.

[h3]Exploration & Secrets[/h3]
Youâ€™ll explore each area on foot, your only means of transport besides two-way portals that allow fast-travel to discovered locations, such as cities, to sell loot, use facilities and restock consumablesâ€”the standard ARPG fare. Notably, quest givers arenâ€™t highlighted when itâ€™s time to return a completed quest, so good luck remembering where â€œGeneric NPC I Forgot The Name Ofâ€™â€™ is located. The average speed of your character is inadequate to traverse any area in a decent time; with how large each map is, youâ€™ll find yourself walking more than fighting, since enemy density is subpar. Youâ€™ll often ask yourself when the current area will end, because youâ€™re fed up with it already.

Each map has plenty of side-areas and dungeons that often host Elite or Boss enemies guarding higher-tier chests that have a chance to spawn the best loot. Exploring is worthwhile to mop up as much XP as you can, but not so much for loot since most chests, including â€œsecretâ€ ones, have miserable rewards. The satisfaction of finding a secret dungeon, clearing it and getting some actual good loot from it is almost always absent.

[h3]Combat System & Bosses[/h3]
The combat gameplay, of course, will change based on your Masteries (classes) of choice, ranging from pure casters to summoners, melee specialists, archers, rogues, and why not, a mix of all the above. The amount of combinations is staggering, with a relatively cheap respec option available at any town for skills. The standard ARPG system of mana, health and related potions is in place, plus an array of consumable Scrolls that have a variety of unique effects, purchased for a high price or rarely found. Should you perish in combat, a feat not easy to achieve due to the generally tame challenge posed by your foes, an XP penalty is applied, having you return to your death-mark to reclaim it; nothing else is lost.

The cooldowns. Good lord the cooldowns. Of any ARPG I have played, Titan Quest takes the cake for the slowest, most infuriating cooldown timers. Whoever thought a 30 seconds cooldown on the basic Taunt skill for a tank (which doesnâ€™t work properly half the time anyway) or even 60 second ones on caster skills were good ideas, should take a break from game development and play some Diablo II to see how itâ€™s done.

Even if the enemy variety is good in a general sense, most maps overextend and bloat for too long, having you fight countless of the same fodder far past what would be ideal for this genre. The Elite and Boss enemies arenâ€™t unique or meaningful enough to grant the needed diversity. Speaking of higher-tier enemies, unless you go against one that is twenty levels above you, you wonâ€™t have much problems dealing with them, at least on the default difficulty setting. Most of them are miserable, generic, and just donâ€™t stand out enough from the crowd save for some different color or aura around them. I died a total of five times in the whole game, which isnâ€™t a lot. 

[h3]Character Progression[/h3]
By killing enemies and completing quests, youâ€™ll level up and receive 3 Skill and 2 Attribute points each time. You can also get these as quest rewards, alongside other unique bonuses like +% damage, but thatâ€™s a rare occurrence. 

Youâ€™ll also loot charms from enemies and chests, which can be used on weapons to bestow passive traits that compound your build, and also reused by destroying the weapon to get the charm back and then put it on a better one.

Leveling up in Titan Quest is tremendously slow: by the end of the campaign, after doing everything, I was just level 37; the level cap is 75. Thatâ€™s less than one level per hour, which may be fine for the last 10-20 levels in an ARPG, when your build is already shaped up, but itâ€™s a depressing affair so early. Your gameplay evolves slowly, frustratingly so: your combat experience will stay the same for hours on end if you decide to focus on a few skills, which is the only way to make them worth using to begin with. Also, youâ€™ll also have to spend skill points to increase your Mastery level and access higher tier skills, further sinking more points into passive stats instead of active skills that evolve your classâ€™ gameplay. | I fully recommend this game. Read on if you want to know why.

The pros:
Although this game was released in 2006 the graphics are still holding up with nowadays games.
But not only the graphics are great even the artstyle is an outstandig masterpiece.
It's not too dark or too colorful.
The game is set in pre-roman ironage mixed up with mythologie.
It's a really well fitiing and unspent setting.
The character progression and skilling is interesting.
The sound ambient and music is well made and catching.
The developer delivered all of the tools the games have been made with, so you can make your own Titan Quest mod or total conversion.

The cons:
The controls feel a bit clumpy. You often get stuck on small clutter on the ground you're barely seeing.
The game doesn't recognize when you're pressing multiple buttons at once for activating skills for example.
This can be the reason why you die rather quickly and thats frustrating.
Sometimes the frames drop at a low rate when special effects like rain or snow are showing.
Even though you can expand your bag the room to hoard stuff is very limited. You need to use third-party-tools like TQVault to expand you stash.
This also applies to the attributes like strength, dexterity, intelligence etc. You need to use third-party-tools to reset them.
The devs have added some lategame contenct but it's not enough to keep the players busy imo.

My most favorite game of all time. Great game, great port.

When I first wrote my review you couldn't play with mods online but the latest update at time of editing did add this and is no longer an issue.

Also for those who are new to Doom mods: Brutal Doom and Myhouse.wad WON'T work on this port. Those rely on a source port like GZDoom or Zandronum to work. Anything ending in .pk3 won't work either. | The absolute best. Rip and tear, until it is done.

Military shooters are a dime a dozen. Hero shooter are more likely to crash and burn than not. Extraction shooters are just the latest fad. Doom on the other hand...

Pack renovado por Nightdive Studios de los dos primeros Doom, con un montÃ³n de mejoras y aÃ±adidos para disfrutarlo mejor que nunca. 

Como ya sabrÃ©is la mayorÃ­a, Doom supuso una autÃ©ntica revoluciÃ³n en el mundo de los videojuegos al ser uno de los mÃ¡s influyentes juegos de disparos en primera persona  de la historia, siendo prÃ¡cticamente el origen de la popularidad del gÃ©nero; por su apartado grÃ¡fico revolucionario con sus texturas detalladas y especialmente su entorno 3D con una inmersiÃ³n nunca vista hasta la fecha; por su modo multijugador que permitÃ­a jugar a travÃ©s de LAN, lo cual fue todo un avance en el mundillo de los videojuegos; y tambiÃ©n por el variado diseÃ±o de la gran cantidad de niveles laberÃ­nticos de los que disponÃ­a, llenos de secretos.

A pesar de que Doom saliÃ³ en 1993, acabo de pasÃ¡rmelo completÃ¡ndolo al 100% y he de decir de que a pesar del paso del tiempo y de que como es lÃ³gico a nivel grÃ¡fico se ha quedado completamente desfasado, sigue siendo uno de los juegos mÃ¡s adictivos y frenÃ©ticos que puedes encontrar en la actualidad.

Este pack incluye: Doom I, Doom II, TNT: Evilution, The Plutonia Experiment, Master Levels for Doom II, No rest for the Living, Sigil y Legacy of Rust, un nuevo episodio totalmente exclusivo. Esto nos asegura una cantidad enorme de horas de juego, mÃ¡s si queremos encontrar los secretos de los niveles o conseguir el 100% de logros disponibles. 

AdemÃ¡s de todo este contenido, tiene mejoras en cuando al apartado grÃ¡fico, gracias al motor grÃ¡fico KEX que permite una mejor renderizaciÃ³n, pudiendo usar resoluciones de hasta 4K y 120FPS, ademÃ¡s de mejoras en cuanto a texturas y efectos. 

Se ha remasterizado la banda sonora, pudiendo elegir entre la versiÃ³n MIDI o la nueva versiÃ³n IDKFA de Andrew Hulshult (podÃ©is disfrutarla en Spotify: [url=https://open.spotify.com/intl-es/album/2YqpDPPwqaKCoSBe36hVAe?si=eD-MuFIXSVuMkAjg1y8aCA]Banda sonora IDKFA de DOOM + DOOM II por Andrew Hulshult en Spotify[/url]. Es una autÃ©ntica maravilla el trabajo realizado, aunque como pega hay que decir tambiÃ©n que se echa en falta que hicieran lo mismo con la BSO de TNT: Evilution o Sigil por ejemplo, que no estÃ¡n remasterizadas.

Sobre la nueva expansiÃ³n exclusiva llamada Legacy of Rust, realizada en colaboraciÃ³n entre id Software, Nightdive Studios y MachineGames, incluye 16 nuevos mapas divididos en dos secciones: The Vulcan Abyss y Counterfeit Eden, aÃ±adiendo ademÃ¡s nuevos enemigos y armas. 

A modo de resumen, mi lista de pros y contras:

[H1][b]PROS:[/b][/H1]

- 2 de los mejores FPS de todos los tiempos, que cambiaron la historia de los videojuegos para siempre

- Que hayan incluido las mejoras totalmente gratis para los que ya tenÃ­amos los clÃ¡sicos en la biblioteca

- Que hayan remasterizado toda la banda sonora de Doom y Doom 2

- Es la mejor forma de disfrutar de estos clÃ¡sicos

- La enorme variedad de enemigos

- La variedad de armas disponibles

- Que hayan incluido todas las expansiones

- Las mejoras para seleccionar el arma

- Compatibilidad total con mandos (para quien quiera jugarlo asÃ­, aunque con ratÃ³n + teclado es mucho mejor en mi opiniÃ³n)

- Montones de horas de juego aseguradas si quieres completar el 100% de logros

- La nueva campaÃ±a Legacy of Rust, con nuevos enemigos y armas

- La ingente cantidad de secretos repartidos por los niveles

- Muy rejugable

- Los controles mejorados

- Traducido al espaÃ±ol

- Tan divertido y frenÃ©tico como antaÃ±o

- El gore

- La ingente cantidad de enemigos en pantalla al mismo tiempo

- Que tenga la opciÃ³n de quicksave / quickload

- Tiene una gran cantidad de logros Steam

- Tiene sistema de guardado de la partida en la nube Steam Cloud

[H1][b]CONTRAS:[/b][/H1]

- Se echan en falta mÃ¡s opciones de configuraciÃ³n y mejoras grÃ¡ficas, como el filtrado de las texturas. Solo da la opciÃ³n de jugarlo con la estÃ©tica retro con las texturas pixeladas, habiendo ya muchos mods que lo superan a nivel visual

- Que no se pueda mirar libremente con el ratÃ³n como ocurre como otros juegos similares remasterizados de la de la Ã©poca, como Duke Nukem 3D o Blood

- Que no se pueda saltar ni agacharse, siempre fue de lo poco que no me gustÃ³ en su dÃ­a de Doom y es algo que ha envejecido mal

- Es muy fÃ¡cil perderse en los niveles
 
- Que no se haya remasterizado la mÃºsica de TNT: Evilution ni la de Sigil entre otros

- He sufrido muchas salidas al escritorio, es bastante inestable. Hace falta pulirlo algo mÃ¡s

Reviews:
Dawn of War: Soulstorm remains a timeless gem in the RTS genre, and its enduring appeal owes much to several key factors. The graphics, while from an earlier era, have aged remarkably well. The detailed unit designs and atmospheric battlefields still capture the gritty, war-torn essence of the 40k universe, immersing players in the chaos of the far future.

The gameâ€™s story and factions stay true to the Warhammer 40k lore, delivering a narrative that resonates deeply with fans. Each faction feels authentic, from the relentless march of the Necrons to the righteous fury of the Sisters of Battle, ensuring that the gameplay aligns perfectly with the dark, gothic atmosphere of the universe.

Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of Soulstorm is its vibrant modding community. Over the years, dedicated fans have kept the game alive and thriving, introducing new factions, campaigns, and quality-of-life improvements. Mods like the Ultimate Apocalypse and Unification expansions breathe new life into the game, offering a fresh experience even for long-time players.

For fans of 40k and strategy games, Dawn of War: Soulstorm remains an essential classic, as compelling today as it was at launch. | The greatest warhammer RTS game of all time

p.s. the best thing about this game is the mods
For the Emperor!! | The classic 40K RTS. Hasn't been topped since. Juegas como Chell, una prisionera que despierta en las instalaciones de Aperture Science, un complejo de experimentaciÃ³n cientÃ­fica controlado por la frÃ­a y sarcÃ¡stica inteligencia artificial GLaDOS. A medida que avanzas resolviendo acertijos, GLaDOS te guÃ­a (o te manipula) con su tono humorÃ­stico y a veces amenazante, revelando poco a poco la oscura y misteriosa historia detrÃ¡s de los experimentos en el laboratorio. La narrativa se construye de forma sutil, a travÃ©s de la interacciÃ³n con el entorno y las respuestas de GLaDOS, creando una atmÃ³sfera inquietante pero cautivadora, hasta su sorprendente y memorable desenlace. Portal logra combinar de manera brillante el suspenso, el humor negro y la intriga en un juego corto pero profundamente impactante.

It's archaic now, but there's nothing quite like speeding through the city at night while Rise FM plays in the background. | Grand Theft Auto III is like the game that introduced me to a whole new level of chaosâ€”and honestly, I havenâ€™t been the same since. Here I am, minding my business as Claude (the silent protagonist whoâ€™s basically a walking disaster waiting to happen), when suddenly Iâ€™m driving a car at top speed, blasting through a roadblock, and stealing a tank. Oh, and letâ€™s not forget the moment you accidentally start a gang war because you ran over someoneâ€™s foot. Itâ€™s the type of game where you start a mission and somehow end up on a 20-minute joyride, dodging cops, blowing up cars, and asking yourself, â€œHow did this become my life?â€ Itâ€™s absurd, itâ€™s wild, and itâ€™s completely addictive.

The beauty of GTA III lies in its open-world freedom, allowing you to create your own chaotic story. Youâ€™re in Liberty City, a sprawling urban landscape full of different districts, from grimy alleyways to vibrant nightlife hubs, and youâ€™re free to cause as much destruction as you want. Whether youâ€™re helping (or hindering) the cityâ€™s underworld in main missions, or just cruising around causing random mayhem, the game gives you the freedom to make it your own. The mission variety is what really keeps things interestingâ€”one minute youâ€™re doing a high-stakes car chase, and the next, youâ€™re on a hilarious rampage with a fire truck. The NPCs are also totally unpredictable, which always keeps you on your toes.

What makes Grand Theft Auto III a true classic is the way it captures the essence of early 2000s gaming. It was one of the first games to truly open up a city for players to explore, offering a level of immersion and freedom that was revolutionary at the time. It might not have the graphics of modern-day titles, but the gameplay, the wild unpredictability, and the sheer fun of being able to do whatever you want in Liberty City is timeless. If youâ€™re a fan of open-world action games, or if you just want to experience the chaos and charm of one of the most influential games of its time, Grand Theft Auto III is a must-play. Itâ€™s messy, itâ€™s hilarious, and itâ€™s probably one of the most fun experiences you can have while breaking all the rules. | Eski bir oyun ve yeni sistemlerde zor Ã§alÄ±ÅŸÄ±yor. Reviews:
I decided to play this first-person beat 'em up again with my brother, [i]years[/i] after having experienced it via Xbox Live.  And it's a great experience still, holding up far better for me than the likes of [i]Braid[/i] and [i]Limbo[/i].  That's strange, since 2D was and is easier to make [i]immediately[/i] playable on a smaller dev budget.  Now, there [i]is[/i] a little jank in this, as you would expect to find in a [b]3D indie game[/b] made before there was even a real 2D indie boom -- but not nearly as much as I feared.  The wild [b]bio-punk[/b] style comes through as strong as ever without RTX/SSAO/8K textures/DLSS and whatever all the rest of the game-delaying, budget-bloating nonsense is -- and I found myself getting sucked right back in to the wacky world of Zenozoik after knocking about an even jankier and much less interesting reality for a decade-plus.

Such jank as you might experience is all baked into the game engine, primarily in the slight sense of [i]delay[/i] and the queuing you get with the melee inputs.  Ghat's main fisty combo, for instance, is set off by [b]holding[/b] the button down until it is complete, with the other button for hard attacks.  It's polished enough that you can definitely [i]get good[/i] at it, but sometimes the delay will make you feel like a madman flailing with rage when you're in the thick of a big battle.  It kind of works in a [i]thematic[/i] sense, really, when you consider the savage world you're in.  Some people complain about the gun combat too, but I think it works well enough; Ghat and his big extended family mostly fight with feet and fists, and since these biopunk guns, all made of bone, stone, and sinew, take work to reload and aim, [i]of course[/i] they might feel a trifle more awkward than those in a legit FPS.  I know it sounds like trying to wallpaper flaws with an imagined [b]meta-connection[/b] between story and gameplay, but it's seriously fine and feels good when you're actually playing and soaking up all the vibes.

Back in the 2009 of its original release, a lot of people played this because there weren't a lot of options -- it just so happened to be a very good, very memorable game despite the widespread attention it incidentally received.  Nowadays, it will appeal more to the PC indie crowd I think.  It's short, engrossing, and costs as much as a sachet of corn nuts when it's on sale, so why not throw it on the ol' wishlist? | Un clasico, quizas hoy no impresione mucho, pero en el contexto de este juego es super innovador, creativo y original. DisfrutÃ© jugarlo y seguir su historia. Espero con ganas jugar la segunda parte y el Artifacts of Chaos. | Incredible visual and sound design. Amateur voice acting but it gets better in the sequels. Never thought I would see a Source engine fighting game. Go buy this for a surreal experience. | The gameplay largely consists of first person brawls that are just fun to play through. The setting and story and characters are all very, very weird, so if you enjoy the bizarre or like unique settings then you absolutely should play this at least once. | -Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½. Reviews:
While this game has great nostagia and is super fun, the controls are so bad that I can<t in good conscience tell modern gamers to buy it. | Crash-tastic! 

My memory of this game, of playing it off a CD, is that you could read an entire comic book waiting for a new level to load. Unfortunately that's the part of the game that has been preserved here. Bugs galore, including having actions edge off screen and characters 'dropping' through buildings making them unmovable or un-engagable. What was fun about this game originally was the campy concept and bright colors. It doesn't look right now. The bright colors and comic book dashes and dots with this early animation style doesn't scream page-turning immersive world. It's like a cheap, superficial game you'd get on a cellphone. 

The missions can be painfully simplistic and there isn't a sense of team building or world building. Your reward is largely your own imagination as you earn enough to unlock 'sets' of abilities or skills. If you're someone who wants the nostalgia either from the original release or from the really, really old comics, this might scratch the itch. If you have even slightly high standards informed by modern games, you'll be disappointed. 

The idea that something this simplistic came out in the same era as the Halo games or even the early Civilization games is a little shocking to contemplate. The people who designed it loved Patriot City and some of the 1980's kind of super villain tropes. They had fun with this, clearly, I just don't think it aged well and given the depth of both missions and conceptual design of other early 2000's games I remain shocked it was ever reviewed and ranked so highly. 

I guess get it if it's on sale or you're really, really curious about what people did when they weren't playing Quake back in the day.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure what the hype is about this game, but I'm not sure what the hype is about. The controls are so bad that I can't tell modern gamers to buy it.

Game Name: The Elder Scrolls IV: OblivionÂ® Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
If you're new to this title:
Oblivion isn't a game that you play. Oblivion is a game that you conquer.
Yes, the graphics and mechanics haven't aged well. Yes, the dialogue is often hilariously unhinged. And yes, the game is ripe with bugs and quest breaking sequences that induce a paranoid amount of saving. But its' defects can also be broken in your favor. THAT realization is when the game grips you:
What can you get away with? What cheese tactics, what exploits, or what innocuous and obscure thing (like picking up and dropping a paintbrush from your inventory... this is not a joke) can you leverage to your adventureâ€” and how far can you leverage it? And there's so much to be adventured: every nook and cranny or every dungeon, achieve and ace every quest, grind every attribute and skill to max, collect every unique item, and then, after a 100+ hours... lament that it's over.

Which brings us to those who are returning to this title:
You know as well as I that this game has near to no replay value. Everything Oblivion has to offer can be experienced in a single playthrough, and the narrative has little to no variation (nor any substantial dialogue or narrative choices for those hopping for more RP in their RPG like the CRPGs that predated it).

It can be a hell of a ride, but with a story you can only fully revel in once, as a fresh player.
Otherwise you're only left to recall the insatiable desire to see and do everything until the memory of your previous experience is restored, which quickly dulls the experience.
However, on a personal note, I will add: that one thing I recalled was that this was one of the few games that truly made me feel as though I were fighting an endless army of demons; running, jumping, and cutting through one Oblivion gate after another...
And I felt it still, even years after its' initial release.
May it make you feel such heartiness as well. | its a nightmare to make this game stable. but its SUPER modable so you can alter it in any way you want like a sandbox. i recommend your learn the modding tools they are easy and you can make a lot of fun stuff for roleplay etc. and despite the goofiness it can be an engaging story, deep lore and great questlines.
if you're unconfortable with the modding and fixing and all that nonsese, and you own skyrim special edition i suggest you buy it just so you can get skyblivion this year (LATE 2025).
its a remake of oblivion made by modders in the skyrim se engine (with unique updated assets/worldmap/EVERYTHING) and the full game will be required to isntall it | This is the best Elder Scrolls game to date, and the best value for your money on Steam in the category of first-person action RPGs. It is a sandbox environment that starts you out on the island that the main city is in, in the center of the map. Each city has a different architectural theme, and a house that you can purchase if you have enough gold and meet the other criteria. The interface is far better than both its predecessor, Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, and its successor, Elder Scrolls IV: Skyrim. The character design is also superior to both, as they did away with character classes in Skyrim. The game world is more beautiful if you don't follow the main quest past delivering the item to the monk at the piory, because if you close the first oblivion gate then oblivion gates start popping up all over the map. There is plenty to explore without the main quest. | una de las mejores compras que hice, pueden decir que tiene mil bugs, que necesita parches, etc pero no me pueden negar que con los mods es un pozo para invertirle horas | Loved this elder scrolls, great main story, cool ending, the world is pretty okay but aged exceptionally well for a 2006 release. NPC's are sometimes pretty odd but certainly an iteration on their continuous polishing & improvement of their approach in the RPG genre, which is portrayed in Skyrim. A recommended playthrough, especially for the main story!
cleaned_review: Oblivion is a game that you conquer.

Game Name: The Elder Scrolls III: MorrowindÂ® Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
My play time on steam is only a tiny fraction of my time in this game. I've played this game on both console and PC since 2004. I still think this is the best game of The Edler Scrolls series. I'd pick the vanilla version of this game over the vanilla version of Skyrim. Skyrim only beats Morrowind, in my mind, because of the fantastic mods available. | It's aged surprisingly well, if you can get past the combat. Treat it less as an action RPG and more of a 3D visualization of what is going on, and it gets a lot better. Some graphical mods to make it more visually appealing, and it's a great game even today, for some audiences. | Everyone said that the early game hours would be painful and dull. I disagree. If you are having trouble I would recommend a character with high agility. It's easier to hit the enemies that way. If you get lucky, you can kill a dark brotherhood assassin and get his OP loot. World building is really cool so far and I'm having a blast playing. I hope it doesn't change! | This game has flaws for sure, it's old, clanky, some mechanics are dated. But, probably the best example of what a Bethesda RPG could be now days. 
 | Might be a little odd to play at first if you are not used to the combat mechanics and you will get lost if you don't have any idea of what you are doing, it has its little flaws here and there, but its also a quite charming game with a with a unique fantasy look to it!
cleaned_review: I still think this is the best game of The Edler Scrolls series. I'd pick the vanilla version of this game over the vanilla version of Skyrim. Skyrim only beats Morrowind, in my mind, because of the fantastic mods available. | It's aged surprisingly well, if you can get past the combat. Treat it less as an action RPG and more of a 3D visualization of what is going on, and it gets a lot better. Some graphical mods to make it more visually appealing, and it's a great game even today, for some audiences. | Everyone said that the early game hours would be painful and dull. I disagree. If you are having trouble I would recommend a character with high agility. It's easier to hit the enemies that way. If you get lucky, you can kill a dark brotherhood assassin and get his OP loot. World building is really cool so far and I'm having a blast playing. I hope it doesn't change!

Terminei o jogo com 15 horas de duraÃ§Ã£o. | So first off, not the worst but not the best. It IS definitely a classic worth owning, that being said It is a classic with the problems of it's time. So if your new to the game remember that. There IS story but not really the focus, the focus of the game was it's destruction system, If you played Just Cause 2 and up it's basically that story wise and game-play wise except on mars and no flight ability. I like the game as a not so serious Legal weed edible on and off game. I play it to blow stuff up in creative ways and not think too much about anything else. If you play on above normal thou be prepared to kill many people as the enemy may and will drown you in themselves and watch ammo. Try and not to be too sympathetic about allies dying as they are as dumb as they can be and show up often without request and are at best expendable distraction, they can also make things worse if your trying to be selective in your destruction. The best way to save them is to not see them die and lose your alert level.

The game for what it is....Is simple. What you do in the game you will be doing till the end of it with enough upgrades and story to get you to it's end. A classic with flaws to be sure but in terms of entertainment it's sure to be better than nothing and worth a grab on sale or full price. Would it be better with a good story? Sure, maybe... But does a game with destruction mechanics that are still highly intricate and advanced 15+ years later really need to have a deep story? Mindlessly smash and explode your problems away until you bring down the entire political system of Mars.

Red Faction Guerrila was a simple game with a simple story but a enjoyable one with a couple of things that could have some better design choices. Right from the the start you know what to expect in the game. You know what areas there is to explore and what to do to restore them to what they were before thing gone bad. The EDF is here and they are not welcome, the barricades, the defenses, the turrents, all most be gone and lucky for you, you will have a great arsenal to make things easier. There are 6 areas for you to focus in the main story and plenty of side activities to keep you busy but not enough for you to get burn out doing them all. I finished around 30 activities and after that I felt I've seen everything there was to see and the remaining would be more copy and paste without anything new so I stopped doing them and went back to the main story.  

Performance wise I only got a crash to the desktop and it was during the DLC main mission. Aside of that, when exiting the game I got a black screen a couple of times, nothing serious. Pushing the FOV to the max makes the game feels so much better, I highly recommend it. Gameplay wise it's a solid game but could have better mechanics. The cars feel a little too stiff when cornering and wobbly on the desert segments. Guns are more than enough and it does not get old destrying everything. Be cautious of how you use them because the AI allies tend to be a little too close for you and sometimes when swinging the hammer the worst can happen. It wouldn't be too bad if you didn't get a morale penalty when your allies die. Speaking of dying, you also get lower morale when you die so if you are dying too much just drop the difficulty down and you'll be good to go. The music feels good and gave me some Mad Max vibes. The world does not offer much variety and cut-scenes could be better looking but it's normal considering the initial release of the game.
 
12 hours after, I finished the main game with some side activities. The DLC is well worth your time and it's a quick one with around 2 more hours from start to finish. I got all the activities and main missions as well destroying everything in the DLC in two gaming sessions.
cleaned_review: The game is a bit better than the original, but it is still a bit better than the original.

Reviews:
I remember having played this game when I was a younger and wanting to try it again... I've played a lot of ARPGs in my time and this game just isn't good, not with the lots of other games there are nowadays and that were there even during its time. I didn't go into it with wanting to dislike it, but have not really found many things to like, or at the very least enough for me to like the game, enjoy my experience, and give it a positive review.

I'm not a fan of the graphics, but that's always been the least important aspect when it comes to games for me, but I can't believe this game is from 2009 judging from... well, everything. The graphics didn't age well (looks like a cheap mobile game), amount of classes (3?!), mechanics, skills and skill trees (every class has 15 active and 15 passive skills), loot (a lot of trash drops) and the controls and combat - very clunky, I tried playing a Vanquisher (kind of a Rogue/Marksman class) and the ranged attacks usually either didn't even connect or only had range for about half the screen.

I'd have expected the game to be at least 10 years older than that, everything just feels so lackluster and jank for its time. If it were, I wouldn't have been so harsh with the review but simply put, there were games that were miles ahead at the time - Titan Quest or Diablo II, which lo and behold, are still very good and playable to this day, even in spite of being older.

There are some nice ideas, like the pet, being able to send it back to town to sell your items. If only the inventory wasn't 3x7, while also having to carry scrolls and potions, making it at least 4 slots smaller. Other than that though, the pet is just basically a way worse and dumbed-down version of the Diablo II mercenary. The only other "good" thing about the game is that you can mod it and the mods don't disable steam achievements, at least the ones I installed. This would be good if the base game itself was good and if some mods just didn't feel mandatory to make the experience less painful.

Now if we move on to the cons, other than everything already mentioned above, there is no respec, why? Yes, there is a mod for it, but still. There were games before its time that had this mechanic, so why does this game not have it?

I am playing in very hard softcore and the game still feels very easy regardless of that, which brings me to the balance being very poor - still remember my first death, which was to a trapped chest dealing over 50% of my health in a zone 5 levels below me, while literally every single other trap I've triggered dealt about 1/10 of the damage of this one, pretty much not even moving my health bar. I just don't get it. On top of that, the monster damage on very hard gets absurd very quickly, even before completing the story you're gonna start getting constantly oneshot with very little counterplay, unless you're of course kiting around half the map and standing half a screen away from the mobs.

This game didn't bring anything new at the time that would be meaningful and worthwhile enough to mention. Unless you're going into the game with extremely strong nostalgia, can't recommend. It is cheap though, so I'll at least give it that. | . SÃ£o 3 personagens fixos e sem nome, nÃ£o tem como customizar a aparÃªncia, cada um Ã© uma classe diferente. 
. A mulher usa armas de fogo, o grandalhÃ£o Ã© o berserker e o magrelo Ã© o mago.

. No inÃ­cio escolhemos um pet, lobo ou lince. Eu achei muito viciante e desafiador no modo HARDCORE. Recomendo! Nota 9/10 | [h1] Cozy ARPG for fans of Diablo 1[/h1]
[h3] Should play well on almost all systems [/h3]

I love this game. I used to play it on my low spec netbook that struggled even running chrome, it ran this game well. There are a ton of better ARPGs out there, but none of them are as "minimalist" as this one. Single dungeon with multiple levels, basic classes and skills, small town with quest givers. It is a bare bones ARPG and that is not necessarily a bad thing. Not having to stress over synergies (non existent) complex skill trees (as basic as they come) makes this game perhaps the coziest ARPG out there. 

[b]Not recommended if you are looking for deep game mechanics, complex builds or modern quality of life improvements. [/b]

The only thing that would complete this game for me is if it had multiplayer, but Torchlight 2 has it, so maybe you'd want to pick up that one instead. | Decent and fun diablo-type game, but a lot easier to get into. Reviews:

Ğ³Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾Ğµ Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ¹. | There's no point to really play this game if you have HD TSE as well. But if you don't then this is a great way to play The First Encounter. The only good reason why you would play this with having HD TSE is for the Trading Cards and Achievements. | Classic FPS. Grab this when it is on sale. The Serious Sam franchise goes on sale frequently. | This game really fucking sucks im going to be so honest.

I have never seen a shooter punish exploration, and ammo/health resupplying as much as this game.  1 armor pickup? spawn 20 enemies. have 10 shells across the map you slowly trod your way to get? spawn in the tankiest enemies that'll eat up that ammo you just got.  I stopped collecting health pickups because i swear to fuck every single health pickup that doesn't spawn in front of you is tied to enemies that'll immediately eat it up.
I also love how they have a key rebind settings tab that doesn't let you rebind a chunk of the buttons despite them being there. quick saving is such a damn pain.
It also takes forever to get any sort of interesting weapons and none of them really are satisfying with how little damage they do. | Ğ»ĞµĞ³ĞµĞ½Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°, ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñƒ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾ ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¸Ğµ

Reviews:
It's cool to have all the Serious Sam games in one place, and all of the old ones have been remastered and are excellent. Highly recommend for Serious Sam fans or the FPS old school genre fan in general. | Great shooter but we couldn't play the mods together. | I always ignored this game because I thought it was a prototype demo for a cancelled Serious Sam game or something. Turns out it's the First & Second Encounter HDs and BFE all in one game with updates. It's great! Works well on Linux too.

I saw online that most people recommend playing these games through here rather than their standalone versions. I would agree as best I know.

I wish it had the non-HD versions and SS2 as well, but no biggie. | While the classic versions of TFE and TSE are better than the HD versions, this has workshop support, meaning easy access to levels and mods. Dead enemies have weird physics but that's not a big deal.

I especially enjoyed the mod "Serious Sam BFE: Redux" by SeriousAmaro. It has way better pacing than the original SS3, turning a mediocre experience into a great one. | Que divertido es matar aliens. Falta un modo pacifico pero de igual forma esta bueno.
cleaned_review: Great shooter but we couldn't play the mods together.

Genres: Action, Casual, Free To Play, Indie, Simulation, Strategy
Reviews:
Fact: I've played this more then any 60 dollar game.  It's just fun, and you can play it for 5 minutes if that's all you got, or two hours.  No negatives, just an addicting little cartoon plane game that can hook you. | One of the best underrated multiplayer games. And it's ultra low spec.
Best part of this is the football. You got football played with planes and you can't underestimate how good that is. 
5 different planes add some good depth to it. 
If you're a beginner- it's worth finding a football server with bots, and learning how to pass and all that. Also there's a good fun tutorial prepared by altitude. 
Most common server is 14 people, and sometimes the skill level can be quite high. In which case be maybe a bit prepared for some grumpy players especially if you don't know which direction you're going, don't know how to pass, and go for enormous kill counts and neglecting the ball. 
Otherwise, enjoy one of the most underrated multiplayer games on the internet, and which is free as well. | A few years ago I had a lot of fun with this game.  Not sure if it's still alive/active or whatever and I can't exactly find out since my account is just, I don't know, gone?  It's weird.

It was really fun, though.  Like a lot of games that have an overall account level, though, it wasn't the most balanced.  Later upgrades and planes were just, you know, objectively better than starting things.  The ships aren't necessarily rock-paper-scissors in design but there are elements like that to them.  Having said that, the starting ship is probably the best one, which is good for beginners.

Regardless, the ships were balanced enough that you could play whatever and probably be fine in most situations.  The game modes were varied enough.  You had death match and team death match, yeah, but there was also a mode where you destroyed an enemy base, and another where you effectively played soccor with the space ships.  I really liked the last one, but they were all fun and I'd play whatever when I did.

Controls were fine, graphics were fine, sounds were fine.  The only problem I ever encountered were some latency issues, where people would just appear to teleport somewhere else or where you were clearly disconnecting (everyone was falling or flying into walls).

Yeah, every now and then I boot this up and try to figure out my old account, or to make my old account work, but it never happens.  Had a lot of good times and I would totally play some more, if not a lot, should I ever fix that.  Good game, if you see it on sale, do check it out.  Assuming it's still alive.  It might not be!

The edit: game is mostly dead except for old elitists, apparently.  Shame.  Guess they are a pretty closed off community and not friendly to newbs.  Oh well.  RIP altitude. | A few years back, this game was great. It had a small community but enough to make the game worth playing. As of now there's probably only a few dozen people playing.

I wouldn't recommend purchasing it now unless it's extremely cheap and you're curious, but during its active lifespan it was a great game.

8/10 | Skill, adresse et reflexe, un concentrÃ© du meilleur dans un petit jeux. MÃªme ma femme y joue !

Addictif et sans prÃ©tention.
cleaned_review: 'Football' is a great game, but it's not the best.

Game Name: LEGOÂ® Star Warsâ„¢ - The Complete Saga
Reviews:
This is unequivocally the best Lego game ever made. 
The combat and graphics in this game are detailed
and makes the game one to revisit for years to come
10/10 game | The first real game I ever played was LEGOÂ® Star Warsâ„¢ - The Complete Saga, excluding Flash games. Honestly, it's a masterpiece in every way. The comedy, charm, and creativity make this an unforgettable experience. Also, after playing LEGOÂ® Star Warsâ„¢: The Skywalker Saga, I found it surprising that you cannot design your own Jedi or Sith even though it is a newer game. Instead, you're trapped with a predetermined cast of characters. However, in The Complete Saga, you can create your own personalized characters by mixing and matching pieces as desired. That increased freedom is why The Complete Saga is the GOAT. It allows you to actually play out your own Star Wars experience in a way that the newer game just doesnâ€™t. 10/10 | It's all a bit old, and the multiplayer isn't properly implemented for that, but it's a classic for a reason. Solid entertainment with lots of fun bits to explore. | Could be on a top 10 list for the greatest video games of all time. Perhaps is the greatest LEGO video game of all time. Not many games can stand the test of time like this one has, with a near perfect reception record. Thank you for this beautiful gift you have so graciously given us, developers. | Lego Star Wars the Complete Saga is The GOAT of Lego games.  All other opinions are wrong!  Thank you and have a good day.
cleaned_review: The Complete Saga is a classic, and it's a masterpiece.

Game Name: Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
This review is for the steam version of the game. Currently, the game is literally unplayable. Upon starting a new game, the loading screen runs for a second, and then the application crashes. I have tried two settings changes and a mod, the only recommendations I could find online, and I still can not play my game. This is not a problem that only I am having. Look online. It offers freedom without sacrificing a focused story. It delivers fantastic combat without forgoing a deep role-playing system.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3424840194 | Some would say that Fallout 3 is a failure, the worst game in the franchise, why do they say that? Hell if I know. This is a wonderful game and has the same kind of charm as Fallout New Vegas, minus a few gameplay addons and PLUS a whole lot of fun. This game pioneers a "whacky" theme to fallout opposed to a highly immersive one. | I originally played this game + all DLCs on the Xbox 360 near its release. It is a classic open world game that you should play at least once in your lifetime. I personally prefer it over New Vegas but mainly due to nostalgia. A negative: on PC it runs slightly worse optimization wise.

one of the best games I could possibly recommend for low end computers. incredible gameplay and great story | Game is automatically incredible because of the parachute and grappling hook mechanic. | Tried this game several times over the years and hallelujah it finally clicked. Had a handful of crashes and a few freezes, but this game definitely holds up and is completely addicting. After 71 hours for 75% I feel like I'm just starting to get good at the controls. 10/10 am playing again on hardest difficulty. | [h1]This game is a gift that keeps on giving.[/h1] 

Even if you don't feel like playing through the story, much like GTA, you can mess about around the map. One of my favourite things to do is using the grappling hook to string people up from the street lights. This game is old, and it shows but it is slightly better than it appears. I nearly gave up due the poor control but with changing the camera behind the character, it was playable. The game initially bombed out at the start, but changing the config as suggested by others made it work for me. 

I even said I was having fun when I got to bash up the bully - three times! Voice acting is great even though the speech was a bit slow than ideal. The initial positive impression soon turned negative however. I got frustrated with the unwieldy UI - for example, in the cauldron mission where you need to cool boiling cauldrons, you will have to open up the Inventory and click on the quest item to cool. The inventory screen would not stay open and cauldrons exploded as I tried to keep having to open up the screen and mouse-click the item. You cannot create a short-cut to the quest item,  but why not? The second issue is that enemies are damage-sponge even at the easy level - which makes the game excessively long although not necessarily hard. 

With some refinements, this game could have been great, but it is currently something I couldn't recommend for modern audiences. Save your money and play something else. | å°æ—¶å€™åœ¨è·¯è¾¹æ‘Šä¹°çš„ç›˜ã€‚ã€‚ | ĞĞ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ³Ğ¸Ñ ÑˆĞºĞ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ²Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ñ‘Ğ½. | Mi juego favorito de la infancia | .

Um novo fÃ´lego para a franquia:

A principal novidade de Metro Redux fica por conta do uso da versÃ£o mais recente da 4Âª Engine, que jÃ¡ se mostra bem adaptada aos requisitos da nova geraÃ§Ã£o de consoles. Na prÃ¡tica, isso se reflete em modelos tridimensionais com uma qualidade melhor, em um novo sistema de iluminaÃ§Ã£o e em texturas com um nÃ­vel maior de detalhes.

O maior beneficiado pelo novo motor grÃ¡fico Ã© Metro 2033, lanÃ§ado no jÃ¡ distante ano de 2010. Embora o game ainda possa ser considerado belo (especialmente no PC), o trabalho feito pelos desenvolvedores conseguiu trazer a ele um novo nÃ­vel de qualidade â€” o que deve ajudar a justificar o retorno daqueles que jÃ¡ conferiram a versÃ£o original.

AlÃ©m de adotar modelos de personagens com uma qualidade maior de detalhes, o game ganha texturas em alta resoluÃ§Ã£o que permitem apreciar melhor a direÃ§Ã£o de arte da 4A Games. O tÃ­tulo tambÃ©m traz monstros com um visual aprimorado e diversas adiÃ§Ãµes Ã s suas animaÃ§Ãµes, o que garante uma maior naturalidade de movimentos tanto para personagens humanos quanto para as criaturas mutantes que vocÃª deve enfrentar.

Metro 2033 tambÃ©m ganhou algumas atualizaÃ§Ãµes em suas mecÃ¢nicas de jogo, adotando um sistema de controles idÃªntico Ã quele visto na sequÃªncia Last Light. Outro ponto que mostra a dedicaÃ§Ã£o dos desenvolvedores a realmente fazer um trabalho de qualidade sÃ£o as cenas de corte do jogo, que agora sÃ£o reproduzidas exclusivamente em primeira pessoa â€” com direito a diversos momentos interativos.


ExperiÃªncia que se sustenta:

O ponto que mais se destaca no conteÃºdo visto em Metro Redux Ã© a maneira como a franquia continua parecendo â€œfrescaâ€, mesmo que seu primeiro capÃ­tulo tenha sido lanÃ§ado hÃ¡ quase meia dÃ©cada. Muito disso se deve Ã  ambientaÃ§Ã£o explorada pela 4A Games, que se assemelha muito mais a um game do gÃªnero Survival Horror do que a um FPS convencional.

Talvez ciente de que nem todos os jogadores podem se interessar por um tÃ­tulo com certas restriÃ§Ãµes, o estÃºdio decidiu criar dois estilos de jogabilidade: Survival e Spartan. Enquanto o primeiro reduz a quantidade de muniÃ§Ãµes e armamentos que vocÃª encontra (o que torna a experiÃªncia mais assustadora), o segundo age como um â€œjogo de tiro convencionalâ€, permitindo que vocÃª seja mais descuidado durante os combates.

Independente da opÃ§Ã£o que vocÃª escolher, a experiÃªncia bÃ¡sica de ambos os jogos se mantÃ©m impressionantemente sÃ³lida. Grande parte disso se deve Ã  presenÃ§a de adversÃ¡rios com uma boa inteligÃªncia artificial (que sofreu aprimoramentos notÃ¡veis na versÃ£o Redux, especialmente em Metro 2033) e tambÃ©m Ã  maneira como os combates sÃ£o construÃ­dos.


Vale a pena? Muito bom mesmo vale muito a pena !!!

Devemos ser bem sinceros: caso vocÃª jÃ¡ tenha finalizado Metro 2033 e Metro Last Light, a aquisiÃ§Ã£o de Metro Redux nÃ£o Ã© exatamente necessÃ¡ria â€” afinal, por maiores que sejam as melhorias apresentadas, em essÃªncia os jogos permanecem idÃªnticos. No entanto, quem nÃ£o pÃ´de conferir as experiÃªncias em sua Ã©poca de lanÃ§amento (ou simplesmente quer revivÃª-las) nÃ£o poderia pedir muito mais da remasterizaÃ§Ã£o.

Nesse sentido, surge como vantagem a possibilidade de poder adquirir as duas versÃµes Redux de forma individual atravÃ©s do meio digital. Dessa maneira, vocÃª pode escolher somente o tÃ­tulo que mais lhe interessa, deixando de lado aquele com qual jÃ¡ tem mais familiaridade â€” algo que, devemos admitir, deve prejudicar um pouco as vendas de Last Light em sua versÃ£o para PC.

Caso vocÃª simplesmente nunca tenha entrado no universo de Metro, essa Ã© a melhor opÃ§Ã£o para conhecer o universo da franquia. Metro: Redux Ã© a versÃ£o definitiva dos dois tÃ­tulos da sÃ©rie e seu grande nÃ­vel de qualidade deixa uma boa perspectiva do que podemos esperar para os trabalhos futuros do estÃºdio 4A Games.

* Jogabilidade renovada ajuda a atualizar Metro 2033
