Reviews:
A fun little point'n'click. Clearly heavily inspired by Monkey Island, but that's no bad thing.

One annoying technical quirk is an improper aspect ratio if playing full-screen on a modern 16:9 monitor. So your options are playing in a 800x600 window, or messing with your display settings. Other than that it ran perfectly on a modern Windows 11 system.

Seasoned adventure game players are likely to find the puzzles a touch easy. I finished the game in around 4 hours without using the hint system. Some of the puzzles were similar to those found in Monkey Island and, weirdly, Loom, so that probably helped me along. But I never found the puzzles to be unsatisfying or wholly unoriginal.

The story is a little cookie-cutter, but there are a few fun twists and turns. The main character is very likeable, honestly a rarity in comedic point'n'clicks. Good art and voice-acting.

Overall, well worth dropping a few quid on. ğŸ‘
cleaned_review: A fun point'n'click game.

Reviews:
SimCity 4 is arguably one of, if not the best city builder games out there. It is unmatched in quite a few ways.

In terms of graphics,, it's timeless. i'm amazed how well the visuals have held up over the years. I think the realism mixed with a distinct art-style is what does it. The not quite isometric camera angle and 3D assets go a long way as well.

Game-play and simulation is what really make SimCity 4 stand out though. You're not just zoning a bunch of RCI and watching all the money roll in. You actually have to be careful and manage your funds or else things will go south quickly. Yet at the same time, it's extremely rewarding to see your city succeed.

You're also provided with a plethora of ways to keep track of what's going on in your city. Not only do you have advisors and graphs; but you also can also turn on a bunch of different overlays to look for pollution, traffic, crime, etc. One of my favourite features though is the query tool. With this you can check how and where residents commute on top of other things.

With Residential and Commercial; not only can you choose 3 different density levels, but you can quite easily control the wealth too. There's also 4 different types of industrial (Farms, Dirty, Manufacturing, and High-Tech) with 2 density levels for all except farms.

I could go on and on about how great this SimCity 4 is but there's just so much. That's not to say it doesn't have flaws though. Vanilla traffic path finding is pretty bad, there are some game breaking bugs, and it just does not like modern computers very much. Fortunately most of this can be fixed with mods and some tinkering.

In the end i'd highly recommend this SimCity 4 to anyone who enjoys city building games. | The best city building game ever made. Runs surprisingly well on modern PCs too. For 2003 this shit was super ahead of its time, Im still waiting for someone to make a city builder that allows you to adjust peoples taxes based on their income. | Este juego es uno de los mejores clÃ¡sicos en el gÃ©nero de ConstrucciÃ³n y GestiÃ³n, pues si bien ya tiene 2 dÃ©cadas desde que se lanzÃ³ en 2003, se nota que. Por ejemplo, podemos construir una regiÃ³n entera y gestionarla; terraformar terrenos cuando todavÃ­a no inaguramos una ciudad con el objetivo de, entre otras cosas preparar y proyectar quÃ© tan plano deberÃ­a ser para recibir una cierta cantidad de habitantes; hacer mapas personalizados de hasta 128 kilÃ³metros de lado, equivalente a un poco mÃ¡s de una quinta parte del largo de la Provincia de Santiago del Estero, que serÃ­an 540 kilÃ³metros, entre otros. | O jogo Ã© muito divertido, e se vocÃª se dedicar a entender a dinÃ¢mica do jogo, vocÃª vai conseguir se divertir bastante nele! | Classic pc game. I have to reinstall right now to try and fix a crashing issue. Could just be my ancient pc. Super fun game!
cleaned_review: SimCity 4 is arguably one of, if not the best city builder games out there. It is unmatched in quite a few ways. In terms of graphics, it's timeless. I'm amazed how well the visuals have held up over the years. I think the realism mixed with a distinct art-style is what does it.

 | Releasing an update that stops the game from even running is anti-consumer and all potential buyers should avoid games by Firaxis games studio and it's related partners in the future. This likely includes all future civilization games, but i'm not a wizard so I cannot say for certain if another studio might take up new entries in this particular series.

Furthermore steam should be making more of an effort to punish games studios who do this. I am very disappointed in Steam for even allowing this to occur.

Users should not be forced on to the forums to find some fix posted by a third party from another website and dig into the game files just to make it function.

This is clear and obvious trick to force people to play newer titles and should be punished accordingly. | Amazing game and out right fun with friends regardless of what happens. Why don't I recommend the game? I am unable to even launch the game anymore and have tried hundreds of hours to try fixing it. It's unplayable and the support I've reached out to either ignores me or says it's steam's issue for the game not working and steam won't take any form of help when requests are made to them. This is a great example why you shouldn't throw in extra connections or third party connections etc. One thing is removed and it's all broke.What's worse? They're still trying to sell the game despite KNOWING it's unplayable. They KNOW it's unplayable and still choose to sell it. A, at this time, $29.99 game that is NOT ABLE TO BE STARTED. 

When the game is fixed the review will be changed obviously but until then I can not recommend the game to anyone. I do not reccomend buying this gaming NFT.

Reviews:
An unexpected joy. Who knew capitalism became palatable when you can literally seize the means of production. I found the narrative charming and often hilariously meta, the dungeons fun in their complexity arising from a bunch of seemingly simple pieces, and the shop dynamics an interesting counterpart thereto. It's a challenge without being punishing, and the loops are all snappy, punchy fun. | The true godfather of the "Running your own shop" simulator style games, going out on adventures to find things to sell or just buying products to mark them up at a premium. I've actually done an entire playthrough of finishing the game where I didnt go out to adventure at all, i'd just buy products from stores or from customers looking to sell and then sell them at a premium. Its criminal that this game has no true sequel all these years later as the game which influenced a genre

Capitalism, Ho! 
Pay off that debt!
 | A must-play for fans of simulation and light RPGs!
A charming and innovative indie game that combines shop management with dungeon crawling, offering a unique twist on traditional RPG mechanics. After so many years King's Bounty still one of the best TBS on the market. 
Basically, you love the genre you have the following options:

1. King's Bounty 
2. HOMM 3 or HOMM 3 + Horn of the Abyss
3. HOMM 5 (never played but it seems good)
4. New Song of Conquest (bought, but haven't played yet)

Age of Wonders and other 4X don't fit, so they cannot be really considered. 
Also, a viable option is Spellforce but it has RTS elements.
Or some more 'tactic' games where you have arena after arena but it's totally different stuff.

What I absolutely love about the game:
1. Old KB (HOMM) formula: mix of basic RPG elements with a turn-based strategy game
2. Fairy, fantasy, hand-crafted visual
3. Casual, silly humor and in some way deconstruction of the fantasy genre
4. Engaging combat with a huge variety of units and fun bosses
5. Absolutely gorgeous music that goes in a row for me with another Katauri masterpiece > Space Rangers!
6. A mix of graphics, design and music creates a vivid fairy tail atmosphere and a cozy feeling deep inside my soul :)
7. Spirit of adventure, princesses, dragons and pirates!
8. Strong nostalgic feeling. For me personally :P

I played it more than 5 times for sure and after all these years, yeah, the graphic looks a bit poor and bleak, but only for the first few hours. After that, it's hard to leave this world of magic and epic battles!

Definitely recommend it to anyone who likes the genre and who just likes slow-paced gameplay with nice visuals and pleasant music. Ğ ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñƒ Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ¹ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¸ĞºĞ¸. | steam keeps asking if i recommend this game and frankly, iâ€™m not sure. i had genuine fun with it for about 50 hours, but i kind of suffered through the last 10. why? because at its core, itâ€™s a solid Piranha Bytes game meaning the hardcore beginning and the lengthy first act (easily half the game) are the best parts. you know, all that classic routine: learning the worldâ€™s rules, figuring out who the baddest baddie is, and choosing a faction to side with. running errands for some sketchy hombres. exploring caves and shores, only to get smashed on the head by a random ostrich (or whatever the hell those things are). getting bullied by the bullies at first and bullying them later. mugging and getting mugged. waking up NPCs in the middle of the night just to pester them with dumb questions. waiting until nightfall just to use the smithy because, during the day, those bulky blacksmith bastards hog it nonstop, leaving you waiting for a turn that will never come. sound familiar? thatâ€™s because this game is basically [i]Gothic[/i], just in a slightly different setting with much better graphics. plus, Kai Rosenkranz composed the ambient music for this one too, and his tunes really hit close to home.

BUT, the first time you try to take on some lizardmen, youâ€™ll realize the combat is janky as hell. all those action points you invested in sword fighting? they donâ€™t mean dreck because those bastards block [i]everything[/i]. every fight becomes a battle of wills: me vs. the will to keep enduring this suffering. and then, when youâ€™ve finished all the open world stuff and only the plot missions remain, youâ€™ll remember: the main story is the weakest part of the game. itâ€™s just uninteresting and painfully boring. again. yep guys, this is truly a Piranha Bytes game. also, i was surprised to see in the credits that Andy Serkis, Lena Headey and Johnathan Rhys-Davies contributed voice work. why? because the acting [i]felt[/i] kind of uninspired. or maybe the writing was so generic and dull that i ended up skipping most of the dialogue and missed everything. who knows?

to wrap this up: after all i do recommend playing this game because Piranha Bytes knows how to create an engaging, tightly packed open world. but beware, itâ€™s an old game, and it has its fair share of jank. actually, quite a lot of jank. but hey, letâ€™s admit it, thatâ€™s part of its charm. | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ€Ñ‹Ğ² Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°! Ğ”Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ¶ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ. Yes, I liked it. It may be difficult to understand at first, but it's worth figuring it out. The game rewards exploration and return because some places are not so easy to get to. I recommend playing the public beta version, because achievement statistics are considered correct and a number of bugs are avoided. And one more thing: do not kill animals immediately, but avoid them if possible, so that in the future, after receiving the necessary tools and cutting, you can get more trophies. And be saved more often. Achievements are not very difficult. | After playing the Gothic series, this game, its characters and the landscape ring a bell in the memories and warms the heart.

As someone who has never played a Gothic game before I have to admit that the game looks very promising but atleast the playtest does still have some problems. (The game says I only played 0,1h but In fact I actually played over an hour offline because I had no connection, that was also the reason why I played it) 

1. Audio - It seems like that they still need to fix the audio because the conversations dont feel natural. Characters make breaks while talking where it doesnt make any sense. 

2. Bug - I guess you could say this is a bug because whenever I killed those meatbugs and looted them, the dead bodies of them were still glowing, even through buildings. When I was at the tower for the fire I still saw those dead meatbugs glow through every single wall.

3. Graphics - They look decent but there is still room for improvement but overall they are totally fine.

4. No syncro? - Im from austria so I do speak german and I do know for a fact that Gothic is famous for his german voiceover, I guess they just didnt implement it in the Playtest.

5. Fighting - Im not really a big fan how the game wants you to fight, I guess its something you have to get used to but its something new.

Im looking forward to this game because for a long time Im already searching for a medieval themed rpg that is not souls like. | wow fellers! You are did the best you could with this teaser, and lemme tell you something. Don't you ever release full version of the game, if this is the best you can do. Absolute garbage. Even fossil original game has better combat system and graphics. Absolute trash. I don't even know what did you expect. | I feel I need to clarify a few things:
- The upcoming Gothic game will be very different from this teaser.
- The combat and graphics of Gothic have been shown in videos and they are completely different from this "test" teaser.
- The hero will come back. Both the hero and Diego have been completely changed between 2019 and 2025. On release they'll look nothing like this teaser.
- The Teaser itself is decent, hero talks too much. The devs said they did that on purpose to get some feedback.

I recommend giving it a try just to experience something different. | unbelievable bad combat system. not working for me, but ANY foe can just kill me instantly. unskipable cutscenes and more stuff that is annoying as Freck. 
dear devs. please dont try to reinvent the wheel. you managed to mess up enuff already

You play it, and then you forget about it.

If it was standalone game and not Gothic, it would be better, but still, it wouldn't be any special. It would just be there, in an ocean of many better rpg games.

In ArcaniA there is nothing to do other than main quest, because all the other quests are either "Go fetch me that item boy" or "Kill these beasts for me boy". But even main quest is all about doing this things. There's nothing interesting that happens along the way. You just kill and bring items to npc's.

The world is big, that's the only good part. And the cities actually look like cities, not like in Gothic 3 which was supposed to show us the entire Myrtana continent, but've we only seen a small villages and a castle that was supposed to be a capital of Myrtana, with no real port for ships lmao. So yeah, you can say it is an improvement in ArcaniA. BUT, we have all this areas to go to and to explore, but we don't have any access to quick travel! You have to go everywhere by foot! The only things you have are teleportation circles that you can travel from one to another, but if you ever used one, you know how bad they are. There are always two, linked with each other, instead of letting us to teleport to whichever teleport we want. It's freaking awful!

The combat system is an improvement from Gothic 3. But only for melee and ranged "classes". Mages actually lost SO many spells...

The visuals of the game aren't breath taking, not even amazing. They're just mid. Not bad. But the optimization of the game is just as bad as in Gothic 3, nothing new. Ohh, I nearly forgot. The models of characters look AWFUL! Not only it's copy paste with nearly every npc, but the women in this game look HIDEOUS! Even one from the main mission, that has the only unique look in the entire game, and with which our Hero is in love with!

The story can be summarized as "Just go and don't come back"
It's just stupid. Whenever it makes a bit of sense, it is shadowed by the overall stupidity. Don't have anything else to add. Oh, wait I have

FIGHT, NEED TO FIGHT! KILL! FIGHT! AAAAARGH MY HEAD! THE VOICES!

I desperately need a remaster of this game, the crashes and bugs make this unplayable at times. This game is definitely the best fallout but not the best game, the attention to detail of many small towns in the Mojave Desert is satisfying and the hundreds of things to do makes this very re-playable. But it is missing one thing, poker. | es horriblemente injugable todo esta mal, en el rendimiento es malo, se crasheea muy rapido y aveces no explica cosas
un 10/10 | This is in my opinion the best first person RPG ever made. Obsidian really knocked it out of the park with this one. The world of Fallout is one of my favorite to visit and this game has plenty to explore. Something to note is that much of this game is set in an open desert which I admit isn't super visually stimulating but there's plenty of unique spots to find within the desert and it makes finding towns and settlements that much more enjoyable but your mileage may vary. In terms of gameplay, this game does show its age in more ways than one, however I don't think this takes away from the game at all. Specifically the shooting in this game is a little janky and hard to get used to but personally I feel this adds to the experience because of V.A.T.S., the sort of auto aim mechanic in the game. Personally I don't have many issues aiming as I've gotten used to the game but for newcomers it can be a learning curve. In terms of the RPG aspect, this game passes with flying colors. You can customize your character a variety of ways and (especially without the DLC raising the level cap) it rewards you for doing multiple playthroughs by trying out different builds and perks. As for the story, there are multiple factions to engage with and the game gives you almost complete freedom on how you choose to deal with all of them. You can even reject them all and form your own path. The soundtrack is also phenominal from both the in-game radio and the overworld music. One minute you'll be listening to classic jazz and country tracks, the next you'll be listening to the creepy ambience as you explore a new cave or abandoned building. The voice acting also leaves little to be desired, with stellar performances all around for basically every character in the game. You will find that many characters sound quite similar, with voices like Liam O'brien and Yuri Lowenthal being used all over the game. This might detract from your immersion but personally I think they do an excellent job with all of their roles and make most of them sound unique. The main game of Fallout New Vegas is excellent in every way I could think of and delivers on everything I want from an RPG. That being said I found the DLCs to leave a little to be desired, especially Dead Money. A fair warning for new players, if you go into a DLC area (aside from the Lonesome Road) you will not be able to return to the main game until it is finished and all of these areas are very high level. The stories of these DLCs also continue and expand on much of the story of New Vegas's base game so I would advise to play them after finishing the game for the best experience. Dead money has a great story but is very flawed. If you did not level any melee abilities before going in, you will most likely have a hard time playing catch up because the guns found here are either not good or are hard to come by. It also has a mute character who uses sign language. Cool idea, horribly implemented. Honest Hearts is some more good old fashioned New Vegas to run around in and I personally found it very enjoyable and it expands well on the main story. Old World Blues is the wackiest of the bunch by far. Many new unique weapons to find and some great quality of life upgrades for your playthrough. I didn't really care for the story, the main characters will talk at you for literally almost 20 minutes straight with nothing interesting to say other than "funny" fart jokes to keep you entertained. Thankfully there is an option to skip all this dialogue which I have used to great use on my many playthroughs. Finally, The Lonesome Road is a great capstone for the game. Your mileage with the story in this one may vary, but the gameplay in this new area is fantastic with many new challenging enemies and awesome areas to explore. With that being said, I do not think the DLC is mandatory to play to enjoy New Vegas to it's fullest. I think the best part of the game is the main game and I often don't even go into the DLC unless I'm doing a full run. If you've been on the fence about trying this one, or even just want a good game to play, play it. It will be worth your time and money. 10/10 | The house always wins.

While the graphics didn't hold up well, that should't matter when playing a masterpiece like this.

The amount of choices and nuance is outstanding and it makes me wish Bethesda would more often let other companies have a go at IP's that they hold. 

Is it out of spite that obsidion created the best Fallout game to date that they no longer allow it? Who knows. 

But what you should know is that this is *the* fallout game to play. The courrior's style is as iconic as this game. | Um dos melhores jogos de mundo aberto de todos os tempos, mesmo anos apÃ³s seu lanÃ§amento continua incrivÃ©l.
cleaned_review: 'The Fallout' soundtrack is a definite must-have for fans of the genre.

Reviews:
After completing the fourth part of Dragon Age, I wanted to play the first part again. And God, how wonderful it is: strong characters, gorgeously written dialogues, an epic story, you just dissolve in all this. I had already forgotten that such games were once released and made.

You really get incredible pleasure from the dialogues compared to the fourth part. Dialogues here are like a separate art form, it is clear that the developers once worked hard. In general, this is not the only thing that can give you emotions, the game itself is very variable: this concerns both your backstory and your choice in certain actions, you are the creator of your story and what its outcome will be depends only on you.

Pros:
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” An epic story with saving the world, where you are the chosen one and your decisions will determine what the ending will be, as well as a number of other important events. The right to choose, as in RPG games, is not an empty phrase here as in the finale of Mass Effect 3; 
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” Well-written and interesting characters;
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” Dialogues and the variability of their choices give exquisite pleasure;
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” The ability to create a character and choose what your backstory will be;
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” Interesting character leveling system. I found it very interesting to fight and level up my character;
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” The atmosphere, music are top notch here;
â˜‘ï¸ğŸ” The ability to install mods.

And also many many other advantages, each of which is native and special for each person.

Even before the Steam version, I spent countless hours here, I spent many hours on certain events in the game, replayed this fantastic game many times. This game gave me so many pleasant and positive emotions that words are not enough to describe everything I feel about this game. I love the first part and consider this game the best from the BioWare studio. There was nothing better from them and perhaps there never will be. I would also add the first and second parts of Mass Effect as well as Jade Empire here. | ä¸æ•¢ç©é¾™è…¾2å’Œå®¡åˆ¤ï¼Œæ˜¯å› ä¸ºä¸æƒ³çœ‹åˆ°é‚£ä¸ªæœ‰æ—¶å¤©çœŸã€æœ‰æ—¶è…¹é»‘ï¼ŒèŠèµ·æ¼‚äº®é‹å­ä¼šè¹¦è¹¦è·³è·³ï¼Œè¡¨è¾¾æ„Ÿæƒ…å¦å¦è¡è¡çš„Lelianaå°±æ­¤èº«å±…å¹•åï¼Œæˆä¸ºä¸»è§’å›¢çš„å¼•è·¯äººï¼Œå…³é”®æ˜¯ä¸ç°å«å†æ— ç“œè‘›ã€‚ä¹Ÿè®¸ä¸–ç•Œè§‚å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç°å«æ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•ä¸èƒ½æœ‰ä¸ªå¥½ç»“å±€ï¼ˆä½œä¸ºç”·äººå½“å›½ç‹é™¤å¤–ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä¸å¯èƒ½é€‰ç”·ä¸»æ§å°±æ— è§†æ‰äº†ï¼‰ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•ä¸èƒ½ä¸çˆ±äººé•¿ç›¸å®å®ˆã€‚é‚£ä½æœ‰ç€ç«çº¢å¤´å‘çš„åŸæ¸¸è¯—äººå¸¸å¸¸å…¥æˆ‘æ¢¦é‡Œï¼Œæˆ‘æ— æ•°æ¬¡æƒ³è¦æ‰“å¼€DA2çš„æ‰‹éƒ½åœäº†ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œæˆ‘çš„DAOæ°¸è¿œåœåœ¨æ‰“å®Œè•¾è‰å®‰å¨œä¹‹æ­Œçš„é‚£ä¸ªä¸‹åˆã€‚å½“å¹´æˆ‘ç©è´¨é‡æ•ˆåº”æ—¶ä¹Ÿæœ‰è¿™æ ·çš„æ„Ÿæƒ…ï¼Œä½†æ¯•ç«Ÿä¸»è§’æ²¡æ¢ï¼Œä¸¤äººéƒ½æ´»ç€å°±èƒ½å†è§é¢ï¼Œå³ä½¿ä¸å†æ˜¯é˜Ÿå‹ã€‚å¯æ˜¯DAä¸ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæˆ‘æ— æ³•åœæ­¢å®³æ€•é‡åˆ°æ€§æƒ…å¤§å˜çš„Lelianaï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸æˆ‘æ‰“å¼€DA2çš„é‚£å¤©ï¼Œæ˜¯æˆ‘ç»ˆäºåœæ­¢çˆ±å¥¹çš„é‚£å¤©å§ã€‚ | è™½ç„¶ç”»é¢å’Œæ‰‹æ„Ÿè½åï¼Œä½†å‰§æƒ…å’Œæ¸¸ç©ä½“éªŒèƒœè¿‡ç°åœ¨å¾ˆå¤šå¤§ä½œã€‚ç©å®Œä»¥åæ„çŠ¹æœªå°½ï¼Œå¤§æ¦‚è¿˜å› ä¸ºæœ€åä¸»è§’å¸Œè…Šè‹±é›„èˆ¬çš„ä¸€å‰‘ï¼Œæ³¢æ¾œå£®é˜”çš„ä¸€ç”Ÿï¼Œæœªå°½ä¹‹è¯­ï¼Œé¢ æ²›æµç¦»ï¼Œä»æ­¤ä¸å¿…å†æ

è·¯è¿‡çš„è–›å§ï¼šåœ¨è¯´æˆ‘å—ï¼Ÿ | Dragon age: Origins, woah there's a game. If Skyrim is the guy in high-school all the girls wanted to date, but was really just average, and Fable was the nerdy awkward foreign exchange student all the juniors tried to bang, then where is dragon age? 

Dragon age is the 6' 8" monstrosity of a man that fingered your girlfriend on prom night. No one expects Dragon age origins. DA is the guy that looms in the background dark and mysterious, but after hitting the showers fresh off an intense PE class, DA walks through to his locker butt-ass naked, with his full 10.3" flaccid hog swinging freely.

That is to say, Dragon Age is bold. The game has mature subject matter dealing with death on massive scales, racism, class based societies, deception, grotesque body horror, and enough S.V.U. crime to keep Benson and Stabler employed for at least 3 lifetimes. Seriously, look at brood mothers and tell me DA didn't earn that mature rating. 

But dragon age is a complex character, just like Jack Reacher, Dragon age isn't just a brute. The game is extremely adept at exploring plot points in immersive and clever ways. Handles scenes that need finesse and understanding with expertise, and does a great job of both showing and telling the player about the world around them. But more than that, dialogue decisions and direct actions carry weight and will have repercussions later into the game. 

If you like well written and immersive RPG's that stick with you well past their run times then check out Dragon Age: Origins at your earliest convenience.

ENG:

Great RPG game, which it does not fit into the Dragon Age 1 / 2 video game series so I recommend this game, like myself!

FIN:

Loistava rpg peli, sille jolle ei sovi Dragon Age 1/2 videopeli sarja niin suosittelen tÃ¤tÃ¤ peliÃ¤, niin kuin itsellenikin! | Great game. Has elements of Dragon Age, KotR and this old school game I never got working called Lords of Midnight.

A unique and flavourful experience with plenty of room to adapt your style of play based on how you like to grind your meat in a beautiful RPG. 

Also, not OVERLY intensive graphically. Quality is still there without turning your PC into a second furnace that can heat your entire house / apartment. Plenty of intuitive built-in options to help you customize your performance visually and avoid any chopping or ugliness

Ambience is great, depth of detail is excellent, the lack of tool tips and the amount of things to be found if you look carefully creates a great "puzzle" element that rewards the attentive without punishing the impatient.

The overly critical may say that it borrows from some other game that they are sentimental to, but Div II definitely has a flavour all it's own.

At $20, an absolute steal of a game. Couldn't put it down once I got into it. | This game is about being a giant dick to everyone, all the time. Seriously I decided beforehand i was going to play this game as a white knight and I was still a total dick. Strangely enough the arch-nemesis is a really cool guy, I wish we could have hung out more.

Also at one point, you get attacked by the ginyu force...
they even do the pose.

9 Malachite Gems out of 10 | Un vero gioiello il gioco di ruolo di casa Larian. Divertente e vario, offre dialoghi brillanti e situazioni mai banali.  The Dragon Knight Saga comprende il gioco base Eco Draconis e l'espansione Flames of Vengeance. | This game caught me off guard. How little I knew that Divinity II: The Dragon Saga would be so unique, epic and beautiful all at the same time. It's one of my favourite RPG's of all time with it's absolutely charming atmosphere, delightful dialogue and interesting enviroments. There's nothing quite like it at the RPG market. A must try!

Reviews:
Divinity 2 is at the first glance a nice game. Deeper into the game, especially in the late game, things become quite monotonous. Also there are some riddles without any real hint as how to solve them. Storywise things don't really make sense later and the ending sucks in my opinion, it doesn't feel fulfilling. | Please make sure to install the Div2Patch from BlanknameES on Github, it addresses many of the games technical issues on modern systems (framerate, crashes, resolutions, keybindings, bugfixes, ...).

I played through the game with the included DLC in about 40 hours and overall it was a enjoyable experience, there's quite a lot of weird things going on in a playthrough, due to it's age and financially constrained development cycle. But if you enjoy to revisit older games, and deal with their shenanigans, then this might be something for you.

I would really love if they would build a worthy successor based on this amazing concept with their modern tech and creative freedoms <3 | One of the greats Great Dev Team at the time and great franchise. from game to game the Easter eggs and humor are consistent. | I had very low expectations from this game but it managed to surprise me a lot. It is a very good  action RPG, A good store and lore, the combat is fun the graphics are a bit old for 2024 but it's worth overlooking that. Very few minor bugs and to be honest I don't understand why some people complain about the ending...

Anyway I recommend this game to all action RPG fans especially if you are a divinity series fab | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ» Ğ² Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¼ĞºĞ°Ñ… Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€ Larian, Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ» ĞµÑ‘ Ğ² Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğµ. this has got to be the best half baked game ive ever played, the magic system is genius the story and voice acting is atrocious. if you wanna fuck around with magic and make people dead this is the game to play (just ignore the placeholder achievement system that never got finished) | This game really didn't age well. I'm cringe laughing through the intro. My guy looks like he is out on a jog. The combat has a back-hand slap in it. There is a lot of clumzy looking animations that make no sense and look entirely silly. The main character has a raspy batman voice. Acting is very rarely good. The intro was a series of examples of villains having the upper hand but then turning their heads away or leaving entirely to let themselves be killed or the protagonists to narrowly make an escape. You can't sprint in this game but you can speed up swimming so you go very fast. Very strange. 

The tutorial was long and arduous and tbh I just about finished it when I felt I had enough for my first sitting with this game. There is a hilarious amount of jank and weird movement that looks very unnatural. But this is a really old game so it's understandable. Can't leave a negative review when I spent most of the intro laughing, can I? | The best part of this game was playing the multiplayer maps. Wish I could've seen this game in its prime, actually low key really fun. IDK much about the story, couldn't keep my attention, but the multiplayer mode with my partner, really made this game something really special. The magic system is really good. Reviews:
Play poker with The Boysâ„¢ when your IRL boys are too busy or too nonexistent to fill that void. This game is like a nicotine strip for your gambling addiction â€” it gives you just the right amount of fix without needing to pawn your phone or drop 150â‚¬ on some online poker site in Malta. If youâ€™re tired of pretending you're not addicted to poker, this is the perfect way to scratch that itch while still being able to pay rent.

Youâ€™re sitting there, in an underground lair (or wherever this place is), playing poker.
Each character brings their own vibe, personality, and distinct set of cards (okay, not really, but you get it).

The real kicker is that this game exposes just how trash your poker skills are. You might think you're the king of Texas Hold'em, but once you see how those other guys bluff, youâ€™ll be questioning every poker move youâ€™ve made in your life. The AI is tough but fair, COLD AS ICE IF YOU ARE NOT ALERT

And hereâ€™s the beauty of it â€” unlike your friends who probably only show up when itâ€™s their turn to actually deal with your addictions, these digital companions will play with you, let you lose to them, and still crack jokes about it, making you feel like youâ€™re not just a lone sad piece of shit wasting away in your room. In fact, they might even make you want to play again, as you desperately try to reclaim some imaginary honor.

If youâ€™ve got a gambling problem, this is probably the closest you'll get to redemption without having to go to any actual meetings. 

All said and done, Poker Night at the Inventory is the perfect game to kill time while realizing that youâ€™re nowhere near as good at poker as you thought. But hey, who needs skill when youâ€™ve got The Boysâ„¢ to keep you company? | Fun old game, didn't even realized you can get TF2 free commenities once earned which is a plus! Know half the characters; early 2000s characters that I know only a little but fun. | A fun enough way to play poker. | one of those times when everything is as old as stone yet highly engaging | this game fucking rocks. it's a shame you can't buy it anymore.
cleaned_review: A fun enough way to play poker.

Reviews:
Osmos is a game that admittedly is somewhat special to me, in light that it was one of the items acquired for the still-deemed-to-be-almost-completely-insignificant 8th Grade Graduation event in 2010, yet also a completely baffling, confounding, fundamentally broken experience.

I haven't the foggiest of clues how literally [b]anyone[/b] could try to play through 2 of the three level branches in-game, and not only deem it a [b]finished product[/b] that's ready to send to market, but also charge $10 for it. Similarly, I very much want to know which game everybody that pushed its Metacritic Score up to [b]EIGHTY[/b] was playing, and/or how much of it was done so before passing judgement.

To delve into what's wrong with this slow, plodding, almost-entirely-unengaging disaster, I first need to have you, dear reader, imagine you're playing literally any game with a level (style of game doesn't matter), and end goal for said stage. 

Now imagine that instead of making sure you have even the [b]chance[/b] of [b]starting to play[/b] this level, you instead need to repeatedly pause and generate a new map to make sure the game bothers giving you collision to stand on, then literally anything else that's needed to clear said stage.

I would say â€œThis is at least two levels in Osmosâ€, however, this analogy is not over, because even if the game you're imagining gives you a starting piece of terrain, allows you to move within it, and grants you the equipment needed to have a chance at beating the stage, no guarantee exists the end goal was generated alongside it, 

This is to say that after spending sometimes up to 10 minutes trying to beat this stage, you can be at the second to last action needed to fulfil the objective, only to find the switch you needed to push, unit you needed to spawn, and/or edge of the platform you need to jump from to get to the goal is completely missing.

Guess what this means you need to do? Keep generating a new map until the basics are granted, then hope the game gave you a complete level that can finished this time around.

[b][u]This is to say that levels in Osmos are not designed, they're generated, and not only that, seemingly nothing by any flags, checks, or programs are in-place to make sure said stage can be completed was bothered to be programmed[/u][/b], making the gameplay loop â€œplay until you get stuck on a level, regenerate said level until you can even start to play it, and hope that the system blessed you with the apparently unheard-of privilege of being able to beat said stage.

I have gone back to this game at least twice since acquiring it almost 15 years ago, and each time, I reached a â€œlevelâ€ that's not only entirely reliant on RNG to be able to not only do anything at-all in, but seemingly completely unable to be finished.

The first revisit saw one of the â€œForceâ€ clusters be perpetually beyond even beginning, and while the A3B cluster seemed doable at first, after â€“ no joke â€“ at least 30 restarts, 1 hour and a half wasted, and only 15 that I wasn't completely blocked out of doing anything with, none of those were finished.

It gets worse, though, because in order to have a chance at defeating any enemy (in this case stationary blobs for most of the levels I bothered even trying to play) you â€“ so to speak â€“ need to take health from yourself, and give it to whichever adversary you may be facing. This already sounds completely unreasonable, but once you assimilate the â€œHealthâ€ of the other enemy, you grow to their size, unable to get through corridors, and use weaker ones to hope to try and beat the bigger ones, while hoping beyond hope nothing happens to give imperative health to your adversary, causing it to grow bigger, and completely block you off from progressing.

[b][u]The fundamental laws of game design state:[/u][/b]

1: If you must have a randomiser take the place of intentional design, include checks, and flags, then redundancy on redundancy to make sure every level can be completed via player agency, and skill, rather than the randomiser putting everything in.

2: Once these are in-place, make absolutely sure that everything it makes can be consistently completed, playing each level multiple times, and perhaps have multiple people also do so, to increase the amount of tested instances/generations.

3: Once everything is confirmed to be working [b][u]then[/u][/b] publish it.

As such, we reach the

[b][u]Verdict:[/u][/b] A seemingly-untested, unfinished-feeling frustration-fest that relies entirely on luck to allow the player to do anything, with two levels either taking hours of restarts to beat, or otherwise are completely impossible to finish.

[b][u]Placed In:[/u][/b] Were this acquired on any other occasion, I would have 0 qualms whatsoever about ousting it from my account such that I never have the temptation to be disappointed by it in the future again, but as it stands, it's shakily at 6: Traumatically Toxic, and â€œRemove it anyway.â€ | Klassiker
cleaned_review: Despite its uniqueness, Osmos is a sluggish, plodding, and utterly unconvincing experience.

Reviews:
An awful way to [strike]kill[/strike] end a franchise. 

Everything about this game is amateurish. It plays like a mediocre fan-made game, whose dev team never really understood what made F.E.A.R. good in the first place. It feels like they took any element they could from other games in the genre, to throw away the most generic and uninspired shooter you could defecate in 2011. 

This game has nothing interesting to offer in the franchise. Everything is a downgrade from the previous F.E.A.R. games. The overall gameplay and the level design are boring, the cutscenes are out of place and the plot is abyssal. There is no atmosphere, no soul, no smart horror moments in this game. It's an insult. | Is this a Call Of Duty game or what? Like seriously, wtf even is this? 
This is such an awful way to end a franchise and I haven't even finished this game because this game is so boring and has lost its identity | The [u]combat style[/u] is so engaging that experiencing it [u]with friends[/u] and cooperating to progress through the story and [u]challenges[/u] brings incredible feeling to your group every moment  

[b]Still[/b] worth playing... | I recommend using some kind of image sharpening for this game, you should be golden after that.

Don't really care what other F.E.A.R. fans say about this game. I've played through all of them now. What you have here is not a Monolith developed game, what you have is a Monolith infected game, yes somehow their DNA still made it in despite it not being made by them, couple that with John Carpenters artistic consultation and what you end up with is a masterpiece in its own right. The combat is outrageously tight and responsive, some of the finest you will ever experience. I really enjoy Paxtons grinning comments and interjections while playing through as The Point Man, it sounds raw gritty and feigns with great delight Monoliths classic tongue in cheek sense of humor and smarm. 

The cutscenes really tie in this game, giving it coherence and continuity. If you allow it in, it is a really immersive high speed freight train screaming to a smoldering hell. I love how the creative direction of this game just flat out didn't give a damn how sick it came off to the player base or viewership. It's unapologetic concerning that, which I find refreshing in today's gambit of garbage, gravy train riding, money grabbing, people pleasing, drop down to knees, and vacuum off some politically polite snowflake that demands you be a proper gentleman.

So what do I ultimately think about F.E.A.R 3? I think you catch the drift of my sentiments already. 

Being able to go back and play as Paxton is just the icing on the cake. The game's cover system is optional, I found myself only partially using it, ultimately it's there if you want to use it but is easily fully omitted. The sound design and music are top notch, although being  slightly glitchy on rare occasion. The sound department in this game just flat out owns and exerts its dominance compared to a lot of stuff out there.

Just finished Paxtons playthrough, was pretty cool. | no entiendo como podes hacer un juego tan bueno y recontra prometedor como FEAR 1 y decaer hasta esta cosa que es fear 3. Fear 2 apenas lo incias ya lo sentis como una version mucho mas estandar del FEAR 1, PERO para cuando lo terminas si se siente como algo parte de la saga FEAR. pero FEAR 3?? a mi me parecio un call of duty experimental malo con una paleta de colores mas oscura, me recuerda a los juegos de peliculas de accion que sacaban en la play 2. 

Como juego generico de accion esta "bien", como parte de una saga tan prometedora, poof, decadencia total, malisimo por donde lo mires, terror cero, atmosefera cero, accion una exageracion y ni siquiera algo interesante, coperativo forzado, entre mision y mision hay cinematicas malisimas que te transportan tres paises de distancia, eso a mi no me gusta. point man de repente tiene rostro y "persoanlidad", pero no tiene voz ni opinion y literalmente su unica "personalidad" es tener cara de ogt constantemente como si fuera un personaje de pelicula de accion vieja, (SPOILER:) te vuelan los pelos dos capitulos enteros de que tenes que buscar al protagonista del juego anterior, y no cumple NINGUNA FINALIDAD ESO, nada cero, lo vas a buscar para nada, y ENCIMA lo matas por ningun motivo, al protagonista del juego anterior. nono es muy malo y me da pereza explayarme mas en porque es tan malo, basicamente, todo el potencial que tiene esta saga, a la basura totalmente. nos quedamos con el primer juego y con ganas de que se transporte esa experiencia a algo moderno.

Reviews:
DO NOT BUY!!

This game should be de-listed from Steam. It will not work anymore. Compatibility mode, installing physx that came with the game, nothing will get this game working.

Unfortunate, because this was one of my guilty pleasure games. XD | Highly recommended. Get it on steam sale for only a couple of dollars. I have zero problems running it on windows 11 on geforce gpu. Multiplayer is generally dead but the single player campaign is one of my all time favorites. It's a bit short, maybe 6 hours, so play it on hard if you want to stretch it out. The plot of Red Dawn, mechanics like early CoD games, Unreal Engine 3. Just an awesome shooter. | Homefront is a unique and compelling first-person shooter that offers players an intense alternate history experience with a surprisingly well-crafted narrative. The game's strongest attribute is its powerful storytelling, presenting a dark and immersive vision of a North Korean invasion of the United States that feels both provocative and emotionally engaging. While the single-player campaign is notably shortâ€”around three hoursâ€”it packs an incredible amount of cinematic storytelling and atmospheric world-building into its brief runtime, with each level feeling like a meticulously crafted painting that captures the brutal reality of occupation.

The gameplay, though familiar, provides solid shooting mechanics and an interesting variety of weapons that become progressively more interesting as players advance through the campaign. Multiplayer stands out as particularly enjoyable, with a team-based scoring system that emphasizes collective performance over individual kill counts, creating a more collaborative and strategic online experience. The game's maps are well-designed, conveying a compelling sense of a crumbling, occupied America that feels both authentic and emotionally charged.

Despite some technical limitations and graphical shortcomings, Homefront manages to create a uniquely immersive shooter experience that goes beyond traditional military game narratives. Its willingness to explore darker themes of war and occupation, combined with its innovative storytelling approach, makes it a memorableâ€”if flawedâ€”entry in the first-person shooter genre. | Great game, kinda short but the story is good and the missions are great, even giving you different things to do every now and then.
Definitely recommend especially if its on a sale. | Ğ¾Ñ‡ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ñ ĞºÑ€ÑƒÑ‚Ñ‹Ğ¼ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼, Ñ€ÑƒÑÑ Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ²ÑƒÑ‡ĞºĞ°

I go home from my job working as an engineer to play a game where you work as engineer, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

Great gameplay, with an inspiring and motivating soundtrack to keep you trudging through real headscratching puzzles. The soundtrack itself is great to play while doing programming or very mentally intensive work.

The fishcake is yummy. | This has been an insane challenge but super fair, with minor exceptions*. If you like this sort of thing, this is EXACTLY the sort of thing you'll like.

Thank you, Zachtronics, for making such an amazing game. This is not a Sudoku or Sokoban where there is exactly one perfectly-logical solution to each puzzle. Instead, each player invents their own solutions -- and some can be more efficient than others, in multiple mutually-exclusive ways. As Zach Barth said in old interviews, SpaceChem is an example of "design-based games, which present you with a goal, perfect information, and a set of combinable tools to achieve it... they're essentially asking you to 'invent' a solution to a problem instead of merely 'finding' the solution." This kind of creative puzzle-solving is what I had imagined a STEM PhD program would be like (though it turns out PhDs are not really mostly about this; but that's a whole other story).

And... after a decade and a half, HOLY COW I finally beat it! Without hints**! I know many others have beat it before me, but it's still satisfying to know I've done something SpaceChem's designer Zach Barth has (according to old interviews) never done himself.

WOW has this ever been a long journey. These little molecules and waldos have accompanied me like a white whale through so many life stages. When SpaceChem came out in 2011, I started playing the game and enjoyed it a ton, but I got stuck and took a break. A few years later, I picked it up again as a distraction from grad school, but only reached the 4th or 5th world out of 9 -- before taking another (loooong) break. A decade later, after getting tenure, my treat to myself was to tackle SpaceChem seriously again... and now it's finally done -- with my kids staying up late to cheer as we beat the final boss.

Looking at the Steam-friends leaderboards, I'm also amused to see where my friends apparently quit playing. The quantum-physics PhD tunneled out in the 3rd world; the Twitch data scientist stopped streaming in the 5th; the software engineer and the IT manager suffered packet loss in the 6th. Somehow, I alone persevered to traverse the desolate worlds 7 through 9. Steam says I've spent 60ish hours on the game; I'd guess around 30 hours covered the first 6 worlds and the other 30 hours covered the last 3 worlds. Many of my solutions aren't optimized and beautiful (especially Don't Fear The Reaper; holy crap I made an ugly mess there) -- but they are mine, my own inventions, my hard-fought victories.

Once again, thank you to Zach and Zachtronics.

* The minor exceptions to fairness: (1) Every non-boss level tells you exactly how many molecules you need to make, but the boss-levels don't. It can be orders of magnitude harder to devise a solution that'll use up all molecules equally and produce an unending stream of hits, vs a good-enough solution that's unbalanced but just enough to beat the boss... yet you don't know how many hits each boss will take until you beat it. Most take around 3 hits -- but not all. (2) The game doesn't seem to allow multiple save slots for a level. If I try one solution and it doesn't QUITE work and I want to try another one, I have to get rid of my first solution and start the second... and if the second fails, I can't revert back to the first. I could take a screenshot of an initial solution, then remake it from scratch later if I need to, but aaargh! This is a small but extremely frustrating flaw in the game's interaction design. HOWEVER, I didn't realize until after beating the game that there's a dev-authorized "community edition" beta version which DOES allow multiple save slots per level. Look it up. Argh.

** "I beat it, without hints": Ok, technically, for the very last 2 boss levels I eventually looked up how many hits it takes to defeat each boss. See above -- I think this is unfair imperfect information. Besides, all the earlier bosses die after around 3 hits, but these two didn't die after 3... nor after 4... so I gave in and looked it up, because there's a big difference between "incrementally tweak my initial solution to stretch from 3 hits to 5 or 6 hits" vs "start again from scratch to allow for 10 or 20 or 40 hits." But I didn't look at anyone else's solutions, merely the number of hits required. | I'm wondering why I'm playing this game, is it any different than going to github and submitting a feature? | This is a game made for people with massive brains. | bu oyun
cleaned_review: I'm a fan of SpaceChem, and I'm a fan of the soundtrack.

Reviews: "God is dead, and we killed him" is often said in view of todays gaming landscape. I can confirm that such a statement is completely accurate, as no other game realeased in the past 20 years has ever come close to this masterpiece. Serving as a fundamental influence to the industry greatest minds, of the likes of Hidetaka Miyazaki, Todd Howard and Hannah Arendt, this game has been describred many times as the greatest achievement in human litereature since the Mahabharata was writen. I uninstaled my entire steam library since no other game could ever saciate my THIRST for greatness as this game would do everytime. I was converted. I wanted it. I NEEDED IT. And so do you. | very funny and wacky and hilarious | Straight gas | NO REASON, IT AMAZING

Reviews:
If you're reading this wondering if you should buy it, listen up.  Unless you see somewhere that they have completed the migration from Games for Windows Live (GFWL) do NOT get it. Due to GFWL not functioning for D3 currently, starting a new game (or if like me you migrated computers and needed a fresh install) means you can't save any progress - not even in the single player mode. :(

That said... I loved DiRT 2, and was very excited about getting DiRT 3. While D3 has its own charms, it's not quite as engrossing as I found D2, though it is extremely pretty and sounds great. If you were head over heels for D2, you'll at least have a close platonic relationship with D3.

TL;DR:  Good game, but not right now.

Edit: I did get D3 to save profiles after uninstalled GFWL, downloading a new client and manually re-installing it, as even using a local GFWL profile refused to work. I still don't recommend the game until Codemasters decides to bother properly updating it.

A few people bizarrely accused me of making up this issue, but simply going to the Community Hub for this game shows there are a LOT of people having this exact problem, and Codemasters have now taken over 6 months since announcing they'll update the game to fix this, but have not. | This is one of my all time favorite racing games. I play it on my simulator with 3 massive 46" displays and it never disappoints! It's also fun to play drunk off your ass :P

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYLkL3zBOmc | With a good Steering Wheel and Cockpit View this Game is nearly a very good Simulation. The graphics are awesome, especially with Dx11 and it runs incredible good and stable. Maybe they could've produced some tracks, which are longer than 3km, like 20km or 30km Tracks, that would be just brilliant!
In the end i would give the game 9/10 Points:
Graphics:               9/10
Steering:               9/10
Sound:                  10/10
Tracks:                  8/10 too short, but gorgeous designed!
Forced feedback: 10/10
cars:                      9/10
Physics:                 9/10
cockpit view:        9/10
 | I really wanted to like this game. REALLY!

Here's what made it impossible:

1. Integration with Windows Live
It's impossible to save your progress unless you have an account

2. Mirriad of online this and online that
The moment you start the game you have to go through choice after choice pop-ups. 
While you are doing that, the game talks to you using words like "awesome", "totally", "cool" and "I have a great feeling about this". None of this can be skipped, you HAVE to listen to it.

3. Boring
Apart from enhanced visuals, this game compared to DIRT2 is the same but without all the fun.

Wish I could have my money back. | WARNING - This is still dependant on GFWL which has been shut down by Microsoft. Therefore, you cannot save your progress in anyway as of this writing (and the past year by the sound of it). There is a way to create an offline profile but it too fails. Multiplayer needed GFWL and therefore is also gone. All you can do are single races with the handful of cars that are unlocked from the start. 

Do.Not.Buy.

UPDATE: After multiple attempts and making an Xbox account of all things, I now have a profile that works. I still cannot get any of the DLC cars from the LIVE store. Not even the free car pack. Which sucks because it has the 1995 STi in it. The whole GFWL thing is still a Byzantine maze of painful obfuscation and Codies really needs to address this.
cleaned_review: i'd give it 9/10

Reviews:
It's Dirt 3, which I consider to be Codemaster's rally masterpiece, but converted to Steamworks.

- includes all DLC
- free upgrade for existing Dirt 3 owners

                                                                                                                                                                                         å¿†é’æ˜¥ | I'll leave this as short and simple as I possibly can, because let's look at the facts. This is a five year/nearly six year old game. Yet, the graphics department is not lacking to this date as one may expect! Neither is the game play. Look at the current videos of high quality settings, or my screenshots. This game still looks and plays great! That in itself is rare and a testament to CodeMasters and their numerous years spent creating quality racing games (for the most part). In fact I find this racer to be more responsive and acceptable to true skill via setup and personal driving style than many of today's releases and that's not a sentiment I pass lightly! So, please do yourself a favor and consider purchasing this gem of a racing game.

For existing users it has been stated numerous times already that GWFL has been removed :) And that not only have the Codie's revisited this game, and revamped it so its player base weren't out of luck like so, so many other developers?!?! No! And not only that, but they included all of the DLC, and guess what?! Look hard fans of old, as there are some new easter eggs and improvements that you will only notice if you spent a lot of time playing the original. I had 100+ hours in the GFWL version before they made this title available in Steam. I would definitely reinstall this "new" version if you own the original. [b]I'd be highly surprised if you're disappointed in the decision but at the end of the day: [i]To each their own![/i][/b]

Reviews:
Portal 2 is one of the best puzzle games ever created. It combines logical thinking, physics-based mechanics, and an engaging story. The game takes place in Aperture Science, a mysterious and dangerous laboratory filled with test chambers. The player controls Chell, a silent protagonist who must escape using the Portal Gun. This device allows players to create two linked portals on surfaces, making it possible to teleport and solve puzzles.

One of the most impressive aspects of Portal 2 is its level design. Each test chamber introduces new mechanics, forcing players to think creatively. The game starts with simple puzzles but gradually becomes more complex. Elements like light bridges, propulsion gel, and lasers add depth to the challenges. The difficulty curve is perfect, making the game enjoyable for both beginners and experienced players.

Portal 2 also stands out with its story and humor. The main antagonist, GLaDOS, is a sarcastic and witty AI who constantly insults and manipulates the player. Wheatley, a clumsy and funny robot, adds another layer of comedy. Their dialogues make the game more entertaining and memorable. Despite its humor, the story also explores themes of control, identity, and artificial intelligence.

Another great feature of Portal 2 is its cooperative mode. Unlike the single-player campaign, co-op requires teamwork and communication. Players control two robots, Atlas and P-Body, solving puzzles that require coordination. This mode enhances the experience, making it even more enjoyable when played with a friend.

Overall, Portal

Not weaker or worse in any way, the sequel is just as perfect.
Definitely a MUST play for all gamers!

Portal 2 is a competent dexterity and logic puzzle platformer, undisputed best one out there.

The story is better, the lore deeper, the mechanics more expanded and level design is intelligent.
The multiplayer and custom content are the cherry on top, just as delicious!

One of the best games of all time, we will play it forever.
If I didn't currently need disk space, I'd keep it always installed.

EstÃ¡ bien, es un juego de ciencia ficciÃ³n sobre un barco que se hunde con una tÃ©cnica decentemente competente para un motor de fÃ­sica acuÃ¡tico:  el gran protagonista es el agua.

La aventura se desarrolla en un gran barco llamado" Reina del Mundo", pero es invadido por un grupo de terroristas llamados" Neo maltusianos" liderados por Mila. Estos quieren reducir la poblaciÃ³n matando personas sistemÃ¡ticamente y robar tecnologÃ­a para convertirlas en armas.
La ingeniera de sistema Kate Wilson se ve inmersa en la batalla por la supervivencia, pero finalmente decide descubrir el complot terrorista y salvar a los pasajeros de la nave mientras este se va hundiendo.

Mientras el ocÃ©ano se precipita alrededor, Kate deberÃ¡ lidiar con el flujo masivo de agua que nos dificultarÃ¡n o impedirÃ¡n directamente el avance. Kate hara uso de buenas habilidades acrobÃ¡ticas para escalar por superficies elevadas y acceder a zonas fuera de las indundaciones, resolver fÃ¡ciles acertijos y utilizar un dispositivo portÃ¡til para hackear cÃ³digos para abrir puertas o acceder a camaras de seguridad, ademÃ¡s harÃ¡ uso de una mediocre arma de fuego con diferentes tipos de municiÃ³n y al final con unÂ poder para provocar grandes olas que desestabilicen a los enemigos

Veamos "hidrofobia" entendÃ­ por el tÃ­tulo que la protagonista presenta un miedo irracional al agua, bien, esto se manifiesta en el juego cuando Kate estÃ¡ sumergida en el agua con la inquietante voz de ella cuando era una niÃ±a, estos sonidos se presentan solo en los momentos tensos, pero nada mÃ¡s, luego en el resto de la aventura parece estar muy cÃ³moda atravesando las inundaciones...

El juego es divertido de jugar, cuenta con 42 desafÃ­os y 72 coleccionables, ademÃ¡s de 13 logros Steam para desbloquear.
Dejando de lado la ingeniosa fÃ­sica del agua, te recordarÃ¡ un poco a juegos como Tomb Raider, pero con tiroteos pobres, un poco lineal, muy corto de duraciÃ³n y malas secciones de acertijos, ademÃ¡s posee un modo desafÃ­o que consiste en resistir durante 5 rondas contra grupos de terroristas.
Recomiendo agarrarlo en alguna oferta de Steam | If you can find this on a deep sale, the gameplay is clunky but fun. I really enjoyed how much of a factor water physics played in this game. | An interesting game.
Built, and hyped, purely on its water physics engine Hydrophobia is an action adventure a la Tomb Raider or Uncharted although on a much smaller scale.
This is and always will be, the first episode of a planned trilogy.
Which is why the game ends abruptly on a cliffhanger.

The graphics are actually pretty decent for such an old game and definitely portrays the almost hard sci-fi I feel they were going for quite well. The environments have that clean sci-fi look that production designers like to think the future will be like.
The 'star' of the game is obviously the water, which again for the time is very impressive.
Actually, although many games since have included some type of water physics I don't know if any of them improved on this particular type. A lot of games have neat effects like the Spintires series and such, but Hydrophobia has water flowing from rooms with more water in them to rooms with less through doors and windows which I think is very different from the smaller scale water physics whereby it only interacts with objects. 
It reminds me a bit of the physics in pixel games like Clonk and Noita.
The water is fairly gelatinous though.

Sorry I went on a bit of a tangent there.
The audio is good enough.
Guns sound a bit weak and there isn't a lot of music, but it's all serviceable.
The voice acting except for the protagonist is also acceptable IMO.

The core gameplay is not bad, but the jank of the controls makes it a bit annoying at times.
Sometimes your character won't jump, or grab onto a ledge and the 'super power' system is terrible.
Which is a minor issue since you only get your power in the last five minutes of the game, but it does make the boss fight more frustrating than it needed to be.
The basic gameplay loop consists of running/swimming/climbing around until you get to a locked door, find the two parts of the key and go to the next section to repeat everything. With the occasional simple cover shooter combat inbetween.

Would I recommend it?
It's often on sale for less than 50 cents and for that price, it's certainly an interesting forgotten game.
And well, I still wouldn't recommend it really but it'll keep you busy and mildly entertained for a few hours.
If Steam had an actual rating system I'd say it's a 6.5/10 or 3/5.
cleaned_review: This is a fun game of ficcion about a boat that is hailed with a decent technique for a water motor: the great protagonista is water. The adventure is develop in a big barco called"Reine del Mundo", but it is invaded by a group of terrorists called "Neo Maltusianos" led by Mila. These want to reduce the population mating people and steal technology to convert them into weapons. The system engineer Kate Wilson sees in the battle for survival, but ultimately decides to uncover the terrorist plot and save the passengers from the ship while this is going down. Kate will use good acrobatic skills to climb over steep surfaces and access areas outside the inundations, resolve easy issues and use a portable device to hack code to open doors or access security cameras, Kate will also use a mediocre fire arm with different types of ammunition and ultimately with power to cause big olas that destabilize enemies.

â˜ 1 | A deceptively simple and graphically minimal game with chill electronic music, Vertex Dispenser is both fun and challenging - offering one part problem solving and one part competitive strategy. We greatly enjoyed the multiplayer vs. A.I. more than anything, though.

The main shortcoming is the extreme minimalism.  The game could do with a bit of polish in its UI and graphics.  Simple doesn't have to mean sloppy. Nevertheless, one of my favorites in the genre since the first Hexxagon. | This Game is a must-have! Dont get disturbed by the graphics, it is very very fun and you really have to use your brain if you wanna be good at this. | This game is pretty weird. It's also a lot of fun. It's fast paced. It's action. It's strategy. It's a puzzle game. And that's really all the words I have that I can use to describe this thing. 

I suggest checking out the demo, especially if you are tired of 9 out of 10 indie strategy games being Tower Defense. | One of very few games in the CRTS genre, its depth and complexity stem from mechanics reminiscent of a falling block puzzle game.  It's up there among my absolute favorite games, I just wish it was more well-known.
cleaned_review: Vertex Dispenser is a simple, graphically simple game that offers a unique challenge and a unique gameplay.

Reviews:
I've played over 1000 hours of this game. I've seen it from it's conception to it's end. 
The community of this game is unlike any other I've ever encountered in an online group. They are vindictive, rude and destructive to the game. Throughout the entire time I played I suffered no end of trolling, mocking and the like. There were people that literally exploited the kicking function to get me off of servers so I could not play the game I paid for. 
The issue also lies with the developers whom constantly ignored community begging to get hackers out. Even to this day, after an anti-cheat patch, the game is STILL cracked, people running around with weapons they shouldn't, running fast, swinging faster than is possible. Some people even exploit the bad latency issues to win. 

There's a top 1% in this game, they are not skilled players by any stretch. Instead of skill they got together and figured out what the best ways to exploit the games mechanics. From unblockable hits to builds that were simply insanely unfair, they scared away any new players to the game by trying their best to ruin the fun for others. To this day, even now, I get on and someone is taking my Steam ID name so they can spam vote kicks so I can't play. 

Stay far, far away from this game. Think of World of Warcraft only cultivated with the worst of the worst (community) possible. The truth is I enjoyed this game but the playerbase was hellbent on seeing it go under. You have honest, fun people who are endlessly frustrated by the trolls, hackers and exploiters. 

There is no welcome mat here, just a gigantic letdown. | ĞŸĞ¾ĞºÑƒĞ¿ĞºĞ° Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ»Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ¾Ğ±ĞµÑ‰Ğ°ÑÑ‰ĞµĞ¹, Ğ¸ Ğ² Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»Ğµ Ñ Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ĞµĞ½. Ğ’ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑƒÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²ÑƒÑÑ‚ ÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‡ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ñ‹ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Malakhur, Shoers, *T!gRa, Doomer Ğ¸ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ³Ğ¸Ñ…. | At its peak, this was one of my favorite games of all time, the combat mechanics were deep and had a steep learning curve, the armor system was very complex and logical, and above all this game rewarded the skill of the players. 

Of the 140 hours I've played, roughly 100 of them were spent on dueling servers fighting 1on1 with other players, all of whom were there because they enjoyed the actual competition or to master their skills with a new weapon. The dueling community was strong and friendly, always willing to help teach new players how to survive the game. 

But then the Devs changed things, the armor system simplified, the weapons became more powerful, crossbows became sniper rifles, hitboxes and crit chances grew, and the art of dueling was lost to the ether; replaced by polearm decapitations, across the map crossbow headshots, and stab spamming. All that is left now is the empty rotting shell of a once great game. | This game has an absolutely TERRIBLE community. It's absolutely toxic and leaves to room for enjoyment. This game is fun, but there is nothing but people you never want to meet in person. 

It's disgusting. Sadly, it ruins the game entirely. Duel servers are the worst hands down, filled with people who are both hypocritical, and completely immature.

I'd skip this one for the community alone. | Als das Spiel noch einen normalen Preis hatte war es sehr gut.

Reviews:
Absolutely wonderful.
Lovingly written story with deep lore.
Rendered beautifully in the game engine.
Really appealing to look at.
Fantastic sound design.
Okay that's enough about Keira Stokes.

As for the game itself? I mean its alright i guess, previous game had a much better atmosphere and horror factor, only thing this game has up on the first is the graphics which have been improved by a LOT. I would say its worth a buy if on sale or in a bundle with the whole trilogy. | This game has nothing on the original. Everything that made the original so enjoyable is sadly lacking in this sequel. The guns suck because they lack power, the slow motion is boring compared to the original, and you can no longer lean around corners. Overall, this game feels like a downgraded cod campaign with horror themes - a real shame because the original (despite being 20 years old) is one of the most enjoyable fps campaigns I've ever played. | it's alright, i prefer a lot of the mechanics and visuals from the original, although you CAN drive the powered armor, so it lowkey peak and the mini DLC is also pretty fun | It's a generic shooter, albeit well-done, but it fails to recapture what made F.E.A.R. so great: its atmosphere. The level design is diverse and much more memorable (I'm thinking about the school especially), but it's a step backward in the horror section and the enemy AI. It's still fun, but it's not as good as it should be. 

Technically, it really feels like you're playing a PC game whose sequel was designed for consoles first, and then, has been ported to PC with fewer features than its original game had. You can't even quick-save, the save system is based around checkpoints. There's no FOV slider, you'll have to change that manually. Reviews:
A really good traditional roguelike(if you wish to play on permadeath) got me into roguelikes back in the day. It is still an amazing game, runs can last 7-8 hours assuming you get to the Dredmor level which is level 10. If for some reason you think thats too much, you can always tick an option to shorten the levels and gain more exp. 

Unfortunately the dev team disbanded and went bankrupt after the failure that was [i] Clockwork Empires [/i] , but it is still a timeless classic with workshop mod support and great expansion packs. The game is full of references to other games from its music to it's memes to your own character's portrait being it a doom reference.

The game also had 3 expansion packs (1 free) that heavily increased the replayability of the game tremendously.
My only real criticism of this game is that it's [b]not really made with controllers in mind[/b], so it's a hard game to recommend if you own a [b] steam deck [/b] or wanna play laid back.

Overall i give this a 9/10 , if you want to play a traditional roguelike that doesn't look like [i]unreadable ASCII gibberish[/i], this is one of the best games to introduce yourself to the roots of the [b]Traditional Roguelike Genre[/b].
 | this game scratches some kind of itch. I just wish it were easier to play on steam deck | Still playing Dredmor in 2025 | Still waiting for a sequel. | hard
cleaned_review: This is a classic roguelike that is hard to beat.

Reviews:
This is a VERY short old-school styled RPG, taking around 5 hours to beat (or 6-7 if you want to tackle the optional boss and do the necessary level grinding). It's more so a parody and homage to the beginning games of Breath of Fire, Dragon Quest, Final Fantasy, so the writing and story is not really anything special or captivating.

That being said, it is still a very fun game, with some unique mechanics that I think serve the game very well. For Random battles, each area only has a certain amount of random battles before they atop appearing, however if you need to grind gold or experience, you can always choose the "FIGHT" option from the menu even after your allotted random battles are used up. In addition, after each turn the enemies will get 10% stronger so you do have a pseudo time limit to finish battles quickly, but to make up for this, your HP is fully restored after each fight. This mechanic of making enemies stronger after each turn means boss fights become challenging as you need to kill them before their attacks just starting wiping your party.

Each party member only has about 5 pieces of equipment they can get in the game, all straight upgrades from each other, so you don't need to worry too much about min-maxing equipment, just play and enjoy.

I would say it is worth the $3 bundle along with Cthulhu Saves the World. It will provide a nice palate cleanser from all the 100+ hour games I know you have been playing. Do note that there is a Remastered version called "Breath of Death VII: The Beginning - Reanimated" which actually has Steam Achievements and has received an upgraded art style from 8-bit to 16-bit. If you enjoyed this game, you should get that one too. | There are criticisms to be made here, sure. But there are enough interesting bits to keep you going for the short time it takes to beat. The crux comes down to: Can you get $3 worth of entertainment out of this game and the other one that comes bundled with it? Absolutely. Battle mechanics are interesting. The character build system is interesting. Some of the equipment choices are meaningful (For example, I kept the shotgun equipped the whole way up to just before the end boss). The humor is kind of hit or miss but there are enough hits to make it worth while. Plenty of references if that's your sort of thing.
cleaned_review: a bit stale, but it's fun.

My first encounter with an indie game started with this game back when I played it on the Wii as a kid. As young as I was, nostalgia is liable to tint one's own view on the game years later, however, I only ever played the demo. Coming back to And Yet it Moves years later, with the typical cynicism many of us in our 20's begin developing towards games, I'm happy to say the full-version of this game was pretty enjoyable!

Being new to PC gaming and Steam sales, I'm beginning to develop taste for ultra short campaigns with densely packed novelty, fun, excitement, or whatever I can shake out of a $3 game. This game delivers a unique take on physics-based puzzles and I think the 3-hour campaign will convince most of you of that! | un juego que me trajo de vuelta al momento donde probÃ© la demo de la wii. la banda sonora y el estilo del juego es increible. pura nostalgia
cleaned_review: a game that I played back when I played the demo of the Wii as a kid. the banda sonora and the style of the game is incredible. pure nostalgia

Honestly, it's my favourite game in the zombie genre. It is a very cool concept that sadly is not used more often and that is actually managing evacuation efforts and fighting zombies from a government/military point of view. The mechanics of the game are pretty simple but allow for much replayability especially if you use mods such as Ground War. Mechanics are also great for getting into the mindset of so many military officials in the movies and games that simply carpet-bomb the entire parts of the city to get rid of the zombies since you will likely do something similar or be tempted to do it when things start going down. All in all great game that is worth the price | Charming little indie game and one of my first games on steam. | One of the most underated fast paced strategy zombie games of all time | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°

this game generally looks much harder than it actually is, except for the "doing it the hard way" section which did take about 30 mins to beat, i didn't end up being frustrated with the game as brute forcing through problems is usually sufficient to solving them,

exploring the map is quite fun and returning to an area is simple so its best to simply enter all the holes you can find

and the music here is also amazing, making the journey a banger all the way through
its quite cheap and well worth the price for the playtime you get, and somehow it still gets occasional updates | well i dont recommend it
the control is too slippery so it actually made the game really hard
as a precision platformer it should focus more level design using clever traps to increase the difficulty rather than through antihuman controls | It's like a modern atari, and i mean that in a good way. It's very simple to learn and I had a blast playing it, plenty of side content too post main game. Reviews:
Limbo is a timeless indie masterpiece that redefined the puzzle-platformer genre with its minimalist yet deeply atmospheric approach. Developed by Playdead, the game immerses players in a haunting monochromatic world filled with mystery and danger.

The striking black-and-white visuals, combined with a chillingly minimalist sound design, create an eerie and unsettling atmosphere that grips you from start to finish. The puzzles are clever, intuitive, and seamlessly tied to the environment, offering just the right balance of challenge and satisfaction.

What makes Limbo stand out is its ability to tell a profound, thought-provoking story without a single word of dialogue. Its themes of survival, loss, and exploration resonate deeply, making it more than just a game, it's an experience.

For fans of atmospheric and emotionally driven games, Limbo is an absolute must-play. i really want this game to succeed. its a fun combination of RTS and FPS that is extremely rare to find. there are, however, two problems that make this not recommended.

first and foremost, dead game. has been dead for a while, and games like this tend to need players to unlock its best gameplay.

but the most important thing that holds this back is the bots. i've played countless RTS games against AI and the likes. there are plenty of RTS games where there also is little to no players, but i enjoy them because i can still play a typical game against an AI opponent. in this game, there is no RTS commander, and therefore basically no reason to play because almost everything this game is relies on that.

RIP to a real one | Nuclear Dawn 2?
