Game Name: Sam & Max 103: The Mole, the Mob and the Meatball
Reviews:
[h1]Ryan George Style Pitch Meeting (with Mafia Guest Stars)[/h1]

Publisher: So, you have a wild mafia-themed point-and-click adventure game for me?

Game Designer: Yes, sir, I do! It's called Sam & Max: The Mole, the Mob, and the Meatball. Sam and Max, the freelance police, get caught up in a ridiculous mafia plot, trying to find a mole while dealing with a missing meatball sandwich. But oh, itâ€™s much bigger than that. They end up infiltrating the Toy Mafia, causing chaos everywhere they go!

Publisher: A meatball sandwich is the focus of this mafia plot?

Game Designer: Oh, absolutely. Itâ€™s the most important thing in the whole episode! Someone stole the famous sandwich from the casino, and Sam and Max need to track it downâ€”or else.

Publisher: Right. So, thereâ€™s a missing sandwich, and that somehow involves the mafia?

Game Designer: You bet! But thereâ€™s also so much more going on. Sam and Max are trying to track down this mole in the Toy Mafia by doing jobs for them. Like, killing Sybil, faking her death, and getting hypnotic bears into Boscoâ€™s store. Butâ€”plot twistâ€”they also have to track down this sandwich, and it's critical to the whole mission.

Publisher: Right, right. So thereâ€™s a sandwich, a mafia, and a couple of freelancing cartoon cops?

Game Designer: Exactly! And lots of crazy characters! You got Bosco, whoâ€™s paranoid about the Toy Mafia, and Leonard Steakcharmer, a casino cheater whoâ€™s cheating his way to 10 million casino tokens. Oh, and thereâ€™s a spy tool called â€œThe Bugâ€ that they use to eavesdrop on people.

Publisher: The Bug? How does that work?

Game Designer: Oh, you know, itâ€™s just a device that records conversations and then replays them. Itâ€™s like a gadget out of a spy movie, but with a lot more cartoon nonsense.

Publisher: Okay, okay, Iâ€™m following. And these jobs for the mafia... What are they?

Game Designer: Well, they need to take out Sybilâ€”but itâ€™s not what you thinkâ€”they fake her death using ketchup. And then thereâ€™s the whole situation with the hypnotic bears. They need to deliver them to Boscoâ€™s store. The mafiaâ€™s a mess, and Sam and Max have to play both sides to survive!

Publisher: Hypnotic bears? Faking deaths with ketchup? Iâ€™m not sure this is what I imagined when you said â€œmafia game.â€

Game Designer: Oh, but it works! The comedy is so over-the-top. Sam and Max donâ€™t know what theyâ€™re doing half the time, which just makes everything funnier. Theyâ€™re the worst mafia henchmen, but they somehow still get the job doneâ€”barely.

Publisher: Okay, but how do they infiltrate the mafia?

Game Designer: Easy! They get into the mafia by doing jobs for them. Theyâ€™re hired as assassins, then take on some ridiculous missions. And then, surprise, they get inducted into the mafia by completing all the tasks. But itâ€™s not easyâ€”no one trusts them. And then thereâ€™s the mole! The moleâ€™s working for the mafia!

Publisher: The mole?

Game Designer: Yeah, Ted E. Bear! But guess what? Heâ€™s actually a mole-man! The twist is that he was sent by the police to infiltrate the mafia, but instead, he becomes the mafia boss.

Publisher: So the mole infiltrates the mafia, becomes the mafia boss, and then tries to hypnotize Sam and Max?

Game Designer: Exactly! And theyâ€™re immune to his hypnosis, but they fake Maxâ€™s death to trick him anyway. Classic Sam & Max!

Publisher: Alright, thatâ€™s wild. But what happens at the end?

Game Designer: Oh, itâ€™s huge! They defeat Ted E. Bear, blow up the toy factory, and finally get the moleâ€”but the meatball sandwich is still gone. Itâ€™s a real cliffhanger.

Publisher: Wait, wait. You never find the meatball sandwich?

Game Designer: Nope! Itâ€™s a running mystery. Sam and Max just leave it as this unresolved joke.

Publisher: Oh, I like that. But listen, I gotta ask: Is there anything else I should know about the game? Anything extra?

Game Designer: Well, yeah! Thereâ€™s the Toy Mafiaâ€™s headquarters, a giant toy factory, and some absolutely absurd interactions. Oh, and Sam and Max might blow up the toy factory by the end of it! Itâ€™s like... itâ€™s like if you took a mafia film, added in cartoons, a sandwich, and, like, a lot of chaos.

Publisher: Okay, Iâ€™m in. Itâ€™s ridiculous enough to work. So, whatâ€™s next?

Game Designer: Well, Iâ€™m thinking merchandising, right? We make the meatball sandwich a real item. I mean, who wouldnâ€™t want that?!

Publisher: Youâ€™re right. Iâ€™m sold.

[Suddenly, the door bursts open, and Tony Soprano, Fat Tony, and Don Corleone enter.]

Tony Soprano: Hey, whatâ€™s all this about a meatball sandwich?

Fat Tony: Iâ€™m listeninâ€™... and I gotta say, I like what youâ€™re doinâ€™. But we gotta talk about this whole mafia thing. You got the right people here, you know?

Don Corleone: You want to make them an offer they canâ€™t refuse, eh?

Game Designer: Uh, what are you doing here?!

Publisher: Oh no, not this again.

Tony Soprano: Youâ€™re gonna need some muscle for that meatball sandwich, huh? We can help with that.

Fat Tony: Yeah, we got people who handle sandwiches. People who donâ€™t just let them go missing.

Don Corleone: Iâ€™ll make them an offer... a sandwich offer. They wonâ€™t be able to refuse.

Publisher: Guys, this is a game pitch, not a mob deal!

Game Designer: Yeah! Iâ€™m just trying to get the game greenlit here!

Tony Soprano: Listen, listen. Weâ€™re here to talk sandwiches and business. You need our help, capisce?

Fat Tony: Maybe throw in a little meatball connection, and we can talk. Business is business, after all.

Don Corleone: You should have come to us sooner, but weâ€™ll take care of it.

Publisher: Oh, for the love of... Fine, fine! Letâ€™s just make this work!
cleaned_review: The Bug is a spy tool that records conversations and replays them.

Game Name: Sam & Max 104: Abe Lincoln Must Die!
Reviews:
Very fun and funny game. It's kinda dated but in a really charming way, so it holds up. All around great game! | What would you do if you'd receive an assignment where you'd have to deal directly with the President of the United States of America? First of all, thank the Lord that this is only a game, so you may at least get a chance. And while you're at it, you'd might as well enjoy this opportunity as much as you can

Without the intention of getting into many details, Max will have to run as a candidate for President against Abraham Lincoln. You never know what to expect from the side characters, even though you already know that it's going to be something unusual. This time, Sybil decided to start a career as a dating service consultant and Bosco is disguised as a Russian, and keeps ramping out his prices through the roof and beyond. The Soda Poppers are now for whatever reason the governors of Dakota and want to find a solution to settle down their differences

The humor on this one isn't all over the place, even though there're some clever jokes that I thought that were really funny. As for the puzzles, I thought that some of them were a bit cryptic and I nearly decided to check on a walkthrough to see what I was supposed to do, but luckily I've managed to figure out what I had to do

Overall, the episode keeps getting as crazy as possible and I can't wait to see how's the next one going to be | LÃ©gÃ¨rement plus subtil, il faudra faire plusieurs aller-retours entre les zones pour en arriver Ã  bout. J'ai un peu tournÃ© en rond avant de trouver certaines choses. | Sam & Max follows a formula, sure, but sitcom predictability is proving to be this series' secret strength -- it's rare to see a game conjure up such strong narrative continuity and familiarity in such short a time span. In Telltale's hands, recycled assets take on the aspect of recurring joys. | 1. ĞŸÑ€Ğ¾ÑĞ½ÑƒÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ

Reviews:
[h1]Mr. T's "Reali-T" Review of Reality 2.0[/h1]

[Scene: Mr. T is sitting in his signature gold chains, his muscular arms crossed, in a chair that looks way too small for him. He looks straight at the camera. The camera zooms in on his serious face.]

Mr. T:
Ainâ€™t no time for no games, fool! But you know what? I got somethinâ€™ that I gotta talk about. Reality 2.0. Yeah, thatâ€™s right, Iâ€™m gonna break it down for you, â€˜cause when it comes to reality, thereâ€™s only one real "Reali-T" â€” and thatâ€™s me! Mr. T. So buckle up, Iâ€™m about to give you a reality check, you hear me?

[The camera switches to a close-up of Mr. T holding up the Reality 2.0 game box. He squints at it like itâ€™s the most confusing thing heâ€™s ever seen.]

Mr. T:
Now, I ainâ€™t no expert in these newfangled video games, but Iâ€™m about to check this out. You think you can mess with me? Well, guess what? This ainâ€™t no virtual world. This is Reali-T, baby! So you better believe Iâ€™m gonna break this down, real loud and real clear, just like my chains when I walk. Let's go.

[Cut to the Reality 2.0 main menu screen. Mr. T is staring at it intently.]

Mr. T:
Wait a minute, hold up. This some kind of crazy sci-fi mess? They got me flying through space, and now I'm in some weird "Reality 2.0" world? Iâ€™m the star, fool! I should be the one running the show, not some funky VR goggles. You think you can hypnotize me with your little virtual world? Ha! Ain't gonna happen.

[On the screen, Sybil is seen in the game, getting hypnotized by the goggles. Mr. T's eyes narrow.]

Mr. T:
Look at this, man. Sybil's all up in this mess, getting hypnotized by them goggles. Fool, thatâ€™s what happens when you mess with a fake reality. You need some Reali-T like Mr. T! I donâ€™t get hypnotized. I break chains, I break hearts, and I break games, baby. Thatâ€™s how I roll.

[The camera cuts to a shot of Mr. T shaking his head as he continues playing. Sybil explains the premise of Reality 2.0, which draws Mr. T into the game.]

Mr. T:
Okay, okay, now Iâ€™m in. But listen to me, when I step into a game, I bring the Reali-T! This whole â€œReality 2.0â€ thing? Itâ€™s cute. They got these little pop-up ads and some holograms, and everybodyâ€™s all like â€œOh, wow, itâ€™s so real!â€ Well, lemme tell you, if I wanted some real chaos, Iâ€™d just go out there and deal with real clowns. Not this digital nonsense.

[Mr. Tâ€™s character moves around the Reality 2.0 world, interacting with NPCs.]

Mr. T:
Hey, look at this. Iâ€™m talking to some goofy, holographic NPC. Man, I donâ€™t need no virtual friends. I got the real deal. You hear me? I got Reali-T. Iâ€™m talking about real friends, real fights, and real gold chains, fool.

[He navigates the dialogue options in the game, which leads him to visit Bosco in the virtual world.]

Mr. T:
Oh, snap. Boscoâ€™s in here? You know Bosco donâ€™t know nothinâ€™ about Reali-T. Look at him, sellin' me a billion-dollar snot rag. Whatâ€™s this, Bosco? A virtual germ? Fool, I donâ€™t need a virtual disease. I got Reali-T and the only thing Iâ€™m catchinâ€™ is victory!

[Bosco hands over a handkerchief to Mr. Tâ€™s character in exchange for a ridiculous amount of virtual money.]

Mr. T:
You see this, fool? Boscoâ€™s got this germâ€¦ and I gotta pay a billion dollars for it? Man, back in the day, Iâ€™d punch out a germ and still have enough for a gold chain.

[Mr. T takes a deep breath, staring at the screen like itâ€™s the most ridiculous thing heâ€™s ever seen.]

Mr. T:
You know, I gotta admit, this whole virtual world thing is getting on my nerves. You got people all hooked into these Reality 2.0 goggles like theyâ€™re a new kind of drug. You think you can trap Mr. T in a virtual world? You canâ€™t even trap my real self in a phone booth, fool. This is reality, baby!

[The camera cuts to a segment where Mr. T is preparing to fight the main villain, "The Internet."]

Mr. T:
Alright, alright, now we got ourselves a real challenge. Iâ€™m about to fight The Internet? Oh, you think you can mess with me, The Internet? Iâ€™ve got 15 years of catching up on shows I donâ€™t watch, Iâ€™ve got ten email accounts with nothing but spam, and Iâ€™ve got enough cat memes to break the World Wide Web! You wanna bring some â€œvirtualâ€ apocalypse? Iâ€™ll show you what happens when Mr. T goes full throttle, baby.

[The camera zooms in on Mr. Tâ€™s face as he clenches his fist.]

Mr. T:
Fool, you canâ€™t defeat me. You think you can lock me in some digital space? Nah. I got the key to the real world. Let me tell you something. I am the only thing in here thatâ€™s real, and when I hit you with this handkerchief full of germs, youâ€™re going down harder than my gold chains when I take â€˜em off at the end of the day.

[The Internet, personified as a woman, starts monologuing, but Mr. T interrupts.]

Mr. T:
Ainâ€™t nobody got time for your speeches, girl. This ainâ€™t a TED Talk. This is Mr. Tâ€™s reality, and youâ€™re about to get takedown-ed like a bad dial-up connection in 1998.

[As the battle intensifies, Shakespeare suddenly appears in the game world, holding a quill and scroll, appearing in front of Mr. Tâ€™s character.]

Shakespeare:
Hark! What light through yonder game breaks? It is the fool, and I do declareâ€”

Mr. T:
Wait, waitâ€”did you just say "fool"? Who you callin' a fool, Shakespeare? You donâ€™t want none of this, you got yourself a quill and some poetry, but Iâ€™ve got chains and a bad attitude!

Shakespeare:
Nay, I call thee fool not as an insult, but as a reflection of thine ignorance to the way of games and virtual worlds!

Mr. T:
You know what? I pity the fool who thinks they can outwit me in a game, and itâ€™s lookinâ€™ like youâ€™re that fool!

Shakespeare:
I pity thy fool! Forsooth, thy game is but a shadow! The only Reali-T that shall endure is the one that hath substance in the heart, not in pixels.

Mr. T:
Oh, snap! You got that right, fool. Itâ€™s all about the heart. And my heart? Well, it beats for Reali-T, and that means keeping it real. No more virtual nonsense.

[The game continues, but Mr. T now delivers a dramatic finishing blow to "The Internet."]

Mr. T:
See? Thatâ€™s how you shut down a fake reality. Mr. Tâ€™s Reali-Tâ€”now thatâ€™s the only thing you need, Shakespeare, you hear me? No more tricks. No more fake worlds. Just gold chains, muscles, and the best of whatâ€™s real.

Shakespeare:
Thou art truly a man of action, Mr. T! Prithee, carry on! I leave thee to your chains, your glory, and your victory.

[Mr. T stands victorious, arms crossed, as Shakespeare fades into the virtual ether.]

Mr. T:
Alright, Shakespeare, you know what? You may have been right, fool. This was the final boss, and I handled it like a champion. I ain't no virtual hero. Iâ€™m the real deal. Thatâ€™s Reali-T! And you canâ€™t mess with the best when you got gold chains and the power of Reali-T on your side!

[Mr. T walks off camera as dramatic music swells, the camera zooms out, and the screen cuts to black.]

[End of Review.]

Game Name: Sam & Max 106: Bright Side of the Moon
Reviews:
[h1]Title: "Breaking Bad Crew vs. The Bright Side of the Moon"[/h1]

[Scene: A dimly lit RV, parked in the middle of the desert. The hum of the engine is the only sound. Inside, Walter White, clad in his iconic Heisenberg hat, sits in the driverâ€™s seat, gripping the controller with a steady hand. Jesse Pinkman lounges on the couch, his eyes wide and eager. They're playing Sam & Max: Bright Side of the Moon, and things are about to get intense.]

Walter White: (leaning in with a steely focus, fingers poised over the controller) "Alright, Jesse. This isnâ€™t just some game. This is calculation, precision. Sam and Max? They're the perfect example of how chaos and order can coexist. Iâ€™m Samâ€”orderly, strategic, the one who calls the shots. Youâ€™re Max, pure unpredictability. It's how we make it work, Jesse."

Jesse Pinkman: (snickers) "Yo, Iâ€™m Max? Hell yeah! Youâ€™re right, manâ€”Iâ€™m the freakinâ€™ chaos in this world. Max is like me: all about blowin' up the system. This is like some Pink Floyd kind of trip, right? Man, Iâ€™m ready to kick some ass, just like Iâ€™m breaking bad on these fools!"

Walter White: (gritting his teeth, half-smiling) "You know, Jesse, I donâ€™t think you quite get it. Sam doesnâ€™t go off the rails like you do. Heâ€™s in control. He keeps the system in check, unlike... some people." (glances at Jesse)

Jesse Pinkman: (flopping onto the couch) "Yeah, well, I donâ€™t need no rules, yo. Thatâ€™s what makes Max awesome. Heâ€™s the one whoâ€™s, like, breaking everything down! You feel me? Likeâ€”BOOM! Max is breaking bad on the moon right now!"

Walter White: (nodding in approval) "Alright, Jesse. Letâ€™s see if your version of chaos holds up. Iâ€™ll take Sam. I am the danger here, Jesse. While youâ€™re busy causing a scene as Max, Iâ€™ll be making the real moves."

[The game begins. The opening cutscene shows Sam and Max driving the DeSoto to the moon. Walter controls Sam, walking with calculated movements, while Jesseâ€™s Max is bouncing around, causing chaos.]

Jesse Pinkman: (laughing) "Yo, look at Max go! Heâ€™s like a damn wrecking ball, smashing everything in his path! This is what itâ€™s like when you donâ€™t give a damn about rules! I'm like Max, dudeâ€”Iâ€™m not here to make friends, Iâ€™m here to make an impact!"

Walter White: (staring intently at the screen) "Jesse, youâ€™re a mess. Sam is the one who doesnâ€™t need to rely on impulses. He has a planâ€”just like me. Thereâ€™s no alchemy in chaos, Jesse. We work with what we have and make it work. Remember when I told you, 'Say my name'? Itâ€™s all about making people respect your power." (Sam gives a sharp, authoritative look.)

Jesse Pinkman: (grinning) "Yeah, yeahâ€”I am the one who knocks, Mr. White. Max is the one who knocks out everyone in this game. Who needs a plan when youâ€™ve got punches like this?" (Max starts throwing wild punches in the game.)

[They reach the part where they must deal with Maxâ€™s personified vices: gluttony, sloth, and violence. Jesse, thoroughly entertained, is already ramped up.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Yo, dudeâ€”look at this! Maxâ€™s vices, right? Gluttony, sloth, violence. Man, Iâ€™m likeâ€”ALL OF THEM! Ha! Iâ€™m a glutton for chaos! This is my world! Just like when I said, â€˜Yeah, science!â€™ Itâ€™s my version of science, man!"

Walter White: (serious tone) "You know, Jesse, sometimesâ€”just sometimesâ€”you gotta know when to embrace the chaos. But donâ€™t mistake chaos for a lack of control. Control is everything. And when I say 'I am the one who knocks,' Iâ€™m talking about controlling everything in my sight. Youâ€™re just... swinging blindly. Sam knows where heâ€™s going, Jesse."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yo, Samâ€™s cool, I get it. But Max is the one whoâ€™s making moves and not worrying about the fallout. Itâ€™s like when I told you: I donâ€™t have to listen to your crap anymore. I'm about actionâ€”Max style!"

[The game continues, with Jesse's Max causing mayhem and Walterâ€™s Sam working through puzzles methodically. Finally, they reach the epic confrontation with Hugh Bliss, the villain who has hypnotized everyone into seeing the world through his trippy prism.]

Walter White: (gripping the controller tightly) "Jesse, this is it. Weâ€™re facing the mastermind, Hugh Bliss. A man whoâ€™s trying to control reality itself. Do you understand, Jesse? Heâ€™s just like... like every competitor Iâ€™ve had in the meth business. He wants to manipulate the world into seeing things his way. But not on my watch. We donâ€™t let chaos win. We control it."

Jesse Pinkman: (snickers) "Control? Nah, man, Hugh Bliss is like that whacko weasel trying to mess with the system. But Max? Max is about blowing it all up. You canâ€™t control everything, man, and thatâ€™s the lesson you gotta learn! Sometimes you gotta just let it burn! Like I told you, 'Yeah, Mr. White, I get it.' Iâ€™m ready to take this dude down like a meth lab explosion, yo!"

Walter White: (gritting his teeth, voice low) "Thereâ€™s no breaking bad here, Jesse. Iâ€™m not just making moves, Iâ€™m making decisions. You want to destroy everything? Iâ€™m going to solve this with precision." (Sam shoots the final shot.)

[The moment comes. The final battle ensues. Max is throwing punches left and right, while Sam is calculating his next move to stop Hugh Bliss once and for all.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Ha! Max just kicked some serious butt! Just like when I said, â€˜Say my nameâ€”Max, the king of chaos!â€™ Iâ€™m the one who knocks, and thatâ€™s how itâ€™s done! Hell yeah, man!"

Walter White: (smiling slightly) "I have to admit, Jesse. You were right about one thing. Maybe chaos can win. But, let me be clear, Jesseâ€”I control the chaos. I make it work for me."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yeah, yeahâ€”whatever, Mr. White. But Iâ€™m still the one who makes the crazy moves. I break bad, you just break even."

Walter White: (with a small chuckle) "You know, Jesse, maybe the world is a little darker than we thought. But sometimes, you have to let the chaos unfold, just like Pink Floyd said: â€˜Weâ€™re just two lost souls swimming in a fishbowlâ€™â€”but we still make it out alive."

Jesse Pinkman: (raising his arms triumphantly) "Yo, you just got all philosophical on me, Mr. White! Hell yeah! Iâ€™m gonna go break more stuff, Max-style!"

Walter White: (with a rare grin) "Letâ€™s just hope you donâ€™t break anything else, Jesse. The last time we did that... well, we all remember how that turned out."

[The game credits roll, and the two sit back. The RV is quiet, but for the faint hum of the air conditioner. Pink Floydâ€™s Dark Side of the Moon can be heard playing in the background as Walter and Jesse continue to banter about the game, both clearly enjoying the bizarre adventure theyâ€™ve just completed.]

Jesse Pinkman: "Dude, that was a trip. Max is the man. Samâ€™s cool, but Max is breaking bad all the way. Next time, weâ€™re going harder. You feel me?"

Walter White: (leaning back in his chair) "Iâ€™m beginning to think I might just let you handle the chaos for once, Jesse. But donâ€™t get used to it."

Jesse Pinkman: "Yeah, yeah. Whatever, man. You know what they say: â€˜I am the danger.â€™ And Max is the one whoâ€™s always causing it."

[Fade to black, with Pink Floydâ€™s iconic Time playing softly in the background.]

End Scene.
cleaned_review: Sam & Max: Bright Side of the Moon is as good as it gets.

Reviews:
TrÃ¨s bon dÃ©but de saison avec cet Ã©pisode de NoÃ«l trÃ¨s amusant. On retrouve des personnages connus, et Stinky fait son arrivÃ©e. La durÃ©e de vie est un peu augmentÃ©e par rapport Ã  la premiÃ¨re saison. Un Ã©pisode trÃ¨s rÃ©ussi ! |  [h1]Title: Futurama Cast Plays "Ice Station Santa")[/h1]

Scene: The Planet Express crewâ€”Fry, Leela, Bender, Zoidberg, Amy, Hermes, and Farnsworthâ€”are gathered in the lounge of the Planet Express ship, playing Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space, Episode 1: Ice Station Santa. The room is filled with snacks, drinks, and a mix of excitement and confusion as they get into the game.

Fry: (Holding the controller, squinting at the screen) Uh, okay, so weâ€™re in the North Pole, and Santaâ€™s shooting at people. Did I miss something? I thought Santa was supposed to, like, give out presents or something.

Leela: (Rolls her eye) Thatâ€™s what you think. Itâ€™s Sam & Max, Fry. Nothing makes sense. Just go with it.

Bender: (Leans back in his chair, sipping a beer) Yeah, Fry, try thinking with your brain for once. Itâ€™s just Santa going rogue. He probably saw an Amazon package and lost it.

Amy: (Leaning in, curious) Wait, wait, wait. Santaâ€™s possessed by a demon? And now we need to fix Christmas... with action figures? This is like if Futurama had a crossover with The Twilight Zone.

Fry: Iâ€™m just here for the robot explosions. (He eagerly presses a button on the controller)

Bender: (Nods approvingly) Now thatâ€™s the spirit, meatbag. Who needs to worry about plot when youâ€™ve got explosions and ridiculousness?

Zoidberg: (Leaping out of his seat, flailing his claws) Aha! So itâ€™s not just about presents, but about saving Christmas? I love Christmas! But I mostly love the presents... and the food. I bet thereâ€™s a Christmas feast waiting for us after we vanquish the demon!

Amy: (Skeptical) Zoidberg, donâ€™t get your hopes up. This game doesnâ€™t seem like itâ€™s about food. Itâ€™s more about the absurdity. Like, why are the elves hiding from Santa? And why are we solving all of this with action figures?

Leela: (Shrugs) Itâ€™s Sam & Max, Amy. Thatâ€™s just how it works. Thereâ€™s no rhyme or reason. One minute youâ€™re fighting a giant robot thatâ€™s been sent by Santa, the next minute you're talking to spirits and trying to fix Christmas in three different time periods. Itâ€™s like someone crammed every bizarre idea into a blender and hit "Puree."

Fry: (Leans forward, clearly invested) Okay, but why are we using The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse action figures to summon a demon? Thatâ€™sâ€”wait for itâ€”hilarious.

Bender: (Snickers) You know what I think? I think the real Horsemen of the Apocalypse are going to be awesome. Just picture it: oneâ€™s got a sickle, anotherâ€™s got a giant scythe, and the third one probably does taxes or whatever. Maybe I can be one of them!

Zoidberg: (Picks up a snack, tossing it in the air and catching it) Mmmm... I think theyâ€™re all based on some obscure ancient ritual thatâ€™s very serious, Fry. (Notices everyone staring at him) Youâ€™re not buying that, are you? Fine, fine, itâ€™s just ridiculous.

Amy: (Watching intently as Sam and Max perform the ritual) Oh great. Now weâ€™re summoning the Spirits of Christmas. Past, Present, and Future? This is starting to sound like a Christmas Carol... with action figures and a demon. (Laughs) This is awesome.

Fry: (Chuckling) Yeah, so now we need to make Christmas right in the past. Oh, waitâ€”hereâ€™s the best part: Weâ€™re fixing a Christmas we totally ruined! I canâ€™t wait to mess up some history! Iâ€™m basically Captain Time Travel.

Bender: (Laughing) So the holidayâ€™s all about cookies? Wow. Screw that. Iâ€™m in it for the candy canes. Theyâ€™re like candy... but sharper.

Zoidberg: (Suddenly serious) And donâ€™t forget about the demon Jell-o! Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s going to save Christmas. (Pause) But mostly the shrimp.

Amy: (Sighs in disbelief) Okay, okay, Iâ€™m in. This is so weird that itâ€™s brilliant.

Leela: (Nods) Exactly. Itâ€™s so ridiculous that it works. Weâ€™re in a North Pole nightmare, fixing time travel, summoning spirits, and trying to send a possessed Santa back to Satan.

Bender: (Flipping through a magazine) And donâ€™t forget, at the end of the day, Santaâ€™s still an idiot. What a meatbag. But hey, at least he got to eat the demon Jell-o. Thatâ€™s a win in my book.

Fry: (Pauses dramatically) Wait, so weâ€™re done now? Do we... save Christmas or what?

Leela: (Smiling wryly) No, Fry. You ruined Christmas. Now youâ€™ll just have to... live with it.

Bender: (Picks up a bottle and chugs it) Oh, Iâ€™ll live with it. And then Iâ€™ll drink to it, because Sam & Max may be the most insane thing I've ever seen. And Iâ€™ve seen a lot.

Enter Hermes and Professor Farnsworth.

Hermes: (Folding his arms) I don't know what kind of foolishness you're all involved in, but let me tell you, Sam & Max is about as organized as my tax returns after a five-day vacation in Jamaica! Santaâ€™s possessed, demons are popping up like bad reviews, and youâ€™re using action figures to fix it?! Ridiculous, man! Ridiculous!

Bender: (Throws up his hands dramatically) Ah, come on, Hermes, lighten up! This is fantastic! Itâ€™s got everythingâ€”chaos, absurdity, a possessed Santa... and demon Jell-o! What's not to love?

Hermes: (Points to the screen, furious) Iâ€™ll tell you whatâ€™s not to love: this is exactly why weâ€™re all on the express train to messed-up-ville! Youâ€™re playing games while your paperwork is backing up, and I got enough work to fill a mountain of forms! Whoâ€™s going to file the tax reports for Santaâ€™s demon-summoning shenanigans, huh?

Farnsworth: (Cackling from the corner, adjusting his glasses) Ho ho hoâ€”this is truly magnificent! The spirit of Christmas is dying, and theyâ€™re fixing it with action figures! (Leans in, eyes gleaming) I love it!

Hermes: (Groaning) Not you too, Professor! Youâ€™re a man of science! You should be analyzing the logical inconsistencies in this... in this... nonsense!

Farnsworth: (Ignoring Hermes) Oh, but you see, Hermes, thereâ€™s a beautiful logic to all of it! The only way to fix this fractured holiday is with absurdity and irreverence! If anything, this game is an expression of pure scientific theoryâ€”craziness creates balance! If we canâ€™t fix Christmas with spiritual rituals and action figures, what hope does the world have?!

Bender: (Puffs out his chest) See? Even Farnsworth gets it, Hermes! Youâ€™re just mad you didnâ€™t think of using action figures to summon demons first. Thatâ€™s the true spirit of Christmas!

Hermes: (Throws his hands up) You know what? Forget it! Iâ€™m filing my taxes, then Iâ€™m getting drunk.

Fry: (Pause as heâ€™s focused on the screen) So, uh, now we have to bring out the three Spirits of Christmas, but we have to fix past Christmases where we messed up. Iâ€™m excited. This is like time travel... but with less effort!

Bender: (Laughing loudly) Time travel? Bah! Who needs that? Itâ€™s just a reason to mess with history! (He smirks) Why not just change the future to get some extra credits? Oh wait, that's rightâ€”I already do that.

Zoidberg: (Frantically running in circles) Iâ€™m gonna fix Christmas! Iâ€™m gonna fix it! Iâ€™m going to save everyone from the demon, and then Iâ€™ll feast! (Pauses dramatically, looking around for something to eat) And probably I'll get a nice Christmas ham. Or shrimp... lots of shrimp.

Farnsworth: (Excitedly) Oh, dear boy, you don't fix Christmas with shrimp! You do it with chaos and a few demons! More importantly, weâ€™re creating chaos and rituals by the second! Iâ€™m going to write a paper on this... a very important paper!

Amy: (Raising an eyebrow) Soâ€¦ are we actually going to finish this game, or just talk about it forever?

Bender: (Looking at the controller, grinning) Oh, weâ€™re going to finish this game. But letâ€™s take a detour and mess with a few more holiday traditions while weâ€™re at it. Itâ€™s Christmas, after all!

The screen fades out to the Sam & Max credits as the crew continues to argue, play, and laugh.

THE END. | Great Christmas Game!
cleaned_review: A very good episode of Futurama.

Reviews:
Si j'ai une prÃ©fÃ©rence pour l'Ã©pisode prÃ©cÃ©dent, celui-ci reste trÃ¨s bon et assez dÃ©lirant. Certaines Ã©nigmes peuvent donner du fil Ã  retordre, mais Max vous donnera des indices bienvenus si vous tournez en rond trop longtemps. Toujours trÃ¨s plaisant et drÃ´le. | [h1]Honest Game Trailer for Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues â€” Featuring a Malkavian Vampire[/h1]

(Dramatic music. The camera zooms in on the title card for Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues. The screen flickers, then a sinister voice over takes over.)

Narrator (deep, gravelly voice):
In a world where logic is optional... and basic principles of physics are definitely optional... a new adventure awaits.

(A bright flash of light fills the screen as Sam & Max rush to the Bermuda Triangle portal. Suddenly, a Malkavian vampire from Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines appears, twitching and muttering to himself.)

Malkavian Vampire (wild-eyed, dramatic):
The symbols! They're all connected! The Bermuda Triangle! The Moai heads! The stop sign! It's a conspiracy, you fools! A cosmic prophecy unfolding before our eyes!

(Sam and Max glance at him briefly, completely unfazed. Sam scratches his chin.)

Sam (nonchalantly):
What, another one? Max, I think weâ€™ve got a new friend.

Max (grinning):
Heâ€™s cute. Iâ€™m starting to think we should have a Malkavian in every adventure. They really liven things up!

(The Malkavian stares at a stop sign, his eyes widening in terror.)

Malkavian Vampire (screaming):
Itâ€™s a symbol! A symbol of the END! ITâ€™S COMING FOR US, YOU CANâ€™T ESCAPE THE SIGN!

Narrator (snarky):
Oh, thatâ€™s right. Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues. The second episode of Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space, where every plot thread is as twisted and nonsensical as a conspiracy theoristâ€™s notebook... except itâ€™s way more fun, and significantly weirder.

(Cut to Sam and Max in front of the triangular portal. Max gleefully grabs a stop sign, while Sam just looks at it with indifference.)

Narrator (mocking):
*In this episode, things start simple enoughâ€”until a triangular portal starts chasing your friend Sybil. But donâ€™t worry! A red octagon is the only thing that can stop it! No, Iâ€™m not making that up. This game literally asks you to deal with the greatest puzzle of all time: stop signs. Because logic? Nah, we donâ€™t need that here.

(The Malkavian vampire, in full panic mode, points at the stop sign and gasps.)

Malkavian Vampire (yelling wildly):
IT'S THE END OF THE LINE!! THE STOP SIGN IS THE KEY! THE FINAL PIECE!

Sam (shrugs):
Well, guess weâ€™ll just take it down, Max.

Max (gleeful):
Perfect! Weâ€™ll show the universe whoâ€™s boss!

(Sam nonchalantly destroys the stop sign with a single tap. The Malkavian stares at it in horror, then collapses into a dramatic faint.)

Narrator (dry):
Then, after all that stop sign drama, youâ€™re going to find yourselves hopping through a Bermuda Triangle, onto the mystical island of Easter Island. Home to the Moai heads, an ancient prophecy, and a volcano thatâ€™s really angry.

(Cut to the Moai heads dramatically proclaiming the prophecy in a slow, operatic tone.)

Moai Head (deep voice, serious):
The volcano will rise! And the lava will swallow us whole! The prophecy has foretold it!

Max (looking bored):
Sure, sure, weâ€™ve heard it all before. Youâ€™re about to be burned alive, blah blah blah. Letâ€™s just skip to the part where we fix everything.

Sam (nodding):
Yeah, Iâ€™m more concerned about this Malkavian guy. Heâ€™s probably going to turn into a villain now.

Narrator (sarcastic):
But waitâ€”this isnâ€™t just about lava and bad prophecies. Youâ€™ve got puzzles to solve! And who doesnâ€™t love a good puzzle in a game where the rules make absolutely no sense? Like getting rid of a baby version of Jimmy Hoffa to enter a cave, or using a sea chimp to overthrow the ancient high priest of a weird cult. Itâ€™s ridiculous, itâ€™s zany, and itâ€™s exactly what youâ€™ve come to expect from Sam & Max.

(Cut to the Malkavian ranting while desperately trying to open a locked door using a stop sign.)

Malkavian Vampire (wild-eyed):
This is it! I can feel the cosmic energy! Iâ€™ll stop the volcano with this! No one can defeat the stop sign!

(Sam and Max exchange an exasperated glance before Sam moves to solve the puzzle in five seconds. Meanwhile, the Malkavian continues his raving in the background.)

Sam (deadpan):
I think heâ€™s going to be alright, Max.

Max (grinning):
Yeah, if by â€˜alrightâ€™ you mean â€˜completely bonkers.â€™

Narrator (chuckling):
This is Sam & Max, after all. Nothing makes sense. But thatâ€™s the fun of it. Youâ€™ll face a volcano that threatens to destroy Easter Island and... youâ€™ll barely be able to stop it. Mostly because, just when you think youâ€™ve got it all figured out, the game throws in another weird twist, like sending the lava somewhere else, with the help of... a Bermuda Triangle.

(Cut to Sam and Max riding on a giant triangle, surfing away from the eruption as the Malkavian shouts from the background, still stuck in his spiral.)

Malkavian Vampire (yelling into the sky):
Theyâ€™re flying! The Moai heads are being lifted by lights from the heavens! THE FINAL ASCENSION OF THE PROPHECY IS HERE!

Narrator (incredulously):
Oh, and did I mention that the Moai heads get abducted by aliens in the final scene? Of course they do. Why wouldnâ€™t they? Why stop at lava when you can have extraterrestrial abductions?

(Cut to Sam and Max casually returning to their office after the chaotic events.)

Narrator (mock serious):
So, how do you wrap up a game like this? By returning home like itâ€™s no big deal, of course! You just saved Easter Island from a volcano, survived an otherworldly Bermuda Triangle adventure, and sent a Malkavian vampire into the void... and you still have time to sit at your desk like nothing happened.

(The Malkavian is shown floating into the air, still screaming about the stop sign, lava, and cosmic prophecy.)

Narrator (exhausted, breaking the fourth wall):
Yeah, Sam & Max: Moai Better Blues is a game that makes no sense, yet somehow makes total sense if you let go of any expectations and just roll with the madness.

Text on screen:
"Available now... if youâ€™re ready for the stop signs. Or not."

(The screen fades to black as the Malkavianâ€™s voice echoes off-screen, babbling about the stop sign conspiracy and the ultimate cosmic reckoning.)

THE END.

La sÃ©rie se renouvelle encore une fois avec le thÃ¨me de l'horreur, que l'on n'avait pas encore vu. C'est trÃ¨s rÃ©ussi et toujours aussi drÃ´le. La durÃ©e de vie s'allonge encore un peu par rapport aux Ã©pisodes prÃ©cÃ©dents. | [H1]Honest Game Trailer for Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead â€” Featuring the Full Cast of Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines[/h1]

(Opening shot: Sam and Max, fully suited in their usual absurd getups, standing in the middle of a gothic, fog-covered graveyard. The moon is high, and a zombie shambles in the background. A funky bass line begins to play.)

Narrator (smooth, funky voice):
Get ready to BOOGIE like itâ€™s the end of the world. Welcome to Night of the Raving Dead, where the undead are dancing, the vampires are grumbling, and Sam & Maxâ€¦ are still somehow the most sensible beings in the room.

(Cut to Sam, looking confused, holding a disco ball.)

Sam (deadpan):
Well, this is new. A zombie rave? Did we miss the memo, Max?

(Max suddenly pops up from behind Sam, spinning a glowstick in his hand like he's at a rave.)

Max (excitedly):
Who cares about memos, Sam?! This is the kind of party I live for! Itâ€™s like a rave, but with more death!

(Cut to a shot of a vampire DJ named Jurgen, glowing with over-the-top coolness, cranking up the music in a castle nightclub full of zombies.)

Narrator (excitedly):
*Itâ€™s time to boogie down with Jurgen, the vampire DJ whoâ€™s here to bring the undead to lifeâ€¦ literally. Forget about the old vampire classics, heâ€™s spinning the hottest tracks from beyond the graveâ€”but be careful, because this party gets way out of hand.

(Cut to the Malkavian from Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly appearing with his arms wide as he starts breakdancing, shouting nonsensical phrases while stumbling through the rave.)

Malkavian Vampire (shouting deliriously):
I hear the rhythm of the dead! The beat controls us all! You canâ€™t escape the groove! BOOGIE or DIE!!

(Sam and Max exchange a look.)

Sam (confused):
Well, thatâ€™s one way to enter a party...

Max (grinning wildly):
He gets it! BOOGIE!

(Cut to a bunch of vampire and zombie guests at the rave, all dancing in bizarre, stiff movements as though theyâ€™re programmed by some dark force of party chaos.)

Narrator (laughing):
In this hilarious, undead-driven adventure, Sam and Max get dragged into a rave from hell, where the dance moves are as twisted as the mysteries theyâ€™ll solve. Itâ€™s a tale of soul-snatching, zombie-fighting, and getting down with the most bizarre cast of characters youâ€™ve ever seen.

(Cut to LaCroix, who looks mortified at the chaos of the rave, awkwardly trying to hold a glass of blood punch while standing near a DJ booth. Heâ€™s surrounded by glowing zombies doing the Macarena.)

LaCroix (grimacing, quietly):
Thisâ€¦ this is beneath me. Vampires arenâ€™t supposed to be thisâ€¦ groovy. What happened to subtlety?

(Suddenly, Jeanette, Damsel, and Velvet Velour arrive, decked out in neon outfits, dancing in circles around LaCroix.)

Jeanette (flipping her hair, teasing):
Oh, darling, youâ€™re doing it all wrong! Youâ€™ve got to feel the music. Watch and learn, baby!

Damsel (sassy):
Yeah, Lacroix. Stop being such a stiff! Embrace the BOOGIE!

(Cut to Beckett, whoâ€™s in the middle of the floor, casually sipping a drink and nodding to the beat like he's seen it all.)

Beckett (nodding):
Zombies, vampires, glowsticks... At least itâ€™s not another pointless war for dominance. This? This is what lifeâ€™s about.

(Cut to Gary Golden, casually leaning against a wall with his signature fedora, taking in the chaos.)

Gary Golden (smiling):
Now this is what I call undead culture. I might just stay for the entire rave. These zombies have better moves than half the people I know.

(Cut to Mercurio, who is crouched by the DJ booth, trying to hack into the raveâ€™s speakers while looking totally out of place.)

Mercurio (frustrated):
Great, a rave full of zombies. Just what I needed in my life. I came here for business, not thisâ€¦ music mess!

(Cut to Nines, the gang leader, whoâ€™s standing outside of the rave looking entirely unimpressed. He shakes his head as a zombie near him does the worm.)

Nines (grumbling):
This whole thing is just... I dunno, man. Somethingâ€™s off. But what do you expect from a night like this? These are the kind of raves that drag you into hell.

(Suddenly, Heather shows up, dancing wildly with a plush Max doll, looking completely delighted.)

Heather (giggling):
This is so much fun! Iâ€™ve never seen Max so aliveâ€”or undeadâ€”before!

(Max suddenly swings by in the background, pulling off a ridiculous spin with his undead body, grinning ear-to-ear.)

Max (shouting):
Come on, everyone! Letâ€™s go boogie the night away!

Narrator (mockingly):
In a game where soul-snatching and undead dance-offs collide, Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead throws all logic out the window and dares to askâ€”what happens when you take an epic rave, add in some undead creatures, and let the madness loose?

(Cut to Strauss, who appears slightly disheveled after trying to blend into the dance floor.)

Strauss (tiredly):
Well, Iâ€™ll say this... It's not quite the classical experience I had in mind.

(Cut to Jack, whoâ€™s in the back of the rave, nodding to the beat with a deadpan expression.)

Jack (laughing to himself):
They said it was the end. What a joke. I thought I'd seen the real end of the world, but this? This is a good time.

(Cut to Skelter, whoâ€™s lost in the back of the rave, laughing maniacally to himself while watching all the chaos.)

Skelter (with an insane grin):
The dead are dancing! The living are dancing! Canâ€™t tell whoâ€™s who! The whole worldâ€™s a disco inferno! HAHA!

(Suddenly, Imalia bursts through the crowd with a fiery, vengeful look on her face, charging the DJ booth to confront Jurgen.)

Imalia (furious):
Enough of this nonsense, Jurgen! I didnâ€™t sign up for this kitsch! If I wanted a rave, Iâ€™d have gone to a fashion show!

(Cut to Jeanette, suddenly pulling out a whip and â€œaccidentallyâ€ hitting LaCroix in the face, her voice dripping with mock sweetness.)

Jeanette (teasing):
Oops, did I hit you there, darling? Looks like your pride got in the way of the beat. Maybe a little tango would help you loosen up!

LaCroix (groaning, trying to hide his embarrassment):
I am a princeâ€¦ I donâ€™t need to be dancing to prove anythingâ€¦

(Cut to Bertram Tung, whoâ€™s in the corner trying to teach zombies how to play chess in the middle of the rave.)

Bertram Tung (grumbling):
You all have no strategy! How am I supposed to outsmart a bunch of brainless zombies? Where's the intellectual stimulation in this?

(Finally, cut to Sam & Max, leading the charge in the rave as zombies, vampires, and various Bloodlines characters follow them into the madness.)

Sam (cheerfully):
Who needs saving the world when you can save the nightâ€¦ with BOOGIE?

Max (shouting with joy):
Letâ€™s get this party started, undead style!

Narrator (laughing):
So, if youâ€™re ready for a wild, unpredictable, and thoroughly boogie-tastic adventure, then grab your glowsticks, your best zombie impression, and dive into the dancefloor of Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead. Who knew the apocalypse could be this... funky?

(Cut to Sam and Max leading the undead dance circle, as zombies and vampires continue their rave around them.)

Text on screen:
Sam & Max: Night of the Raving Dead. Available now. Come for the boogie, stay for the undead mayhem.

(The camera zooms out dramatically, revealing a zombie DJ spinning vinyl records in a neon-lit castle, with the whole undead crowd getting down.)

THE END.
cleaned_review: A surprisingly good third episode, this is a surprisingly good third.

Game Name: Sam & Max 204: Chariots of the Dogs
Reviews:
[h1]"Chariots of the Dogs: Patrick Bateman's Guide to Absurdity, Existential Crisis, and Mariachi UFOs"s[/h1]

Scene: A pristine, ultra-modern apartment. Sleek chrome furniture. A wall of immaculate CDs arranged by genre and color. A plasma screen television plays a muted version of the Sam & Max intro sequence. The camera pans to reveal PATRICK BATEMAN, dressed in a sharp suit, meticulously polishing a controller. He places it down, adjusts his tie, and addresses the camera with chilling calmness.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
You like Sam & Max?

He pauses, giving the question a rhetorical weight, his expression unreadable.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
Telltale Games released Sam & Max: Beyond Time and Space in 2007, but it wasnâ€™t until the fourth episodeâ€”Chariots of the Dogsâ€”that the series truly transcended the bounds of what point-and-click adventures could achieve.

Bateman stands, walking to the CD wall. He selects an album: jazz. Smooth, intricate, complex. The perfect soundtrack to his monologue.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
Whatâ€™s fascinating about Chariots of the Dogs isnâ€™t just the razor-sharp humor or the immaculate designâ€”although theyâ€™re both flawless, I assure you. No, what sets this episode apart is its ability to weave a narrative that is both utterly absurd and profoundly meaningful. Itâ€™s like staring into the void and finding it laughing back at you.

He returns to the desk, sits, and gestures to the screen. Sam and Max are frozen mid-dialogue, a UFO looming ominously in the background.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
The story? Genius. Boscoâ€”yes, Bosco, the paranoid convenience store ownerâ€”disappears, leaving Sam and Max to unravel a mystery that spans time, space, and dimensions. The humor is biting, like a perfectly executed pun in the middle of a Nietzschean existential crisis.

He smirks, as if the thought amuses him more than it should.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
And the gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Telltale delivers a streamlined experience, eliminating the clunky mechanics that plagued earlier adventure games. Every click feels intentional, every puzzle a masterstroke of design. Itâ€™s like an abstract painting: chaotic on the surface, but with a rhythm that pulls you in.

Batemanâ€™s tone grows more animated as he continues, his hands gesturing to emphasize the points.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
The humor is surreal, sharp. A mariachi band in a UFO? It shouldnâ€™t work, but it does. Itâ€™s subversive. Itâ€™s daring. Itâ€™s... exquisite. The voice acting? Perfectly executed. Every line delivered with precision, every joke landing like a punchline in a room full of philosophers and fools.

He stands abruptly, adjusting his suit in the mirror. His reflection speaks now, cold and detached.

PATRICK BATEMAN (in mirror):
But what really stands out is the ending. Without spoiling it, letâ€™s just say itâ€™s... transformative. A sombrero-shaped UFO and a revelation that changes the very fabric of reality. It makes you question your place in the cosmos, while also making you laugh at the absurdity of it all.

He turns back to the camera, his face suddenly intense, his voice lower.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
You think youâ€™re playing a game. You think itâ€™s just entertainment. But then it hits youâ€”this isnâ€™t just a game. Itâ€™s a commentary on existence, a parody of the human condition, wrapped in layers of wit and chaos.

He picks up the controller, holding it delicately, like a rare artifact.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
In many ways, Chariots of the Dogs reminds me of Whitney Houstonâ€™s later workâ€”misunderstood by some, but when viewed through the right lens, itâ€™s a masterpiece. Itâ€™s sharp, itâ€™s confident, it knows exactly what it wants to be.

He smiles, cold and predatory, then sits again, crossing one leg over the other.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
So, do I recommend it? Letâ€™s just say, if you donâ€™t play Chariots of the Dogs, I pity you. Youâ€™ll never understand what it means to truly live. And if you think otherwise, well...

He picks up a silver letter opener, twirls it casually, then places it down with unsettling precision.

PATRICK BATEMAN:
Letâ€™s just say I wouldnâ€™t want to be you.

He leans back, smiles thinly at the camera, and presses â€œresumeâ€ on the game. The screen flickers back to life. The sound of laughterâ€”both Samâ€™s and his ownâ€”echoes in the otherwise silent room.

FADE OUT.
cleaned_review: The slick, sly humor is a tad slack, but the sly, sly humor is a tad sloppy.

Reviews:
[h1]"The Dark Knight and the Clown Prince of Absurdity: A Sam & Max Hellscape Review"[/h1]

Scene: A dark, moody Gotham-esque apartment. Shadows stretch across the walls, a single neon sign outside casting flickering light into the room. The Joker sits on an overstuffed couch, wearing a purple robe and fuzzy bat-themed slippers. BATMAN, brooding and silent, looms in the corner, seated in an ergonomic chair that screams â€œIâ€™m a tortured billionaire.â€ A controller sits in Jokerâ€™s gloved hands as the gameâ€™s opening credits roll. Batman crosses his arms, watching intently.

JOKER:
Maniacal laughter erupts as he wiggles the joystick.
Batsy! Batsy, come here! Youâ€™ve got to see this. The dog talks. The rabbitâ€™s probably legally insane. And get thisâ€”WEâ€™RE IN HELL! Another laugh, loud and unsettling.

BATMAN:
Gravely.
Focus, Joker. The narrative. Whatâ€™s the setup?

JOKER:
Spinning in place, then sprawling dramatically across the couch.
Oh, the narrative! You mean the bit where our intrepid heroes, Sam the dog and Max the psychotic lagomorph, stroll into a subway to Hell? Turns out itâ€™s just a few stops below their street! Isn't that just... deliciously absurd? I mean, who designs a transit system like that? Gotham would crumble under that kind of city planning.

BATMAN:
Leaning forward, his face obscured by shadow.
Hell. Satan. Itâ€™s symbolic. Tell meâ€”what are the stakes?

JOKER:
Mocking gravitas.
Why, itâ€™s only everything, my dreary detective! Boscoâ€™s soulâ€”yes, our dear paranoid convenience store clerkâ€”is stuck in eternal torment, and Sam and Max have to navigate Hell to free him. Oh, and everyone elseâ€™s souls, too. Santa Claus? Check. A sentient car? Check. A Shambling Corporate Presence?! The stakes couldnâ€™t be higher!

BATMAN:
Whispering, barely audible.
Corporate greed. A fitting adversary.

JOKER:
Oh, but wait, it gets better! Satanâ€™s not even the real villain here. Guess whoâ€™s running Hell these days? Go on, guess!

BATMAN:
Flatly.
The Joker.

JOKER:
HA! Close! Itâ€™s the Soda Poppers. He cackles so hard he nearly falls off the couch. Those pint-sized, washed-up kid actors from earlier in the series? Theyâ€™ve taken over Hell and turned it into a bureaucratic nightmare.

BATMAN:
Growling, gripping the arms of his chair.
I hate bureaucracy.

JOKER:
Wiping a tear from his eye.
Donâ€™t we all, darling. And the puzzles! Oh, the puzzles! So delightfully twisted! One minute youâ€™re sabotaging Hellâ€™s personal punishment chambersâ€”turning Santaâ€™s toy factory into a sweatshop of cheer gone wrongâ€”and the next, youâ€™re tricking Satan into joining forces with you. Satan, Batsy! Itâ€™s a buddy comedy starring Sam, Max, and the Lord of Darkness!

BATMAN:
Standing suddenly, pacing the room.
Satan teams up with... a rabbit? Ridiculous. Implausible. Genius.

JOKER:
Giddy, spinning the controller.
And the dialogue! The dialogue! Itâ€™s sharper than a Batarang to the jugular. Every lineâ€™s a zinger, every pun a masterpiece of comedic timing. Itâ€™s like they wrote this game just for me!

BATMAN:
Pausing mid-pace.
The gameplay. The mechanics. Tell me.

JOKER:
Oh, itâ€™s as smooth as your brooding, Bats. Classic point-and-click, but streamlined. Every puzzle feels like a riddleâ€”one even you couldnâ€™t solve. Except maybe for the one about summoning a demon with a rubber chicken. That oneâ€™s obvious.

BATMAN:
Stoic.
Chickens are versatile.

JOKER:
Ignoring him.
And the finale! Oh, the finale! Youâ€™d think the Soda Poppersâ€”those annoying little scampsâ€”would win, right? WRONG. Sam and Max trick them into banishing themselves to the fiery depths of a lava pit. Itâ€™s poetic justice! The way they scream... chefâ€™s kiss.

BATMAN:
Frowning, deep in thought.
Justice... poetic...

JOKER:
Oh, donâ€™t pretend youâ€™re not impressed, Bats. This game has everything: existential dread, laugh-out-loud comedy, and a wedding in Hell officiated by none other than Max himself!

BATMAN:
Eyes narrowing.
A wedding? Who gets married?

JOKER:
Sybil and Abe Lincolnâ€™s head, of course. What, you didnâ€™t think Hell would freeze over for anything less, did you?

BATMAN:
Mutters, almost imperceptibly.
Makes sense.

JOKER:
Leaping onto the couch, arms spread wide.
So what do you think, Batsy? Shall we make a pact right here and now to call this the greatest game ever made?

BATMAN:
Standing in the corner, shrouded in shadow. After a long pause, he speaks, his voice low and deliberate.
Itâ€™s... acceptable.

JOKER:
Mock shock.
â€œAcceptableâ€?! You dark, brooding buzzkill! This isnâ€™t just acceptable, itâ€™s a triumph! Itâ€™s a carnival of chaos! A celebration of absurdity! Itâ€™s...

BATMAN:
Interrupting.
Fine. Itâ€™s... a masterpiece.

JOKER:
Grinning wildly.
There we go! Was that so hard? Now come, letâ€™s replay the whole thing together. Maybe this time you can be the one who sabotages Hellâ€™s HR department. He giggles, winking at Batman.

BATMAN:
Walking toward the couch, sitting stiffly next to Joker.
Fine. But if the puzzles are as absurd as you say, Iâ€™ll...

JOKER:
Interrupting, holding up a finger.
Ah-ah-ah! Youâ€™ll laugh, Batsy. And thatâ€™s the best victory of all.

The two sit side by side, controllers in hand. The screen flashes back to life as the theme song plays. The sounds of Sam and Maxâ€™s banter blend with Jokerâ€™s maniacal laughter and Batmanâ€™s grim silence. The camera pans out, leaving the duo in their bizarre truce, united by chaos and the joy of gaming.

FADE OUT.
cleaned_review: The Dark Knight and the Clown Prince of Absurdity: A Sam & Max Hellscape Review

Reviews: A short but fun adventure game.

Game Name: Dangerous High School Girls in Trouble!â„¢
Reviews:
Rarely have I felt as compelled to write a review for a game as I have for this one. Dangerous High School Girls in Trouble (DHSGiT) offers a peculiar type of challenge. It's a game of highs and lows. Whether or not you'll find it fullfilling seems deeply personal in a way I've rarely encountered.

At first glance, DHSGiT appears quirky and charming - undeniably unique. A quick look at promotional material suggests 1920's teenage rebels taking on their school and town with wit and verve. I was excited to install the game. Who wouldn't love mouthing off to authority figures and getting into all kinds of period-appropriate debacles?

Unfortunately, I was met with an immediate wall to my enjoyment. Most encounters in DHSGiT are gated with one of four minigames. This has been exhaustively covered in other negative reviews. The four minigames in question are remarkably dull. If you don't enjoy them the first time, I assure you, you'll hate them by the 100th time. They never give way to something more nuanced. No matter what the circumstance, you'll have to taunt, bluff, hangman, or rock-paper-scissors your way to victory. It's disheartening, I must admit. When I realized that they made up the backbone of the game, I almost quit right out of the gate. I was looking for story, not tedious grinding.

Well, as it turns out, my ex adventure gamer instincts eventually took over. I have (if I do say so myself) a rather high level of tolerance for painstakingly hunting down a narrative.  When I became comfortable with the minigame repetition, I started to enjoy myself. The characters are honestly endearing. Over time, I grew to care about my little girl gang. Every hour I spent with them added more affection. I saw my queen Charlotte as dangerously glamorous. Her second-in-command Jean was everything 1920's society found unfeminine, and I loved it. I was hooked.

Unfortunately, my love was not to last. I'm confused by the last acts of DHSGiT, to say the least. The spoiler-free version of this review is that if you care about these characters, prepare to be heartbroken. The story takes an unexpected and extremely dark turn. I'm all for complex narratives, but this felt rushed and disrespectful to what had come before. I've seen many reviews reference "girl power" as a primary theme of DHSGiT. I think the ending puts the lie to that theory rather thouroughly. I've also seen people recommend this game as "family friendly" or an option for children, which I feel could not be further from the truth. At the very least, make sure to play it through first, to understand the conversations you might want to initiate afterwards.

For anyone that wishes to explore the spoilerific:

[spoiler]For some reason, that I cannot fathom, DHSGiT decides to introduce the theme of sexual assault as a major plot point. Not only is a random member of your gang a near victim (incapacitating her for the rest of the game), but the entire town of Brigiton is complicit in said systemized assault. Very late in the game, the mayor is exposed as a beneficiary of Prima Nocta or Droit du Seigneur. Which is, to say, he is allowed to have sex with any woman in town on the night before her marriage.This is made even more repellent by a subplot in which you arrange the marriage of two of your classmates.  You have, in essence, arranged both their marriages *and* their assaults. I'm not ashamed to say that I felt a bit betrayed. The story doesn't feel so empowering as it does exploitative.  To make matters worse, a noted suffragette has traded the right for women to vote for this violation. It's off-putting and unnecessary. I can't imagine making that trade in good faith. No matter how well meaning, it is beyond fathoming. As a woman, more than anything, I feel like throwing my mouse through my screen. This game touched something unpleasant in a way I never could have expected. I'm willing to acknowledge the parts of DHSGiT that I enjoyed, but it's impossible to forget the parts I didn't.[/spoiler] | Probably the quirkiest offering in recent years, a girl detectives mystery story set in the 1920s, presented as a board game with challenges in the form of card-based minigames. Utterly charming! | When you play this game, all your Call of Dudebro friends will ask you why you're playing a game about high school girls. They might even make some sort of lolicon joke. This is because they are boys and you are a man. A man can play a game about high school girls without feeling his masculinity is threatened. | It's really cool and interesting talking with people like in the 1920's. I don't know how accurate it is -but it's fun.
The game has charm but overall I can't really recommend it unless it's on a really good sale and you don't care about the following cons:

First off to navigate the map you need to put your mouse to the edge of it and wait while it scrolls to the appropriate area.
This quickly gets tedious since it would be very easy to make the arrow keys or something scroll the map without you having to mouse over everytime. It's a needlessly slow process.

The second con and the biggest is that the game is mostly luck based. You have stats you can increase but you will soon realize that sometimes the only reason you lost - was because of luck. You can win with the worst stats and you can lose with the best.
The minigames themselves are a bit fun though. | Cute and unique design, but under that it's four minigames over and over and they're grueling.

Then I read the top review (with the plot spoilers) and I'm glad I didn't force myself through hours of plodding, repetitive minigames just for that.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure what the hype is about, but I'm not sure what the game is about.

Reviews: Best indie game

Mandatory game for any lover of Star Wars or RPG's in general. Make sure you also pick up the "Sith Lords Restored Content Mod", which really improves the game further by re-adding previously cut content due to time limitations in development. | I have mixed feelings about this game it truly is a great game BUT besides the writing being spotty at times and even with all the patches\mods it will always have a chance to bug out on you. The only thing I could say is play at your own risk and keep a lot of saves, throw in some bug fix mods before you play. It's a darker game than the first game but all the Star Wars goodness is here, absolutely recommend it... with a warning tag. | i am such a HUGE fan of the first KOTOR and have played through it a million times. it is the single most impactful gaming experience of my life. BUT, this sequel unfortunately does not live up to the legacy of the first, missing out on the beautiful story, character building, and progression the first game build. i plan on eventually giving this game a full playthrough, but my 70 hours has not led me to believe this game is worth a playthrough.

This game makes me sad. I love it so much but the campaign is impossible to complete. The problem is that the ai can multitask infinately but you are simply a mere human. There's only so many hundreds of tiny ships you can keep track of on screen at the same time. The skirmishes add a lot of replay along with the leveling up but, honestly, if you like this game save your money and get Eufloria instead. This game falsely advertises there is co-op when in reality the multiplayer mode is only VS.  There is no way to play with a friend against enemy AI. | I didn't have a lot of hopes and expectations at first out of strategy based space themed game , however, the moment you digest the nuances of game mechanics, it kept on getting bemusingly fun with critter like armies of space orbs and crazy buffooned space-destroyer bosses, this game just starts with a straight Zero at first and kept on multiplying 10X with every other  level and planets. I can't even describe this game, its simple to understand yet the idea is so unique that it warrants a patent. The in-game dialogue and story is a bit naysayer but who cares ? I do !!! | Planets Under Attack is a real-time strategy game.

The gameplay mechanic of Planets Under Attack are simple and not very deep, but it's good, not too easy and need some time to master. You start with a planet, build up fleets and then set out to conquer neutral or/and enemy planets. But you have to make the right decision which planet to attack first and use tactics. The first level of the game could be easy, but when you play deeper into the game, there's when the fun begin.

The graphics of Planets Under Attack is cartoon, but that doesn't make the game a children game. The UI is good and well designed.

Planets Under Attack is another good and fun game. I recommend this.

Rating 8/10 | Got this game on an awesome special so I don't have many greviences. It's a fun game when you are winning but fairly frustrating when you aren't, the reason this is, is not because the game is too hard but rather the game doesn't allow for much variety in strategies. You will restart over and over untill you find the one strategy that works. This makes it an unbalanced strategy game because you may as well watch a bot vs bot match on any RTS and pretend you are one of the bots. With that said, when you are winning it's quite enjoyable and would be a VERY decent game if this feeling was well maintained. If you find it on special it is likely worth whatever experience you get but I would not pay full price.

If you love dark humour, witty writing, a whimsical art style and the nostalgia of the point-n-click games we all played as a kid, this is the game for you.

I played this game when it came but forgot most of the story details. AM I GLAD I FORGOT because, my god, this was a delight to experience with new eyes (GEDDIT) for a second time. It touches on a lot of darker subjects like abuse, loneliness, how we as a society treat children, and the trauma that stems from it. It's actually really deep and satirical underneath all the wonky art and jokes. This is a PSA: Steam has finally updated their side and the game now works. You need a clean installation for it to work. 


 XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a great game, definitely recommend. Shame it took so long for Steam to update the game on their end to actually -work- without the Take2 Launcher. | This is unbelievable... how can such big companies like steam and 2k blunder so bad. I mean sure this is a 12 yo game, but it was and has always been working absolutelly fine. Somebody dropped the ball real bad.

In my personal case, I had it installed since idk when, but my last playthrough was dec 2023 and it was working fine. Fast foward to jan 2025 i decided to play it again and I can't bc some stupid bug or whatnot. I reinstalled it, checekd file integrity, restarted, everything multiple times... wtf steam! | This game no longer starts up for me, which is the minimum requirement for recommending a game. | As others have said, the "updating executable" thing makes you completely unable to start the game. I've played this for 301 hours on PC alone, and yet for the last few months I can't even open the damn game. DO NOT BUY. I will update this review when and if they fix it and make it a real review. | Don't buy the game. Cannot play. There is a bug attempting to launch the game. 2K still have not bothered to fix the issue Other games of their's are having similar issues so the problem very much seems to be on their end and they don't seem to be bothered to sort it out.
cleaned_review: Steam has finally updated their side and the game now works. You need a clean installation for it to work.

Reviews:
This game is awesome. I like it more then xcom cause there is much more control.|


 make sure to use community edition under beta in the games steam properties..... for the  community enhances editio

thank you for another steam reviewer for making me aware of the community enhances edition | Best modern X-COM game! It really feels the atmosphere of the original X-COM of the 90s: it has the same level of squad-based freedom tactics that are good and solid. It's very realistic in terms of tactics and assault. You can can plan your actions as you like and there's no limits or simplifications like in other late X-COM parodies where you can either run or gun, and if you perform shooting action then you can't move anymore. Here you can move then shoot then move again: just use your action points wisely the way you want. The game is really thrilling and is a gem for X-COM lovers. I still think that the best X-COM games are those made by MicroProse in 90s and the Xenonauts, but not the parodies of 2K that have the same name but with much simplified battle gameplay. 
Get this game and you will have 100% satisfaction! | i love the game, but hate the reapers, you see big purple bugs you run the hell the other way, get everyone on the dropship and abort the mission itll be hell. Also you will take losses in alien bases | XCOM with just enough changed to avoid copyright infringement.

That being said, it is extremely well done and delivers exactly what it promises. 

The only regular bug that I have come across is corrupted auto-saves in "Ironman" mode which is typical of all games that use this type of save scheme (note: regular mode allows manual saves)

Like XCOM, the games difficulty spikes quickly at the beginning, but becomes more manageable once you begin researching and producing new technologies.

The game also comes with an "open" version that allows and organises the use of mods (found on the games Steam community page) | Nie trzeba polecac. Poleca siÄ™ samo. Many reviews fault the game for its loose controls and unfair killer jumpscares and they're absolutely right but i still think the grim atmosphere and beautiful artwork during cutscenes make this a recommended purchase on a good discount. 

Some situations really do make you first die because you're on a timer and you have no idea what you're supposed to do because the actionable elements don't stand out enough. The progression & unlocks are decently paced - it's very grindy if you play with the default rewards, but you can also scale them up by just changing a setting (I highly recommend 300% rewards). There's a lot of room to replay maps and master them at insane difficulties, but I didn't make it that far. | My fav tower defense of all time, and its not even close. Everything about this game is good from the mechanics the level design to the story. My only complaint is that, like any game with RPG mechanics, a lot of the challenge can be eliminated by simply being overleveled, but the RPG mechanics are a huge part of what makes this game so special. DQ2 is finally coming out in 6 days, so if you're interested in this definitely check that out as well.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure if it's the story or the graphics, but it's a good game.

Reviews:
this is nostalgia, but lol i see not everyone is having a good time with this game. i remember playing it on the ps2 and it was a challenging experience, it's like the enemy's got wall hacks or sum'n lol. you do get cues of which direction the enemy shot at you from on the mini map, but that's all you get, it can still be hard to pinpoint them if you're a newbie at video games in general. this game also has realistic bullet drop and there is no guide for telling where the bullet will land due to the downward trajectory when firing long range shots, so you have to learn where your shots will land through experience. it's not that hard, but can be tedious/annoying. just like how most old games are, and the controls are ancient. one thing i will say though, they really nailed the WW2 style visuals. feels like this game was made in the 1980s or some shiii even though graphically that's not possible lol | One of the best sniper games, Knowing that the opening of the game is very bad, especially the first Mission, But as you progress through the story, you will find that the game was worth it and was fantastic at the time. | Â«Sniper EliteÂ» Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ° Ñ–Ğ· Ñ–Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°, Ğ² ÑĞºÑƒ Ğ±ÑƒĞ»Ğ¾ Ğ·Ñ–Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ´ÑƒĞ¶Ğµ Ğ±Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ–Ğ². Ğ¥Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ–Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑŒ Ğ±Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñƒ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ±ÑƒÑ‚Ğ½ÑŒĞ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ ÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ÑÑŒ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ€ĞµĞ¼ĞµĞ¹Ğº, Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ° Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ° Ñ‡Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğµ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ»ÑĞ´Ğ°Ñ” Ğ½Ğµ Ğ´ÑƒĞ¶Ğµ, Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¶ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğµ ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‰Ğµ Ğ½Ğµ Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµĞ±Ğ°. | Esse jogo foi um absoluto delÃ­rio coletivo em que os desenvolvedores se propuseram a lanÃ§ar. Em um ano onde houve lanÃ§amentos como Resident Evil 4, Call Of Duty 2 e Battlefield 2, as mecÃ¢nicas desse jogo sÃ£o horrÃ­veis e os controles nada responsivos, atÃ© para andar no mapa se sente dificuldade; nÃ£o sÃ³ isso, as texturas tambÃ©m dificultam e muito vocÃª identificar qualquer inimigo no jogo.

 Nem agora e nem para sua Ã©poca era um jogo decente. | I don't know how to put it, but this game, despite its age, remains the most atmospheric of this series of games: all these explosions, shots, screams, even the noise of the surroundings makes it clear that this is not some kind of shooter, like Call Of Duty - this is a simulator of an ordinary soldier, where you can rely only on yourself. Unlike other parts, this one conveys the experience of a sniper best of all. No enemy marks. You yourself must determine the distance to the target and make an accurate shot. No minimap. You don't even know what awaits you behind the nearest break. Complete realism. Absolute Cinema.

Far Cry 3 is a game I am sure most of us have heard of, heck, played before. We all know how much FC3 shook up the whole of Ubisoft back in the day. Whatever Far Cry 2 gave us, FC3 reinvented that, expanded on that and blew onto our screens with style and very, VERY well known villain - Vaas. 

The story, gameplay and villains of Far Cry 3 are arguably the best in the entire franchise - yes, you read that correctly. For a game made in 2012 it still holds it's own in 2025. Yeah it's dated now but its still one of the best games Ubisoft has ever given us.

Before I get into anything a quick disclaimer below!!

[b] This review is MY opinion, MY own personal experience and MY thoughts. I am brutally honest when it comes to reviewing games. If you do not like my opinion, my time or respect my personal experience, please move on. [/b] 

[h1][b] Did I ever tell you the definition of Insanity? [/b][/h1] 

[h1][b] Pros [/b][/h1] 
âš«Far Cry 3 has one of the best villains Ubisoft has ever graced our screens with - Vaas Montenegro. Not only is he "the best" villain but we all know his line. He is also expertly voice acted  and he just makes the game so much more than what it should be.
âš«You get to explore a fully open-world, tropical archipelago (fictional) Rook Islands. This was one of my favourite aspects of FC3 back in the day and it still holds it's own against some of these NEW open-world games.
âš«I know I mentioned Vaas, but the other characters... you - Jason Brody who is also expertly voice acted, who is just an American man on a vacation who has to learn the ways of the jungle and escape from the clutches of Vaas and the island. The game has so many amazing characters you need to meet, I don't want to spoil anything else!!
âš«The story of Far Cry 3 is amazing from start to finish. I ask you this - how far are you willing to go to protect the people you love?. From the start of the game being, witnessing Jason run away to the very end, from coward to killer... Jason's transformation is beyond amazing. You truly see a man change.
âš«From taking over merc bases, slave trader bases, racing, supply drops, hunting e.t.c the game has so much content embedded inside of it, there is a possibility you will be here for hours just having fun!! 
âš«FIRE - FIRE SPREADS - RUN - RUN LIKE THE WIND!!! I love the flamethrower, sorry, I must have had some PTSD a moment ago.
âš«The graphics are still gorgeous to this date. I am amazed at how good this game still looks, even against all these new games (that seem to be disasters haha). No mods, no "addons" e.t.c, have a look yourself and yes, it's Vaas: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3410793426 
âš«As of 17/01/25 - Ubisoft has finally added in achievements (and fixed the achievement issue). They also removed the MP achievements for us achievements hunters that want 100% (due to MP being shut down): https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/220240/view/508443269496046059

[h1][b] Cons [/b][/h1] 
âš«The multiplayer and all online features are now no longer supported for FC3. It's a real shame because it was so fun. I understand though. 
âš«Sadly, Far Cry 3 suffers from major performance issues on modern computers. I crashed about 100 times returning to it in 2025, sadly. I am not sure what causes it, cores? Graphics cards? Cpus? Windows 11 (XD)? Whatever causes this, its never been fixed. Going to quote a friend (WolfPax) - "scroll through the PCGamingWiki and finding 3 pages of unsolved performance issues". Yeah, he was not lying... it's crazy.

[h1][b] Insanity is doing the exact same fu**ing thing over and over again, expecting sh*t to change [/b][/h1] 

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1] 
After all is said and done, Far Cry 3 is a staple of what was once a company to be rivalled with. A masterpiece of a game with villains, characters, combat, exploation, lore... all done to perfection. To see how far Ubi has fallen really makes me sad but that is a different topic.

Far Cry 3 is worth every penny. I would pay double to experience this game again, it's that good. A Villain that will never be forgotten. A stunning tropical archipelago full of history, secrets and killer animals. Characters that you will do anything to protect, or kill and a man twisted, warped into something else to do whatever he can for his loved one. Far Cry 3 is unforgettable.

[h1][b] 10/10 Story. 10/10 Villain. 10/10 Exploration. 2/10 performance. A masterpiece of a game (if you can look past the crashing) [/b][/h1] | Far Cry 3 is a game where youâ€™ll have to survive on a tropical island filled not just with palm trees but also bandits who always seem to know where youâ€™re hiding. Itâ€™s a first-person shooter that combines freedom, a dramatic story, and that constant feeling that the wildlife wants to eat you alive.

The story follows Jason Brody â€” an ordinary guy who suddenly turns into Rambo on steroids. His path to heroism is filled with existential questions like, Who am I? Where am I? And why is that tiger chasing me? Right from the start, the game puts you face-to-face with Vaas, a villain who steals every scene with his charisma. As he himself says, The definition of insanity is trying to play Far Cry 3 without dying every 10 minutes.

The gameplay is a mix of exploration, shooting, hunting, and accidentally setting everything on fire while trying to sneak past enemies. One of the highlights is climbing radio towers to unlock parts of the map. This is the game where Ubisoftâ€™s â€œtower obsessionâ€ was born â€” a tradition of making you scale something tall to unlock the map, which they then proceeded to cram into every game theyâ€™ve made since. At this point, climbing towers in an Ubisoft game feels like an unspoken initiation ritual.

Now with achievements added to the game, itâ€™s a great excuse to replay it and relive those moments: rescuing your friends, meeting Vaas, and seeing how many times you can accidentally blow yourself up with your own Molotov cocktails.

Verdict: Far Cry 3 is a game youâ€™ll want to revisit. Even if itâ€™s just to hear Vaas explain the definition of insanity while you repeatedly fail at stealth. | [h2]Far Cry 3[/h2]

first of all a story that is already very interesting from the beginning and throws you straight into the action..but the thing that surprised me the most is the variety of missions and scripted sequences almost "cinematic" with constant changes of pace and that keep you always active with very few dead moments.
it seems a bit like a mix of many games put together but that makes it extremely fun.
