You fly along quite varied beautiful landscape always forward and avoid obstacles by steering left and right while collecting rings, that can speed you up and slow you down and give bonus points. Thats it. But the execution is very good. You will want to restart often, which becomes more interesting, as the obstacles are placed differently each time and the time of the day and therefore the mood changes. Tight control and a pleasant atmosphere. Somewhat addictive. Give it a try.

Reviews:
Since HoloBall just came out a few days before Cyberpong, I think many people will be wondering what the differences are and if it's worth owning both.

In single player, Cyberpong VR is best described as VR Breakout with a dash of Tetris.  Blocks spawn at the back of the arena and slowly move towards you.  You destroy them with bouncing balls and powerups until a block makes it to your side.  Then the game is over.  There's strategy in how you save and use the powerups, and skill in juggling and aiming the many balls.

The suprise for me was PvP multiplayer, where it plays like VR Pong.  There are no powerups or blocks, just returning the ball back and forth as it becomes faster and faster.  It sounds simple, and it is, but being face to face in VR with your opponent brings so much to the game.  It's an absolute blast.  Shoutout to Shaquille who beat me easily 5 games straight.

Cyberpong will have you moving all around the required play area, but it doesn't push you to swing with the same vigor that HoloBall does.  I've had to take a break for a few days from HoloBall for my arm to recover.  Cyberpong brings my pulse up, but doesn't wear me out.

TL;DR: While Cyberpong VR and HoloBall look similar, they play very differently, and both are great fun.  The online multiplayer in Cyberpong VR is an absolute must try. | My main problem with this game, and it's a huge problem I think, is that it maps the playable area to your chaperone bounds exactly.

Couple that with the tiny size of the paddles, and this means you'll be swinging your Vive controllers - at high speeds - right at the bounds of your chaperone, which is usually where you have walls and floors and furniture and what not. I can't tell you how many times I've hit my controllers against stuff, and how many balls I've missed because I'm too afraid to swing at my chaperone bounds.

I can't believe the developers haven't thought about this. Look at Holoball, which does it right: in Settings, you can set a padding area from your chaperone that basically narrows down your playing field so you're not swinging at the edges. And the paddles are larger in Holoball.
In Cyberpong, the default paddles don't even extrude past the controller. No, for that you have to use an "ability" or select another character with long but extra narrow paddles. Utterly ridiculous.

Beyond that, it's... eh. It's way too claustrophobic. And the balls are slow, and the shape and position of the paddle makes swings awkward. | Nostalgique de Tetris ou de Pong, amateur de casse brique, fan de gros scores, foncÃ© excellent jeux bien prenant bande son rythmÃ© contrÃ´le intuitif. 
Ce jeux est une vrai sÃ©ance de sport garantis !!!! | I'm guessing a lot of people are considering whether to buy this or Holoball.  Well, here're my thoughts as someone who owns both:


**NOTE: The following paragraph no longer applies; the Cyberpong team quickly changed the mechanics of the game to allow for smashing and controling the ball to a much, much greater extent.  You don't have to, but you can speed up the pace of the game quite significantly if you do.

Holoball responds to how you hit the ball more than Cyberpong.  Holoball really is more like raquetball, and if you're looking for that smash-hit feeling, then Holoball is what you want.  For me, smashing it ends up straining my elbow after a short play-time, and I start feeling it there before actually working up a sweat.



Cyberpong is more polished, period.  The powerups, the tetris-meets-breakout singleplayer mode, the various characters that have different paddles (although, let's be real here - the default paddle is the best paddle), all of that just makes for a more fleshed-out game.  I played through Holoball and was done with it after about an hour.  I'm still playing single player Cyberpong trying to best my highest time.

And finally, multiplayer.  I'm reserving my judgement until I see what the Holoball team does, but suffice it to say that this is the main selling point for Cyberpong right now.  It lags a bit, but only the interactions between the ball and the other player.  You never have a problem making contact with the ball (i.e. the ball never lags through your hand or anything).  It's incredibly simple - just barebones pong against another person - but that's all it needs to be.  Facing off against another human being who can wave to you, taunt a bit, sympathize when something crazy happens.  You feel the company, and it's fantastic.

All in all, I'd recommend this over Holoball as of right now. | For VR, this is a great, easy to learn (and play) single or multi-player game that I have really enjoyed, especially when at home and taking a work break from Covid.  It's  like ping pong with colorful cubes and the object is to keep breaking them before they reach the top.  Easy, fun and slightly addictive!
cleaned_review: I'm not sure if it's the same as HoloBall, but it's a lot more fun.

Reviews:
Funky graphics and feel. Tries very hard to be Limbo and take the creepy to the next level, doesn't always succeed. I played OddPlanet before I played Limbo, and ended up playing Limbo just because all the reviews mentioned that it was better. They were right. Whilst Limbo is a few years older it's held up better than OddPlanet has, and was executed with much more finesse.

My big criticism of OddPlanet really comes down to the controls. The jump mechanic is clunky, leading several of the puzzles to be more about getting the timing of your jump absolutely dead set perfect rather than having the challenge be about solving the puzzle itself. It's often a case that you work out what you have to do, but it takes 60 tries to get it right. If I want that I'll go buy a platformer and smash my controller up when I get mad.

If you loved Limbo and are looking for more this is a reasonable substitute, but don't expect it to be as good. | [b]OddPlanet[/b] is a decent little love letter to Limbo that suffers from a stunted playtime and some over-simplified puzzles. 

A girl has no name as she crash-lands on a strange alien world, nor does a girl have much in the way of a defence from its many hostile inhabitants except for cowering in the shadows until danger has passed. There's some great set-pieces here, the best of which involves being captured by the terrifying resident Neanderthal tribe and your subsequent escape from their cave but while much of the art direction and atmospherics are on point, the entire experience sometimes feels overly derivative. There's no real reason for your character to be a copy of the glowing-eyed silhouette boy from Limbo. His anonymity was a major point of that game's story; here, you see the girl's face and hear her voice several times.

A lot of work has gone into [b]OddPlanet[/b] over the past couple of years from its original sole chapter and it arrives on Steam with another two in tow. It's not enough really; there doesn't feel like there's any real resolution at the end of the game which, for an experience that relies heavily on its plot to balance its plain platforming and puzzles, will leave some players feeling a bit short-changed.

Still, I can't really not give this a recommendation based on the complaint that I really wanted to play more of it, can I?

éŸ³ä¹æ–¹é¢ï¼Œè¿™ç§æ¸¸æˆç©èµ·æ¥ç›¸å½“å¤šçš„æ„Ÿè§‰éƒ¨åˆ†æ¥è‡ªäºéŸ³ä¹äº†ï¼Œè¯¥æœ‰çš„ä¹è°ƒéƒ½æœ‰ï¼Œå¸¦å…¥æ„Ÿä¹ŸæŒºå¼ºï¼Œå½“ç„¶ä¸»è¦æ˜¯é‚£ç§å†·å†·æ¸…æ¸…çš„æ­»å¯‚çš„æ„Ÿè§‰ã€‚æ€»ä¹‹ï¼Œå„æ–¹é¢éƒ½ä¸é”™ï¼Œå€¼å¾—ä¸€ç©ï¼Œä½†ä¸è¦æ‹¿å®ƒè·Ÿåœ°ç‹±è¾¹å¢ƒæ¯”ï¼Œæ¯”ä¸äº†çš„ã€‚
åé¢çš„å†…å®¹åœ¨ä¸­å›½çš„ç½‘ç«™ä¸Šä¹Ÿæ²¡å•¥æ”»ç•¥ï¼Œä½†ç¡®å®ä¸éš¾ï¼Œæœ€åç¥å¤§å®¶ç©å¾—æ„‰å¿«~ | I originally played this many moons ago (10 yrs?) way back when it was an app on an iPod. Back then, when it first came out, it was only ever one episode. Slowly over that time it has grown into 3 small episodes and been ported to PC. The developer is really Piotr Krol (Polish I believe?) and believe me when I say this, this is his greatest showcase out of all his current products.

A few moan about the controls not being super responsive at times and that the voice acting seems somewhat out of place, but these gripes seem really in consequential and easy to excuse when you admire the heavily inspired limbo world he has created and the magical score and sound effects that enrich the environment to life. Also believe me, the controls are much worse on the mobile version, plus on the mobile version you get constant advertisements that like to pop up as soon as you try and make a jump.

Story is a little girl who crash lands on an extremely hostile alien world where everything wants to kill you. Living in Australia I can relate to this as everything wants to kill us here too. Like the game we too have giant spiders that are poisonous and about the size of a large dog. Also like the game, if you go out to centre of the outback, you would probably come across some primitive Neanderthals whose only language is throwing rocks at you. As for the swamp filled with frogs it was very reminiscent of the top end of Queensland during flood season. Cane toads everywhere on the roads that make a popping sound under tyres like bubble wrap which can be quite addictive. 

Here I am thinking she has landed on an alien world. Struth never did I realise she's probably in my backyard. Loneliness definitely gets to you out here in the 'never, never', while she made a short connection with an opossum/cat looking creature and constantly writes in her journal, itâ€™s just not the same as having a deep and meaningful with a bottle of beer and saying amen to a porcelain bowl. Not that she's probably old enough to drink, on the other hand it would perfectly explain her parking skills. Pffft women drivers (roll eyes) ...

Game abruptly ends with the girl closing her eyes while resting against a tree, probably her final thought being that there are good squish noises (spiders) and there are bad squish noises (you). In any case, Australia has trees that kill people too. Undoubtedly Piotr Krol is warning everyone, 'Visit Australia if you plan to die on an odd planet'...

https://youtu.be/vf4XXMw6P5E

If you enjoyed reading this review feel free to subscribe to my curator page. Thanks...

cleaned_review: 'OddPlanet' is a decent little love letter to Limbo, but it's not enough.

Reviews:
This game is my Roman empire.  It haunts me.  The 8 hours I have in this game (as of writing) tell nothing of the amount of time I spend [i]thinking[/i] about this game.  I wish that there was a way to give a mixed review instead of solely positive or negative, but I'm rating this game positively just because of the amount of space it occupies in my brain.

The first time I beat it all the way through, I got the bad ending because it honestly is one of the most frustrating gameplay experiences I've ever encountered, and I was trying to fly through it as quickly as possible.  It has bad controls and no direction, and it's buggy as all hell.  There were times when my game would just [i]not load the items necessary for progression[/i], completely soft-locking me in some cases.  Like one of the earlier chapters of the game has you looking for a bucket to use on the well, but in my game, the bucket just didn't spawn in either of the locations it was supposed to.  Later, I needed a gas canister, and [i]that[/i] didn't spawn, either.  The few shooting sections in the game are also just abysmal and don't work.  I really enjoy the game as an atmospheric post-apocalyptic walking simulator, and the few points where it deviated away from walking simulator territory fell extremely flat because of the janky controls.

However, this game's story and characters take up so much of my heart and mind, and I don't know why.  Just walking along with the nameless companion and taking pictures of both him and the world fills me with such inexplicable warmth.  Even though the game does not contain that much dialogue, the dynamic between the two main characters is something I keep coming back to.  Maybe it's because of what I imagine for them while playing; maybe I am imposing something on the game that's not actually there.  But like I said, I got the bad ending first, [spoiler]and you lose your companion, and when I woke up in the metro station without him by my side, I cried.[/spoiler]  I'm currently working on getting the "Continue to live...?" ending, where you keep your companion with you because... I don't know.  There's something deep inside me that cannot rest until I finish the game with both main characters together and alive.

This is extremely subjective, rambling nonsense about... [vague hand-wave] the ability for even art that is not objectively "good" to get its claws inside of someone and move them in signifcant ways.

TL;DR: Do I like this game?  Yes, and I will probably keep revisiting it every small handful of years to reimmerse myself in the world and everything.  And between playthroughs, I will continue to not shut up about it to anyone who will listen.
Can I actually [i]recommend[/i] this game?  Well... in a word: no.  I am well aware that I am kind of a weird guy and that it's incredibly unlikely that this little indie project will do for anyone else what it has done for me.  And without that deep, personal attachment to it, the bugginess and jank is [i]really[/i] not worth sitting through.  The act of actually playing this game consistently makes me wish I liked it a little less so that I wouldn't be compelled to keep revisiting it.

But if you're a masochist for bad controls and getting soft-locked out of progression, or you just wanna try and figure out what the hell I'm on about (buddy, not even I know...), go for it. | Ğ”Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞµĞ» Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ² 35ĞœĞœ, Ğ½Ğ¾ ĞºĞ°Ğº-Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ñ€ÑƒĞºĞ¸ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ´Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸. cleaned_review: I'm not sure what the game's story is about, but it's a very good game.

Reviews:
This has to be one of the worst AI's I've seen in a long time (!)

Cheating AI to compensate for being bit dumb is common practice in RTS games, but apparently the devs think that their AI is stupid beyond any redemption so they juiced all the cheating levers to the moon and the only thing that remains is artificial difficulty in the most boring and tedious way.

Raiding/attacking an AI is absolutely pointless unless you can actually destroy their main base. They're barely relying on population for their production and any villagers/military units you kill respawn almost instantly anyway so it's absolutely pointless to raid them.

The issue seemed a bit less apparent during the Campaign, so at least that part was bit better balanced. But trying out Conquest mode afterwards is just absolutely disgusting. It's doable, but an absolute drag cause it requires constant micromanagement to barely compensate for all the AI cheating. And even then it takes so long to finish off an opponent because raiding an AI does barely anything, so unless you're way way stronger the AI will just bounce back in the blink of an eye.

Bit of cheating would be fine, but I mean the AI units literally respawn like 2-3+ times faster, and their armies have barely any upkeep so it doesn't matter if you destroy their economy cause they will just field an army of 15+ units without any economy supporting them anyway. It's just a joke imo, this is not an actual challenge.

Please put some actual thought and at least a little bit of effort into your AI so the cheating doesn't have to be so blatantly in your face. 

It's a shame, cause the base game mechanics are interesting enough, the game looks nice visually and has a good theme. Reviews:
Probado en Oculus Rift CV1

Nvidia Fun House es basicamente una demo tÃ©cnica de Nvidia (como tantas otras que tiene) pero para VR. La aplicaciÃ³n tiene unos requisitos mÃ­nimos muy altos, ya que los graficos en "low" requieren una GTX 1060, en medium una 1080, y en high dos 1080 en SLI.

Dejando de lado los requisitos mÃ­nimos tan altos, es un buen ejemplo de la versatilidad de la Realidad Virtual. Que nadie se espere una historia ni exploraciÃ³n ni nada del estilo, es sÃ³lo un conjunto de minijuegos, eso sÃ­, con un derroche tÃ©cnico: fuego volumÃ©tico, sistemas de partÃ­culas complejos, simulaciÃ³n de pelo, etc.

Tiene una buena respuesta a los Touch Controllers, especialmente con las espadas, con pequeÃ±as vibraciones y efectos realistas cuando se tocan, y las fÃ­sicas y demÃ¡s efectos relacionados con la interacciÃ³n del jugador son muy buenos y fluidos... si tienes un buen PC, claro.

Sinceramente creo que Nvidia deberÃ­a haber abierto mÃ¡s el espectro de requisitos mÃ­nimos para abarcar tarjetas grÃ¡ficas mÃ¡s modestas (repetimos que los requisitos mÃ­nimos estÃ¡n por encima de los que pedÃ­a Oculus al principio (y eso que luego se bajaron del carro)) ya que esta demo sÃ³lo servirÃ¡ a aquellos con buenas tarjetas grÃ¡ficas, o tarjetas en SLi que quieran ver todo tipo de shaders y efectos brutales muy de cerca en RV. | Not anywhere near the depth of The Lab, but for a free game, still pretty fun.  It's basically a mini tech demo, but the games are rewarding and feel balanced, and everything certainly looks beautiful.  I don't know if it's something I'll come back to on a regular basis, but I'm glad I tried it and I certainly recommend giving it a full playthrough at least once.  I suspect it would be a good first game for VR newbies as well... oh, and the credits are good for a laugh, too. â˜ºï¸ï¸ | LÃ¤uft sehr flÃ¼ssig mit GTX 1060 mit PiMax 4K VR, jedoch ist das ganze ziemlich witzlos ohne Bewegungscontroller, Steuerung funktioniert zwar mit Tastatus und/oder XBox One Controller, jedoch hatte ich keine Kontrolle Ã¼ber die Handbewegung, lediglich mit Farbe auf Clowns schiessen war somit problemlos. Alles in allem aber ganz nett anzusehen, auch wenn Verbesserungsbedarf besteht; Handkontrolle per Maus wÃ¤re nett gewesen. | One of the best VR experiences to try, which is great considering it is free. Any time I have introduced someone to VR, I had them play this game. The games are very simple to learn but so much fun. They give you a nice idea of what VR has to offer and what your new headset is capable of. You should definitely try this if you own a VR headset. | Free game for Nvidia owners. Pretty fun basic games good intro to VR. Great graphics great physics.
cleaned_review: Nvidia Fun House is a good example of the versatility of Virtual Reality.

Reviews: Evolution can be a fun game if you have a plan in mind, but a pain for the inexperienced. As long as you keep your wits and tread carefully, you should be able to complete the campaign without much challenge. Would recommend this game, but only if you know what you're doing
cleaned_review: This game is a bit slow, but it's fun.

Reviews:
Destinations is probably the most immersive VR experience to date.  It allows to  walk into carefully-reconstructed actual locations (plus a few fantasy places thrown in for variety). Most scenes are not interactive, and the areas you can move through are relatively restrictedn but the sens of actually being there, whether it's in an old church graveyard or on the surface of Mars, is unmatched. Very impressive ! 

It's made even better by the user-created scenes that prolong the experience's duration. | Tolle Erfahrung und das Konzept, welches dahinter steckt, lÃ¤sst auf mehr hoffen. Je mehr Leute daran teilnehmen und auch eigene Inahlte beisteuern, um so lebhafter wird es. Ich bin auf die Zukunft gespannt....

Reviews:
O.k, I was gonna rant about something related to my theories on life, but this really is an Experience that 'has', 'just now' (yes, just 'right now') opened up dimensions in comic book storytelling. O.k, now, I will rant

The 'Experience' just opened a whole new ways comics can be appreciated.  Walk-in comics, animation, 'no' animation, voice acting, floating lettered bubbles, take your pick.  Eternal Frozen-Freaking Moments.  It's gotta be done, can someone please fling a sheep's bollock at Allan Moore and get him to come out of comic-writing retirement, and his daughter Leah to get some Electricomics happening with Steelehouse.

http://pipedreamcomics.co.uk/and-the-winner-of-digital-comic-app-of-the-year-is/

http://steelehouse.com/

Someone please get a SteamVR version happening.  Thank you Rexodus and Steelehouse, for opening up another dimension. | Are you ready for camp? No, you don't have to pack your sleeping bag and mosquito spray, this is bringing the camp to you!

Dinosaurs in space with giant guns and swords vs generic black goo alien energy thing. Hosted by what appears to be a slightly taller Vanellope von Schweetz. The dialog is... campy, the jokes are... also campy. The entire premise is campy, but if you're okay with camp, it's actually pretty solid. The VR is used in a way that really emphasize the scale of the characters and how that sense of presence comes across to the normal sized person that you are.

All said, it seems to mostly just be an advertisement for a comic book series, which looks even campier from the previews they offer, and it seems to just be a passive experience, despite pretending otherwise, but everything is polished well enough to be worth at least checking out to see what they do.
cleaned_review: The 'Experience' just opened a whole new ways comics can be appreciated. Walk-in comics, animation, 'no' animation, voice acting, floating lettered bubbles, take your pick. Eternal Frozen-Freaking Moments. It's gotta be done, can someone please fling a sheep's bollock at Allan Moore and get him to come out of comic-writing retirement, and his daughter Leah to get some Electricomics happening with Steelehouse.

Reviews:
I finally decided to leave a review of this game after seeing the AMA on Reddit, because I want to support these guys any way I can. Everything about this game makes you happy. Everyone's always smiling (because your character can only smile), other players are extremely friendly (its totally normal for people to compliment you or congratulate you if you hit them in paintball), and the devs are just as feel-good as the game itself. They are extremely responsive to the community and really have a way of making everyone feel special. I sent Against Gravity an email recently, and the response I got came back less than six hours later not from some intern, but from the CEO. And in the AMA, when someone asked how they could support the company financially, the response was to instead to make a donation to charity and to "tell 'em coach sent ya". They're small gestures, but it really shows that they care.


In a world where it seems like we are constantly being bombarded with negativity, and where everyone is divided, this game is like a haven of positivity. Es una experiencia social en la que puedes personalizar a tu avatar con distintos trajes, peinados y complementos y luego salir a un hall donde encontrarÃ¡s a un montÃ³n de gente con la que charlar, interactuar y jugar a diferentes juegos.

En RecRoom tenemos una variedad de juegos para elegir, para jugar con amigos o con gente que encontremos conectada en ese momento, todos ambientados en un ambiente estudiantil, tipo instituto o High School, pero de todos ellos para mi gusto los que se llevan la palma son el PaintBall y el Quest for the Golden Trophy recientemente aÃ±adido. El primero es, como su nombre indica, un juego de paintball por equipos con varios modos de juego (combate por equipos, capturar la bandera...) y diferentes armas (pistola, escopeta, granadas, rifle de francotirador) todas de pintura. Es extremadamente divertido.
El Quest for the Golden Trophy es un juego parecido a una mazmorra de un rpg, cooperativo hasta 4 jugadores, en el que armados con espadas, escudos y arcos ( y mÃ¡s adelante tambiÃ©n podremos encontrar una ballesta y no se si despuÃ©s habrÃ¡ algo mÃ¡s) tendremos que adentrarnos en una mazmorra con un estilo grafico que simula los pasillos y estancias de un instituto decorados para simular una mazmorra, todo muy original. Jugar con otros 3 amigos me recordÃ³ fuertemente a las sensaciones de jugar una raid en juegos como WoW (salvando las distancias). Aqui es todo mÃ¡s casual, y no hay clases ni roles  y las mecÃ¡nicas son mucho mÃ¡s simples, pero sustituimos la necesidad de una rotaciÃ³n de habilidades optimizada y habilidad con los dedos por habilidad para movernos nosotros mismos, agacharnos, esquivar, apuntar, ser rÃ¡pidos en resucitar a un compaÃ±ero caido (chocando las manos) para que pueda volver al combate, interponer nuestro escudo delante de un compaÃ±ero para protegerlo de un disparo de un enemigo, y cosas asÃ­. Me ha parecido que, siendo aun un juego sencillo, sienta muy muy bien las bases de lo que podrÃ­an ser futuros mmorpgs y marca el camino a seguir.

Todos los juegos se pueden jugar en abierto, con la gente que haya conectada, o en salas privadas donde podemos invitar a nuestros amigos. Incluso hay una sala social en la que se pueden hacer cosas como jugar una partida de pÃ³ker o de dados.

Y ademÃ¡s de todo ES GRATIS!!!! no se puede pedir mÃ¡s. Si teneis Oculus con touch o HTC Vive, no se a que estais esperando para probarlo!!!

7/10 | absolver is a complex, pvp-oriented, martial-arts inspired fighting game that died on arrival because most gamers are stupid. they do not seek challenge or player expression. when a game gives you roadblocks, they don't play it. when a game gives you options, they look up meta builds. absolver allows you to create your own fighting style by putting together different attacks in order to form combos. the game features a stance system, offering right-front, left-front, right-rear and left-rear facing positions from which you can initiate attacks, and many attacks will end in a stance that is different from the initial one. the combat is a masterclass in player expression. being able to combine different motions in order to create your own fighting style is about as close as it gets to complete freedom in combat while remaining in static animation territory (physics are hard to get right).

players get a wide array of clothing and armour to choose from, allowing for an astronomical number of combinations thanks to absolver's nine equipment slots (head, elbow, shoulder, inner top, outer top, hand, waist, leg and foot). lots of asymmetrical pieces, pleasant colours and often loose-fitting clothes make this game's fashion style stand out.

absolver has a beautiful watercolour-like art style, depicting old structures that have seen better days, calm forest paths, massive temples and highly refined, decorated and gilded environments. sadly, there's little to explore, but what is there is dense in detail and looks amazing.

all of the environments feature detailed soundscapes, from birds singing to machinery moving, from wood creaking to cave ceilings dripping. the environmental soundscapes are complemented by the game's minimalist original soundtrack, featuring lots of different string instruments, blending flamenco, arabic and indian sounding melodies, a few woodwinds, bells and chimes and some nice percussive rhythms to match the rhythm of fights. a final note on the audio side of things, fights sound great. the impact sounds for punches and bashing weapons are heavy. the cutting sounds for swords are okay. these are sort of hard to get right because blades don't make much noise as they cut through flesh, except for when they hit a bone, so knowing how difficult it is to represent cutting sounds, i'll give them a pass.

heavy recommend.
cleaned_review: Absolver is a game that is a great way to learn the art of the game, and also to enjoy the limits of the game.

Reviews:
This is a game where you throw balls at round enemy robots who are trying to shoot you and you can teleport to a series of cubes (the internet is not a big truck... it's a series of cubes!) and depending on where you teleport, you're standing on a different cube face facing a different direction.  It's all very disorienting and kinda disturbing.

I only played the easiest mode (yeah yeah, call me a wimp if you must) where you don't have to throw the balls, you just aim in the direction and fire and it goes that way.  I did OK, but I found that I really had to keep teleporting or I got killed.

Speaking of that, when you die, you only had the one life so that's it.  Then a creepy robotic voice says "you died! Game over man" or "they killed you!"  "You got shot!" or some other line. I guess it's amusing...sorta.

The graphics are really basic.  Cubes to land on and stand on, some spacy looking background, round enemy robots that don't move, they just teleport in and eventually locate you and shoot. Oh and it seems the cubes can be destroyed so that means eventually if you survived for long enough, the places to run to might dwindle to nothing.

 It seemed to me that this game was probably made very low budget.  I didn't find the music that memorable, the gameplay was kinda flat and repetitive (but to be fair I was playing the simplest mode where there are no powerups) and I kinda lost interest quickly.

Things I liked about this game:
[list]
 [*] I guess it could be like a big shootout, and maybe with the powerups it'll be cool.  I only barely played it so I might not have seen the best it can give.
 [/list]

Things I didn't like about this game:
 [list]
 [*] Nothing really grabbed me about this game.  I'll try it again and see if I change my mind.
 [/list]

Right now, the verdict is still out, but I would say pass on this game based off of what I saw for that short time period.  I'll give it a few more runs and see how much my opinion changes.  If I go from "Ugh" to "meh" or even "I Love it!" I'll come back and update this.  
 | It looks like a game made in one day.
I know the game is cheap but come on, it doesn't worth 3â‚¬.

The voice is anoying, the gravity is anoying, everything is anoying ... Even the positive reviews looks fake. No, it's not a "top 5" game. It's not fun at all.
 | I love this game!! For how much fun this is I cant believe how cheap the game is. This game is a mental and physical workout and your constantly dodging enemy fire. I love how you move around and how gravity plays a factor. I have to add, make sure your wrist straps are secure with this game. This game involves a lot of throwing motions so lets just say your controllers get sweaty and are way harder to grip. I can definitely picture people accidentally throwing their vive controllers with this game. | YESSSSS, thank you so much... I AM SWEATING, fianallly I AM SWEATING ! ! !
The first VR game that achieved that!

The game is fun, thrilling and challenging. Actually for me in the TOP 5
of VR games you can get on steam! Finally sth. worth to play in VR.
It would not make sense in 2D, not in 3D and not seated.

btw. ... You should stripe your HMD as thight as possible :D

Excellent, but be warned: it is highly addictive! Aw man, I loved this game!!! The fave color at the first play set up was awesome. I picked blue! The gameplay was awesome! The best part was the use of the Steam Workshop and how you could share puzzles you make in the editor to the workshop! This game is the best! Wait, what was this game about again? | Human Fall Flat is a unique game that combines puzzle and comedy elements. The game offers players to control a clumsy character who must overcome various obstacles and puzzles in surreal levels.

One of the main advantages of the game is its humor. The control of the character is very awkward and naughty, which leads to a lot of funny situations and falls. This makes the game very fun and relaxing.

The puzzles in the game are also very well designed. They require the player's problem-solving skills and creative thinking to overcome the obstacles. However, they are not too difficult, which makes the game accessible to players of any level.

The graphics in the game are also noteworthy. The levels are very colorful and surreal, which creates a unique and memorable atmosphere.

Overall, Human Fall Flat is a great game for those looking for something new and fun. It offers the perfect balance between humor and puzzles, as well as unique graphics and atmosphere. Reviews:
Dead Island Definitive Edition

Ich kann es kurz machen, denn das Meiste kann man hier Ã¼berall nachlesen. Ich werde es zwar positiv bewerten, weil es durchaus SpaÃŸ macht und nie unfair ist - jedenfalls bis jetzt - ABER es gibt einige Dinge, die mir auf die Nerven gehen und zwei davon ganz besonders:

1. Das vÃ¶llig Ã¼berflÃ¼ssige Kopfgewackel, das beim schnellen Laufen sogar noch eins drauf setzt und mein kÃ¶rperliches Wohlbefinden auf eine verdammt harte Probe stellt - Stichwort 'Motion-Sickness' - und das sich im MenÃ¼ NICHT abschalten lÃ¤sst. Menschen, die darunter leiden, sollten die Finger von dem Game lassen.

2. Ich habe in meiner kurzen Spielzeit einige Errungenschaften freigeschaltet (nicht mitgezÃ¤hlt wie viele) aber es waren mehr als drei oder vier. Angezeigt wird hier nur Eine. Das nervt. Mir ist alleine deshalb schon die Lust am Weiterspielen vergangen, weil ich da eigentlich mit 100% durch wollte.

Technisch ist es ansonsten OK, es lÃ¤uft flÃ¼ssig, die Steuerung ist etwas zu trÃ¤ge fÃ¼r meinen Geschmack und manchmal geht ein FuÃŸtritt mitten durch, ohne Schaden anzurichten, weil man einfach zu dicht am Gegner steht. Ecken und Winkel, die man gerade noch befreit hatte, damit man keine Gegner im RÃ¼cken hat und man sich mit dem Haufen vor einem in Ruhe beschÃ¤ftigen kann - kÃ¶nnt ihr nicht immer aber oft vergessen, weil die spawnen trotzdem aus heiterem Himmel direkt hinter euch, wo gerade noch alles leer und "gesÃ¤ubert" war. Keine Ahnung, wo die dann plÃ¶tzlich herkommen aber anscheinend direkt aus dem Nirvana... Ziemlich bekloppt.

Spielerisch ist es aufgrund mangelnder Abwechslung und gewisser EintÃ¶nigkeit mit 'Dying Light' (1) vergleichbar, und bitte - ich weiÃŸ, dass die Fan-Gemeinde fÃ¼r den ersten Teil extrem groÃŸ ist und ihr jetzt bei dieser Bemerkung Schnappatmung bekommt - aber es hat keinen Zweck, mir den Kopf abzubeiÃŸen, denn mir hat der erste Teil trotzdem nicht annÃ¤hernd so gut gefallen, wie der Zweite. Das sieht eben jeder/jede anders.

Wenn ihr wirklich ein Zombie-Spiel haben wollt, wo alles passt, dann solltet ihr euch mal 'Dying Light 2' wenigstens mal ansehn, das Studio ist das Selbe. Das ist um LÃ¤ngen besser als das hier und sehr viel interessanter. Dort wurde eigentlich an alles gedacht, was ich hier vermisse. MenÃ¼einstellungen - ALLES da, Steuerung perfekt und direkt, Story - ist gut und gar nicht mal so Ã¼bel, gute und anspruchsvolle Nebenquests (die Meisten jedenfalls), Adrenalin pur und richtig gutes Gameplay mit guter Optik.

Ich werde das hier jetzt erstmal wieder deinstallieren, denn trotz einigem SpielspaÃŸ schafft 'Dead Island Definitive Edition' es nicht, mich mitzunehmen.

Ğ¢Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğµ ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ»Ñ‹ Ğ² Ñ‚ĞµĞºÑÑ‚ÑƒÑ€Ñ‹,Ğ·Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµĞ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ² Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ğ°Ñ…,ÑĞ¼ĞµÑ€Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾, Ğ¸ Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ»ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹ Ğ¸Ğ· Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹. | Pros:
- Visual Improvements: The game has received a significant graphical upgrade, with enhanced textures, environmental objects, and lighting effects that make the world feel more immersive.

- Content: The Definitive Edition includes both Dead Island and Dead Island: Riptide, along with all the DLC, offering a lot of content for players.

- Quality of Life Improvements: The game features several quality-of-life improvements, such as better inventory management and additional gameplay tweaks that make the experience smoother.

Cons:
- Performance Issues: Despite the visual improvements, the game still struggles with performance, particularly with frame rate drops and occasional bugs.

- Outdated Mechanics: Some of the core gameplay mechanics feel dated and repetitive, which might not appeal to everyone.

- Mixed Reactions to Changes: While many improvements were made, some changes, like altered weapon models and textures, have received mixed feedback from players who were nostalgic about the original versions.

Overall, Dead Island: Definitive Edition offers a lot of content and visual enhancements, but it still has some performance and gameplay issues that might not be for everyone.

ĞœÑƒÑĞ¾Ñ€. | This game is absolutely dated. It's a product of its' time for better or for worse. If you can get behind some 360 era jank then give this game a go. I remember trying it back in the day and not vibing with it. Now that I'm a bit older, I really like what this game has done. In a time when everything was so heavily focused on guns it makes guns practically useless. The melee has a lot of weight to it that not many games from the time did. There are certainly aspects I wish were improved but taking everything at face value I have to say this is a fairly unique experience. I would imagine with a full party of four that this game would be a real blast.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure if I'm comparing it to the original, but I'm not sure if it's a good thing or not.

Reviews:
One of the best free VR experiences out there. Essentially a house-sized moving art piece. I highly recommend grabbing a wooden chair, setting it up where one of the chairs are in the virtual space, taking a seat and enjoying the views (once you're done exploring everywhere). It's incredibly immersive and relaxing.

I just wish it had cost a couple bucks so I could support the developers. Thanks for the awesome content! I'll be keeping an eye on all your future projects. | One of the prettiest experiences in VR.
cleaned_review: Awesome VR experience.

Reviews:
Download the demo, it's free and has all the game mechanics in it. You don't gain anything by picking up the early access game which has seen no attention from the dev shortly after it went live. Look at the "eary access game" notes from the developer written in June of 2016 and feel free to browse the trello board ( http://trello.com/b/oOCNIEaS ) listing the tasks he was planning on but never got around to:

Approximately how long will this game be in Early Access?
â€œThe game will be in Early Access for at least a month, until it has proper assets (sound, graphics), as well as more content.



It's a shame I can't recommend this game; it missed all of its early access milestones. It seems the developer had great ideas to make the game more fun. | This is my favorite VIVE game so far (I have about 25). Just be prepared for a true workout as you get better at it. Tonight I made it to wave 26 and was sweating like no other! 

This is truely a mix of Tron discs and Captain America's shield. At about level 15 it starts getting really intense with dodging, shields up, spinning around and throwing your shield. 

I will say that the controls when launching the disc still don't feel absolute. About 80% of the time I hit my target but there are times when you KNOW you launched correctly and the disc didn't do what you want. Kind of like Wii or Move controllers. When this gets fixed, I will be in heaven.

I am really looking forward to where this game goes next! BRAVO!!!! | If you have a VR, I would recommend this game if you're into action games or ones where you have to survive in a arena for as long as you can. I think it is still in early access and Idk what the future update will look like but so far its a fun game. A Game where you're main weapon is a shield plate you can throw at enemy drones that tries to eliminate you as well as you can deflect their laser projectiles or reflect it back at them. Overall a good game with only 1 problem. A VR positioning issue that is weird to fix but always happens whenever you start the game. | As it is very early access I'll keep this light. I enjoyed playing it as is for now and already we are getting frequent updates from the developer. Well worth it for under a fiver.

UPDATED:  It's been 4 months since any word from the developer despite requests from users in the discussion forums.  This is simply part of the 'great VR cash grab' of 2016.  Avoid and lets not reward this behavior! | edit* No updates to the game in over a year.  I think he abandonned this game.  Fun , but might not be worth $5 now as there is no reason to go back to it after you got a high score or two.  Online leaderboards aren't shown in the game itself , you have look at them here --> http://steamcommunity.com/app/488150/discussions/0/351659808497694953/ *

This game is a hell of a workout :)  Starts of relatively slow , but come wave 25 or so and it's just pure madness.

In this game you throw a shield using either your left or right hand at small flying robots that shoot back at you if you don't clear them quick enough.  You are able to reflect the shots back at them with your shield.  Every shield throw and reflect has to be absolutely perfect if you want to hit something , which can be a little frustrating at times , but sure is a great challenge that I'm sure I'll get better at the more I play.   

Overall great intense game that gets the blood flowing quickly.

cleaned_review: I'm a big fan of this place. It's a great place to play ping pong.

Reviews:
I feel like this game should have been marked as "Early Access".  There's a lot of potential here and some pretty creative ideas, but it has a definite "work in progress" feeling to it.  

Only a handful of classes and some of those marked as experimental.  
Combat is primarily melee with no magic avaiable.  
User interface and keybinds feel clunky.
Game does not flow well (e.g. needing to talk to NPCs in the beginning gets very repetitive in a game where you're expected to die and start over frequently).

I'm not going to refund it, though.  This could turn out to be a very good game, and I want to support the dev.  However, I wouldn't recommend buying it unless you accept there's a lot of work that still needs to be done. | This game is a lot of fun as long as it caters to the kind of roguelikes you prefer playing. What I mean is that this game, while being very strategic with currency, elemental resists, attack stances, etc., some people looking for, say, another ADOM or ToME might be dissapointed with a lack of variety in equipment and attack methods (i.e. you will be in melee 90% of the time; there appears to be no spells in the game aside from wands at the moment). Classical roguelike elements like cursing and identification exists, and this game features a corruption system that is somewhat similar to ADOM's (albeit a lot nastier and dangerous in this game). 

Currently there are 5 classes (3 of which are locked for hard and higher difficulties) and they are generally pretty unique and interesting. For instance, you can play as a spirit that can't use items or talk to NPC's but possesses the ability to possess and completely control a monster that's close to death. Gameplay and strategy appear to be largely tied to the classes and their playstyles at the moment, so I suggest doing some reading (or better yet, watch a video) in order to determine if this game sounds like it'd be fun to play.

Overall I'm very pleased this is an actual roguelike with strategic depth, and not a twin-stick shooter "roguelike" the genre has been flooded with in recent years. I Recommend this to anyone interested in the former, as it has a lot of potential, in my opinion. More classes and more variety in consumables would be a good start for the game to improve, I think. | Ğ’Ğ¾ÑĞµĞ¼ÑŒ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑĞ¾Ğ². Ğ£Ğ¶Ğµ ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ‹Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğº. Sadly it does not, so I'm going to have to say this game is a pass, even with it's neat concepts.

The fact the writing and score make a text-based story compelling and chilling enough to keep me glued to my seat shows how well written this game is. | Allora, innanzitutto va detto che il gioco Ã¨ solamente testuale (molta roba da leggere, sia utile a stabilire un "ambiente" realistico, sia informazioni) perciÃ² non aspettatevi azione nel senso classico, piuttosto aspettatevi di indagare...e riflettere, anche se sul secondo punto sono abbastanza confuso.
C'Ã¨ poco da aggiungere al titolo, Orwell cita ovviamente l'autore di 1984 dove in una societÃ  distopica, le persone sono costantemente spiate per il bene di una nazione in cui non esiste alcuna opposizione.
Orwell Ã¨ la piattaforma che andremo ad utilizzare, "l'occhio" del governo che attraverso indiscriminate ricerche e libere estrapolazioni di dati da social media, account bancari, cellulari, computer, dati medici e via dicendo sarÃ  nostro compito assicurare alcuni "terroristi" (se lo siano o meno Ã¨ vostro compito scoprirlo, e qui un altro problema che sorge) alla giustizia.
Qual'Ã¨ il confine se esiste fra privacy e sicurezza? Ci abbiamo giÃ  rinunciato entrando nei social media e dando le nostre informazioni a qualsiasi sito le chieda? Paranoia o realtÃ ? Se non abbiamo nulla da nascondere, cosa ci importa? 
Ma quali sono i criteri per esseri considerati "un pericolo"? Magari si comincia con cose serie ma poi si arriva al conformismo totale sospettoso di qualsiasi differenza?
Queste solo alcune delle domande che il gioco pone, forse in maniera un pÃ² "guidata" (alla fine la libertÃ  di pensiero significa che il pensiero non deve essere influenzato) in certe parti, ma se all'inizio puÃ² sembrare avvincente indagare e collegare punti fra i vari indizi che prenderemo senza troppi scrupoli con qualche click da diversi metodi....alla fine rimarrÃ  un pÃ² di amarezza.
PerchÃ¨ ...se capitasse veramente a voi? Mettiamo sia tutto complottismo e paranoia, ma se potesse accadere?
Non siamo poi cosÃ¬ lontani, e le notizie del gioco rimandano a fatti reali ovviamente con nomi e tempi diversi.
Lo consiglio, non dura molto, si finisce in 7 ore, Ã¨ completamente tradotto, ci sono delle piccole sbavature (soprattutto confusione fra gender o nomi di persone, o frasi tradotte troppo letteralmente dall'inglese)
Non credo comprerÃ² il seguito, totalmente in inglese e che a quanto ho letto non Ã¨ pari a questo.
Non mi ha "sbalordito" enormemente, ma fa pensare sia in termini di soluzione di alcuni "enigmi" che di temi etici.
Molto pratica la UI e piacevole l'utilizzo di ritratti disegnati in modo molto minimal.
Consigliato a chi ama i giochi di scelte e conseguenze che poi scopri che era tutto un equivoco.

I love roguelike card games, but I feel like I should have listened to the negative reviews with this one.

The mechanics are all quite cool, but for me the entire design falls apart on one fatal flaw. I usually play these kind of games to do some quick up to one hour long runs in the evening. However, with this one, two evenings in a row, the runs ended up in a lengthy slog that almost lasted past midnight. And the worst thing was that the gameplay did not even change very much during those 2+ hr long runs, I just eventually felt like I was doing the same thing over and over again. The resulting boredom and loss of concentration (which is highly required ALL the time or you will lose fast) made me perform worse, so I did not even win in the end.

Idk, it just feels like it is a game for a different, more slow-paced era than this one. There are just so many more interesting games of the same genre, that spending 50+ hours to unlock most the different content of this one seems highly unlikely for most gamers imo.

Game Name: The Thrill of the Fight - VR Boxing
Reviews:
W game the graphics are better in game than it looks in video. | Something about having even the appearance of someone throwing a punch at you that raises your heart rate.  I find this is one of the better boxing simulators.
 | 9 years after release and this game has such realistic mechanics for VR boxing its a great cardio and even builds muscle as I got sore after playing consistently at first. Play at very small intervals to start 5-15min take frequent breaks as it can definitely knock the breath out of you. 10/10 | This game is old, but remains the best VR boxing game so far. | Thrill of the Fight is VR boxing at its absolute finestâ€”no fluff, no gimmicks, just raw, sweaty, heart-pounding action. This game doesnâ€™t hold your hand; it throws you straight into the ring and dares you to survive.

The realism is insane. Every punch you throw, every block, and every dodge feels legit, like youâ€™re really in there trading blows. The physics are on point, making you work for every victory. Forget button-mashingâ€”this is about skill, stamina, and strategy. If youâ€™re not drenched in sweat by the end of a match, youâ€™re not doing it right.

What really stands out is the simplicity. Thereâ€™s no over-the-top flashâ€”just you, your opponent, and the fight. The intensity is addictive, and every victory feels earned. Itâ€™s perfect for fitness junkies, boxing enthusiasts, or anyone who just wants to throw hands in VR without pulling punches.

Bottom line? Thrill of the Fight is brutal, authentic, and ridiculously satisfying. If youâ€™re looking for a VR experience thatâ€™ll leave you sore and grinning, this oneâ€™s a knockout.
cleaned_review: Thrill of the Fight is a brutal, authentic, and ridiculously satisfying VR experience.

Genres: Casual, Free To Play, Simulation, Early Access
Reviews:
Some nice sounds and they create some cool loops.

Overall this seems like it has a lot of potential but I've been running into a variety of issues I hope will be resolved in future updates I will list all of them here.

1) I can't seem to control where the different effects get inserted into the sound loops the program chooses for me
2) I can't choose which sound to create, I have to just create a bunch until the one I want appears
3) I can't make separate loops everything goes into a single loop, this makes it hard to properly create a custom soundscape / music etc
4) I can't tune the speed at which the loop goes through the nodes

If anyone knows how to do these things I'd really like to know, or if the devs intend to add this functionality at a later date.

In conclusion, fun toy, with great potential, but currently not a lot of depth. But hey it's free and for that price it's pretty cool already. I've spent about 10 minutes on this game thus far, and so far I seem to be liking it. I appreiciate how different it is from all the other VR titles; I personally don't know any other game that let's you create your own tune in VR! I'll update this when I have a chance to play more. But overall, I recommend this, as it's creative and unique in it's own right. ANÃLISE DE ACESSO ANTECIPADO PUBLICADA: 4 DE SETEMBRO DE 2016
Fun free music experience. The 7.1, I think, is used great. You create different music crystals with the trigger finger, make them come into contact with each other, they start creating a beat already chosen by the game, then you can grab them and throw them in any direction to make that sound come from that direction. Then pull out more crystals and do the same thing. If you don't like the sound of one of them, you can pop them by stabbing them with your controller. There aren't too many different sounds created, hopefully that will expand. It does seem like the same song can be recreated. What I had fun with is just using 1 or maybe a small dose of a second crystal and placing the crystals like they are the instrument. For example, there was one sound that sounded like someone humming something briefly, and another sound that sounded like someone snapping their fingers. So I placed the crystals where a persons mouth would be for humming and a persons hands would be for snapping. Then the drum sounds I placed behind me where a drum set often is located on stage. I put water droplet sounds on the floor. I enjoyed it and since its free, nothing but thumbs up!
 | A simple and very enjoyable way to play with music in a virtual space. No music skills or experience are needed to enjoy playing with PolyDome. I really hope that the developer continues to update it, I'd definitely spend money on a more fully developed experience. 

The only suggestions I have would be to add a way to delete existing nodes, and to add the ability to pick up and move nodes by hand instead of only being able to swat them in a direction.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure what's going to happen with this game, but I'm sure it's going to be fun.

Reviews:
Not wanting to sound overdramatic... But games like these while playing multiplayer. They show a glimpse of what's to come!

Here's what i mean:

I just played a multiplayer game with a random dude. I spawned in, looked up and saw him looking at me. He waved at me. I waved back. 

I didn't know what to do to start the match. So i made a shrug gesture towards him. He pointed to the table where it clearly stated what button i had to press. I pressed it and the game begun.

We played for a long time. Both of us trying different serves and screws. During the match we did all kinds of gestures towards eachother. Gestures of sadness when you lost an important point while the other celebrates with his hands in the air. Gestures of frustration when you lost a lot of points in a row etc... Body language in VR is really easy to understand. At least to me...

It was getting late and i had to go to sleep. I waved, he waved back and i disconnected. Never to see that player again...

What's so cool about all this is that you can express yourself without any pre-programmed gestures like /wave, /dance, /whatever. Now you can make your own little dance when you win. You do your own gestures. You do you! It's magical!

I can't wait for similar games like this one!

I don't mention much about the actual game here except for the VR multiplayer experience.. But the game is actually really good. It feels pretty realistic. Sure it's not perfect... But it is pretty damn close i'd say. | WARNING! Consider this abandoned by the developer. WARNING! 

Over 6 months past the promised launch date, read the early access notes before you consider taking a risk. The game content is solid in this current state it's a good game, but when a developer fails to fully complete the game they promise then I won't recommend it.

Want a Ping Pong game, get Eleven: Table Tennis VR instead. | I should have done thins a while ago.

BUY THIS GAME!!!!

This is not only the best Ping Pong game on the Vive, but it has an AMAZING community and is very very polished.

I have had hours and hours of fun playing people online which brings me to my next point.

SUPPORT THIS DEVELOPER

Rarely have I seen a developer this involved, this commited and this passionate about their game. I had the pleassure of helping him test some items. Do you know why he was up late testing and developing? Because ONE PERSON was unhappy with something about his game, so he re-wrote a major part of the game to be better for us all.

I got the chance to speak with him one on one and I can tell you without a doubt, he cares about this community and he wants nothing more than for us to just have fun.

Game is a 10/10 for me

COol game, early stage, I dont like the need to touch the gems to take them. The battles can be interesting, but need something to make it... more fun, not just swinging the sword as crazy, like.. if yo swing once you make more damage and if you swing quite a lot, you wont.. stuff like that. 

I liked the theme, maybe more magic would be fun.. But I don't need to see how many gems I have all the time, I think. | Good game.  It was exactly what I was looking for when I downloaded it.  I'm excited to see the finished product.  It is, however, a little glitchy still.  I made several blockes that did nothing.  I wouldn't mind seeing some armor in the game, especially if you had  a helmet that effected your vision. | Positive :
- Great atmosphere (including high quality graphics and sound).
- Fun sword/shield mechanics.
- Short but very promissing Act 1.

Negative : 
- Teleportation mechanics only, and a bit outdated ones too.
- You can't pick up the shield with Oculus Touch controllers, but you can still try out the sword (which is only half the fun).
- The developper is kept busy on other projects, so Acan's Call isn't getting updated or even fixed.

I no longer recommend this title even as a free demo because the shield mechanic is broken, act 2 is nowhere in sight, and it looks like it's going to stay that way. | + Nice environments
+ Enemies are well made
+ Weapons are upgradable

- Dull combat (to easy to block everything with shield)
- Awkward handling of sword and shield
- No story
- No updated for several months

Overall: Not reccomended | A bit short, I struggled sometimes with the objects collision (I'm not yet sure if I prefere no collision or full collision), I'd like to have a full game of this kind, with item drops, skills, etc. 

Developers, I need you to work on additional content for this game!

Reviews:
If you like Rick and Morty, you'll love this! Definitely one of my most fun VR experiences. Was literally laughing out loud while playing. Short, sweet, funny, and free! Can't beat it. | Parents guide :
- Profanity : Yes
- Violence & Gore : Yes
- Nudity : Yes

Your kids will love it. | When I heard there was an interactive VR experience by the creators and voice actor of Rick and Morty, I thought I knew what to expect.

And lo and behold, in all its glory, an impish, impetious, curse-laden delight.

I laughed, I giggled, I cavorted, I once even guffawed.

Great for everyone except those people who don't like long-winded high-brow expletive-based with-weird-dashes-in-the-middle humor. Those people are wrong, screw 'em. | FuÑĞº you! What are you doing in my review?
DEVELOPERS: Thanks a lot, Guys! Great work, and FuÑĞº you all! :D | A truly funny experience, well worth the 20-30 minutes to download and play. And when I say truly funny, I don't mean the kind of funny where you laugh at things when others are around because they're supposed to be funny. I mean truly funny in that the dialogue was extremely well written and had me laughing to myself stupidly at night after my family had gone to bed.

A few parts took me a bit to figure out (especially the court room) but that is mostly a testiment to the writing: I wasn't sure if I was supposed to do anything because the characters kept saying hilarious stuff. Accounting was free and extremely well done, and easily deserves a recommendation.

Great game and recommended if you are a strategy player. Looking forward to the new game soon! | I am coming back to give this game a review after sinking thousands of hours over into both Civ 4 and Civ 5 and on the launch day of Civ 7. Having played Civ 7 for a few hours now, I can say that that those of us who truly loved and still love Civ 5 judged Civ 6 too harshly when it released. It changed some things that people liked, but I still found many of its new features truly enjoyable on launch. I had fun. I still preferred 5, but in 6 the art, the music, the innovations to unrest, espionage, religion, and--to a lesser extent--city development were all excellent. Heroes are cool. The roster is cool. It's hard to believe that in 2025 we are still witnessing pro-Russian narratives in the gaming industry. In the latest version of the game, the developers once again ignored Ukrainian localization and completely erased the Ukrainian nation, which is heroically fighting for its survival and independence.  

The announcement of a new character, a tsarina-murderer being portrayed as a "symbol of culture and enlightenment," is a slap in the face to millions of Ukrainians. Glorifying an imperialist figure is not only outrageous but also immoral in the context of the war and occupation Ukraine is enduring today.  

Ukrainians deserve respect in the gaming industry, not an attempt to promote imperial narratives disguised as "cultural values." Enough with the propaganda! We demand full Ukrainian localization, Ukrainian heroes, and characters that truly reflect our history, culture, and struggle. | este jogo Ã© bom mas o prÃ³ximo a 2K ta de sacanagem! nunca que vou pagar ! 350/650R$ num jogo de nicho! I have more hours on this game than the deserves and I still don't have the last achievement, which is seeing absolutely everything. This would be okay if there was a skip function, but I have instead had to spam the space bar while multitasking to get to the options and hope that I find the missing couple of pages. My first playthrough or two was fine, but its so annoying that the last achievement takes so much time to get. If you don't care about 100%, its an okay game, the story isn't great by any means, no dialogue tree, just some scattered choices that (mostly) don't have much impact overall. The recon and research is all scattered so it doesn't feel like a linear story, the art is okay but I would have preferred if the full detailed pictures of the characters had the expressions instead of the smaller avatar images off to the side; its just not as visually interesting.
The cats aren't all that interesting either, they have fairly stereotypical personalities and there's not enough story to flesh them out (plus collectively they are actively harming the player characters by infecting them with a cat curse, great starting point for a love connection)
So over all, it gets boring and repetitive very quickly and the lack of skip function makes replaying to get achievements frustrating. The game isn't really worth the time.

Reviews:
This is a simplistic strategy game similar to Eufloria, and highly reminiscent of command school in Ender's Game. The game is an excellent demonstration of the timelessness of simple strategy games like chess and, to a lesser extent, checkers: very easy to pick up, but endlessly different possibilities that keep you coming back for more.

Highly recommended for at least a quick try as this is an independently developed game offered for free. While adding extra features might betray the minimalist approach, it could be worth a shot to add an extra twist to the experience. If multiplayer is released, this will undoubtedly be a must-have for quick 10 minute strategy battles on the Vive. | A tech demo for the real time strategy concept that will eventually devour us all into its wargame-like maw. It's a perfect Ender's Game-esque experience for the steep price of whatever your horrid internet provider charges for a meagre amount of data.

I'm not sure why I can't stop playing this or stop cursing at the AI when it's just a simple VR tactics game, but now my arms ache and the headset is slowly melding into my pores.

Send help.

Preferably in the form of a larger spaceship with more lazers. | Very cool RTS game for VR. The game is simple. You can manage a simple space war in VR. Select planets, choose % of ships and move them to other planets to conquer a huge solar system.

CONS: After playing few games, this can be repetitive. Maybe adding more complexity like multiple type of ships, planets with moons, types of planets (earth like, gaz, etc.) could improve this game and add other challenges. | This game actually makes me feel like I'm commanding a battle... like in Ender's Game, where you're disconnected from the action but commanding from within a virtualized environment.  This is hands down the most playable VR game I've found.  The gameplay is great, the controls make sense, the strategy is engaging.  

NOW I WANT online multiplayer.   ALSO, I really want to be able to be able to rotate the view when I pinch the controlers to resize. The game is to guess the angle an attack is coming in and block it. Every few attacks you get a chance to hit. That's all there is to it.

To make this game worthwhile:
- improve the block detection a lot, as in the AI hits the player a lot even through good blocking angles
- improve the hit reaction anims/gameplay. At the moment only one hit is allowed in the window and the AI barely reacts.

Essentially go play Infinity Blade again and take more notes. | For free a perfect nice sword fighting game :) | SincÃ¨rement il n'y a rien Ã  dire. C'est vide....

Reviews:
An incredible 3D platformer. This is why I love indie games so much, no triple A developer would try and make a game where you play as a snake winding and weaving for platforming. It makes you feel like a snake. Gives me 3D worms and Spyro vibes visually that makes me feel all warm and fuzzy. I hope they work on a sequel, I feel like there is more they could do with this formula. | this game is peak platformer design because it has zero jumps in it i love the physics and the snake is adorable | Unique game where you play as a snake called Noodle
Once you understand the controls and movement, this is a very fun game
Visually it looks very good and I quite liked the music
I wouldn't mind a sequel for this game.

If you like 3D platformers, I definitely recommend this game

9,5/10 | Snake Pass is pretty flawed: It has a less polished presentation than you would expect, and the camera sometimes struggles with some of the more intricate challenges. And the optional collectibles feel unrewarding and only serve to encourage the player to linger in levels that are already a bit bland.

However, the unique movement controls work well, and coiling across bamboo scaffolding feels way more expressive than one would typically expect from a game character with such a slow,  deliberate movement. I think that this is just enough to compensate for the flawed game built around these core mechanics. | Serpentea como toda una serpiente :D, me gusto mucho pero tuve que pelear mucho con la cÃ¡mara esa es mi unica queja

Was really looking forward to playing this game is I loved playing Spore back in the day but sadly it seems this game is not compatible with the Valve VR headset at all. It puts up the title in the VR headset and just hangs there forever, no errors no crash just nothing but the title in 3D space.

I just noticed that a it says a 2m x 1.5m game space is required and I'm not sure if I started the game in that mode or just fixed position but it should at least tell you if there is a problem as opposed to saying nothing at all and hanging.

I will try the game at a later date as they say it will be free in an announcement so hopefully this bug will be fixed. I won't recommend the game at the moment but will update once I can actually play it.
 | Paid 5 dollars for this game as my son wanted it. IMO, not worth anything. It feels more like a demo for potentional VR buyers and not really a game. | this is a cool game. its like the evolution games you probably played before, but if not, its pretty simple. eat. then upgrade.
eat fish smaller or weaker, then evolve and place your new appendages? ahh ya know, like a beak or a fin, each giving attack  or speed upgrade respectively. theres also skills with certian items. after killing and collecting the parts, you get bigger fish that can hold more parts and such. for instance if you take the eyes off to put more spiky spikes, you cant see lol. well you can but its blurry as mess. cool really. so simple concept, but it becomes more deep as you play and upgrade, with things like ice or toxic sacs on enemys, spikey or armored enemys, even some environmental hazards like jellyfishys.

now, accessibilty, this game runs on rift S. it even has in game controller models.... thank you for that. anyways theres one hiccup, and thats that the left stick is your start button and right is your button to go to evolving screen. easy fix though, if you like me dont want to click the sticks in, you can map them to the A and X buttons, using steam controller configs. there should be a preset one i made at least there, or do it yourself.

there is no turning options, but there is a way to move a bit in the underwater area. sort of a dash teleport. it works fine.
other than that theres not much to it, except eating items and fish.
bought it for 50 cents, and soon it will be free. either of those are really a good deal, becuase i would reccomend this game even at a higher price, i just never found it until now. it was definately well hidden.

so reccomend for sure. | It's a pretty neat game, upgrade your creature, fit it with new parts, make it look horrendous and go out to eat some more horrendous creatures, I like it. | The game's great, I loved the original spore so i just wish they'd make a another or a spore 2... or a spore VR
cleaned_review: ... ...but sadly it seems this game is not compatible with the Valve VR headset at all. It puts up the title in the VR headset and just hangs there forever, no errors no crash just nothing but the title in 3D space. I just noticed that a it says a 2m x 1.5m game space is required and I'm not sure if I started the game in that mode or just fixed position but it should at least tell you if there is a problem as opposed to saying nothing at all and hanging. I will try the game at a later date as they say it will be free in an announcement so hopefully this bug will be fixed...

Reviews: CAT | KITTENS.
cleaned_review: The KITTENS are a great choice for a sexy, sexy, or a sexy cat.

Reviews: Really good game. Give it a minute to let the concept sink in while you're playing. There is a pattern to each one, you just have to figure it out. I'm going to put more time into this for sure. This will be great for when I'm supposed to be working. | A bunch of squares that need to be purged | Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ°...
cleaned_review: Really good game. Give it a minute to let the concept sink in while you're playing. There is a pattern to each one, you just have to figure it out while you're playing.

æœ€åè¿˜æ˜¯å¾—å¤¸ä¸€å¥ï¼Œå°ä½œåŠä¸‹æ–™å°±æ˜¯çŒ›ï¼ | ATOM RPG is an exceptional indie gem that brilliantly captures the spirit of classic isometric RPGs like Fallout and Wasteland while carving its own unique identity. Developed by AtomTeam, this post-apocalyptic adventure offers an immersive and richly detailed experience that caters to fans of deep storytelling, tactical combat, and atmospheric world-building.

Story and Setting
Set in a post-apocalyptic Soviet wasteland, ATOM RPG stands out with its distinctive setting. The game masterfully blends dark humor, social commentary, and a gripping narrative to create a world that feels both familiar and fresh. The storyline, filled with twists and morally complex choices, keeps you engaged while exploring the ruins of a once-thriving civilization.

Gameplay
ATOM RPG delivers a robust gameplay experience:

Tactical Combat: The turn-based combat system is both challenging and rewarding, requiring strategic planning and thoughtful resource management.
Character Customization: The RPG mechanics are deep, with a flexible character creation system that allows players to build characters suited to their preferred playstyles.
Quests and Exploration: Side quests and random encounters are thoughtfully designed, adding layers of depth and unpredictability to the experience.
Graphics and Sound
The game's isometric visuals are beautifully crafted, with attention to detail that brings the desolate world to life. The atmospheric sound design, including the haunting soundtrack, enhances immersion, making every step through the wasteland feel impactful.

Replayability
One of ATOM RPG's strongest aspects is its replayability. With multiple endings, branching quest lines, and a wide variety of ways to approach problems, players are encouraged to experiment and revisit the game to uncover its many secrets.

Community and Support
The developers have shown a strong commitment to their community by listening to feedback and regularly updating the game. This dedication has fostered a loyal player base and continuous improvement.

Conclusion
ATOM RPG is a testament to the creativity and talent of indie developers. It respects its inspirations while pushing the boundaries of the genre with a unique setting, compelling storytelling, and engaging gameplay. Whether you're a fan of classic RPGs or simply looking for a well-crafted post-apocalyptic adventure, ATOM RPG is a must-play title that delivers incredible value.

Rating: 9/10
Verdict: A richly crafted and unforgettable journey through the ruins of a Soviet wasteland. Reviews:
Ashes of the Singularity carries a familiar essence, particularly for fans of Supreme Commander. The influence is undeniable, and I could feel its spirit seeping through the gameplay. The campaign offers a solid, well-structured experience, while the multiplayer delivers the standard fare youâ€™d expect from an RTS. That, in essence, is the theme of this gameâ€”it doesnâ€™t reinvent the wheel, but it delivers a polished and well-executed version of familiar mechanics.

My biggest gripe is the unit design. Many units look too similar, which can make it difficult to differentiate them at a glance. Additionally, the two main factions, while distinct in playstyle, share a somewhat uniform aesthetic, which makes them feel less visually unique than they could be.

On the positive side, the game excels in its command and control mechanics. The speed at which you can build, group, and maneuver your forces is impressive. The V key will quickly become your best friend, as it allows you to form cohesive armies that support one another effectively. However, the attack-move function can be a bit frustratingâ€”frontline units will engage while those in the rear sometimes idle instead of pushing forward. The best workaround is to avoid attack-move and instead overshoot your target, ensuring your forces spread out and engage as intended.

If you find Ashes of the Singularity on sale and have a soft spot for Supreme Commander, itâ€™s absolutely worth picking up. Iâ€™ve had a great time with it, and despite some minor flaws, it delivers an enjoyable large-scale RTS experience. | I wish more games would take this approach its simple but not halo wars simple(love that game too btw). | Once you get the hang of it, it is fun. Gives you that old Total Annihilation feel. Definitely a rts I have been hunting to play since beating all of the Supreme Commander games. | Sah auf den ersten Blick nicht schlecht aus, spielt sich aber leider nicht wirklich gut.

Reviews:
Overall the game delivers exactly what it promises.  It's real good.  Pretty.  Great loop.  However when you begin playing you only have a single commander.  If this commander is injured before you unlock a second one, you are forced to play crippled for the rest of the game.  At this point you are better off restarting the entire campaign.  I found this so discouraging that I can't give the game a positive review because I value my time.

I've posted about this in the discussion boards.  The moment a solution is in place I'll flip this review. | ABSOLUTELY ADDICTIVE! Funny as hell, easy to learn, and great for when you want a 4x game but not all the micromanaging.
cleaned_review: Great game, but the only thing that makes it worse is the limited number of commanders.

Reviews:
I'm normally the type of person to get motion sickness in VR, so I was convinced I'd get sick here. Somehow I'm not, though. I dunno what you did, but I'm able to fly around and do all kinds of maneuvers with no problems at all.

Eagerly awaiting multiplayer so I have something to shoot at! | [b]For those who don't realise, this game is being developed by the dev of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/465430/]Vertigo[/url][/b]

Hot damn, [i] this game[/i].
I am not usually one to write reviewsfor games - I actually couldn't tell you the last time I did it, or the game I did it for without going and checking now. But holy hell. This game is already among my favourite Vive games. The freedom it gives is astounding and the movement system is fantastic. I don't get any kind of motion sickness at all (Though, to be fair, I'm yet to have a game give me any kind of nausea).

Honestly, even if you only have a spare 10 minutes to have a little play around, I can assure you this free little gem is 100% worth your time. Can't wait to see where it leads.

Thanks, Devs! Keep up the good work! | sick free game, fly a jetpack with W I N G S! I just wish there were more enemies and races, as well as improvements on wing physics (slower fall rate when gliding, faster gliding, wing flapping actually being a thing) The closest thing to flying like a bird so far, and yes it's closer than eagle flight. Using the motion controllers to manipulate each wing individually is very fun and allows for manuevers that make you feel like you're actually flying, gliding around in the classic map is great for just relaxing or doing intense dive bombs through the cuboid in the centre. Brilliant game! The sense of flying is wonderful, and the world is full of things to check out.
Multiple, beautiful maps to try.
No sickness, flying feels intuitive.
Damnnit, it's free!
If you get motion sickness may | SOOOOOOOOOO cool. This "tech demo" as it is right now has a unique freedom of movement. i love the wings and sugest adding wing suit alternative  costume or maybe a pair of lazer blue jet airplane wings, maybe some rings to fly through for trick flying games. Obvoiusly if dogfighting multiplayer rooms were added some day this game could make some real cash. Totaly still in development dont expect a goal or score yet but it is liberating to rocket to the top of the map then use the wings to glide down and land like a bird. MUST TRY. --support this dev!-- | I think this is my frist review ever, maybe second. I have 60 vive games, and none of them have me as excited as this game. I just flew around the city, and with the guns and ranking, I imagine this is going to become a multiplayer of epic proportions. Hopefully there will be upgraded guns, leveling, new skills, upgraded wings and jets, etc. This is very fun just zooming around with no one else there. I imagine an MMO for this game will be the best experience on the vive hands down.
cleaned_review: I'm not usually one to write reviews for games - I actually couldn't tell you the last time I did it, or the game I did it for without going and checking now. But holy hell. This game is already among my favourite Vive games. The freedom it gives is astounding and the movement system is fantastic. I don't get motion sickness at all (though, to be fair, I'm yet to have a game give me any kind of nausea)

Reviews: Dropped about 75 hours into it years ago and completed all the puzzles in the base game. Just coming back to it now to play some of the community made puzzles as well and from the looks of it that may keep me busy for a bit. Good relaxing game to play when streaming TV or movies on the other monitor, | Really great picross/nonogram game! The puzzles are fun and unique, and what's pretty different about this one is that it has quite a few more difficult puzzles, whereas I feel like most picross games give you a flood of 5x5s and 10x10s and then only hand you a couple of 30x30s at the end. Pictopix gives you a good number of large puzzles that actually get harder as you progress. The last level was a real treat as well. Could not recommend enough! | possibly the best picross game out there | Lots of pictograms in this pictogram game. It rocks | Just as good as Picross.
cleaned_review: Great game!
