Ğ­Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾Ğµ ÑĞ¾Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ¸ÑĞºÑƒÑÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€Ğ°ĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸, ÑĞ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ½Ğ¾Ğµ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½ÑƒÑ‚ÑŒ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ°ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ ÑƒĞ³Ğ¾Ğ»ĞºĞ¸ Ñ‡ĞµĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞ¸.

Ğ˜ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ±ĞµÑ€Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµÑÑŒ Ñ‚ĞµÑ€Ğ¿ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ, Ğ² Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğµ Ğ½ĞµÑ‚Ñƒ ĞºĞ»Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸ÑˆĞ¸ ÑˆĞ¸Ñ„Ñ‚ :) | Admittedly emotionally compromised by this game, so bear with. I think the British coastline is one of the most consistently beautiful places I can lay eyes on, and have dedicated hundreds of hours of my time to walking around as much of it as I can. After my granddad on my Scottish side passed away, I accompanied my grieving father down the plots of land that meant the world to the both of them, and extended as far beyond as we could. One of our trips took us to Gometra, a place of such beauty it finally broke his stoic ass into tears, despite it not being somewhere he'd ever visited before. It's just such a haunted place, the whole coast is. Freezing cold, battering you with constant gales and rain and seafoam and seagull shit - the same elements that carve the land itself. Jagged slippery rocks and mundane flora, the only specs of colour or sign of human life being litter or debris, broken glass or empty cans left god knows how long ago. On my solo walks, my mind would wander to morbid places, imagining what would happen should I trip and hurt myself; what kinds of infections I'd get, how long it'd be if at all before I would have any chance of help.

That same uneasy awareness, the pull of the beautiful and the morbid, defines my experience with Dear Esther. The game's Hebridean island is made to feel like a place out of time, a frozen echo of someone's grief. It makes use of randomised props and narration, one of the major points of contention way back at this game's release. What does it all mean? Do you really need to replay it to get the full story? Even back when this was just a simple free Source mod developed as a university project, I somehow just Got It. I didnâ€™t need to know who Donnelly was or why the narrator was here. The weight of it was enough, the way the words hung in the air like mist over the cliffs. Some things you donâ€™t need to piece together; you just need to let the words hang as you eavesdrop on the memories on the breeze. Maybe this all works for me because - - embarrassingly, I think anyone who knows me particularly well would attest to this - - I am very emotionally vulnerable, not only to art but so many facets of life. If I am interpreting this as an existentialist tale about grief, would I be so greedy as to also demand Answers when life itself rarely supplies them at times of struggle? Much of why I feel this game be more effective than some of its more better-regarded peers is that it invites me to sit in the loneliness of the space. Pained, empty, but full - full of all the things unsaid, all the memories tied to a place that canâ€™t speak for itself.
And maybe thatâ€™s why it hit me so hard. The randomisation of narration and props isnâ€™t a gimmick; itâ€™s a reminder that stories are never static. The same place, the same words, can mean something different depending on where you are in your life when you encounter them. Iâ€™ve played Dear Esther's original form, and the remaster a great many times, but this replay was a good few years in the making - and the story I uncovered felt wonderfully evocative... not because the island has changed, but because I have.

On replay I was particularly taken to the work put into the sound design. This is such a rich soundscape... The whisper of the wind through the grass, the distant crash of waves against the cliffs, the faint echo of something that could be a voice. Doesnâ€™t just set the mood; it deepen it, pulling me further into the islandâ€™s strange, mournful embrace. Jessica Curryâ€™s score remains as achingly beautiful as it was I first heard it, swelling at just the right moments to catch my breath in my throat, and using elements of unusual distortion and industrial wailing to convey a real sense of sorrow. It harkens to whenever I visit the coast - there's never a moment of silence, even in relative stillness and isolation, it's this overwhelming cacophony of nature is trying to crush the ground I'm standing on. Can't praise it enough, man, entire characters in some of my favourite games don't have the presence of the wind in Dear Esther.

One unsung aspect of this game for me is the involvement of Robert Briscoe - the veteran level designer for Mirror's Edge. That being a game I adore for its incredibly well thought out world - not just gameplay-wise, but mostly by how it conveys a sense of place. Mirror's Edge thrives on its pristine, dystopian cityscapes, where every building and rooftop feels deliberately placed to tell a story about control, surveillance, and rebellion. Briscoeâ€™s work there demonstrated an ability to create environments that are more than just backdrops, theyâ€™re active participants in the narrative, conveying meaning through their design - on top of just looking gorgeous. This same philosophy is palpable in Dear Esther. A broken fence, a rusted piece of machinery, or a strange marking on the wall - each detail feels like a breadcrumb leading me further into the islandâ€™s mysteries. Itâ€™s also worth noting how Briscoe leveraged the Source engine to its fullest potential. The lighting, in particular, plays a huge role in the gameâ€™s emotional resonance. The way the sun sets over the cliffs or how the glow of phosphorescent caves contrasts with the bleakness above ground is breathtaking. These moments arenâ€™t just pretty, theyâ€™re deeply atmospheric to me. The final chapter's skybox? Abso sublime.

The game isn't for everyone, and I understand why. I also don't think any game worth playing would be. The only interaction function is a camera zoom, there is one walk speed, if you don't feel for it then there's nothing to latch on to. Still, the smear back at release does feel incredibly quaint now that you can hardly walk through Itch without tripping over a game like this. It doesn't feel that way now, but this was an incredibly risky game at the time, and one that has definitely helped blossom a subgenre of narrative adventure game. You have to forgive me for the glaze sesh, it never really sat right with me that this game has been forbidden from getting its flowers even now. | Game doesn't lead player for achievements well as they busy with strong emotional relationships with related relatives based on phylosophy of life. Director messages on floor having no interaction i can't be 0 to 30 dk. On the other hand why would be strange spooky ghostly ominous sounds around dk. ps: cave was a big surprise and different kinda art with game was nice. | a beautiful walk through an impossible island as a man descends into madness | This is far from being just a "walking simulator" - this beautiful emotionally game it's so rich in everything that makes it this unique.

Brotato is a very simple rougelite however what makes the game really fun is the many characters combined with the many weapons COMBINED with items and levels. Holy hell you get so much replay value. Not to mention harder difficulty modes to add more challenges.

Honestly the price is a total steal but the game does go on sale.

I totally recommend the game :3

ãƒãƒƒãƒ—ãŒæƒ³åƒä»¥ä¸Šã«åºƒãã¦ã€æœªé–‹åœ°ã‚’æ¢ç´¢ã™ã‚‹ã®ãŒæ¥½ã—ã‹ã£ãŸã€‚

Can't really say I enjoyed this after the first hour. Being forced to play thru large levels where the end boss usually is something that summons 4 badgers with 84 health and 16 attack when your pulling a max of 32 atk...

I know its "Grind and get stuff to get better!" but its such a slow process its aggravating, and nothing so far made me go yay this is awesome to have. Treasures in short supply so building progress is sloooow, guess your supposed to just give the mail guy all your stuff and go die on the next floor or something and repeat that 10-15 times. Just let us leave.

Ran into a bunch of glitches and things unexplained that made me lose stuff (like retry just resets all progress back to the start of the entire area, not the battle, not the floor, everything, it was like... could I get a warning? Also went on a quest that said progress in the town would not proceed, assumed "no new items unlocked" nope... it just negates the entire run, no items brought back no nadda. Runs take forever too, and barely give you stuff. Specially if your trying to win, and fail, which you will, and it just deletes everything from your backpack. | Pretty fun game with lot of replayability

Pro
Replayability good thing for a roguelite each run will be different due to the item, character and challenge you choose
Fun little story with lot of tutorial to introduce the different mechanic
Easy mod support integrate with steam workshop to add even more replayability

Con
RNG dependant making some run at best boring at worst plain not fun | A couple of bugs still, with the major ones being: save files being deleted or keep loading at the same checkpoint over and over again like with my save file. Please don't put your hours in it like I did this weekend ;) The concept is good, a finished version 2.0 would be preferable. | I seriously went back and forth on this. There are aspects of this game that I [u]really[/u] like. The concept of sorting your backpack in a combative scenario and defeating enemies with strategic item placement is really great. The main character and the first unlockable character are fantastic fun*. However, there are numerable UI issues and item description issues that make learning how to play the game very unpleasant. Certain items are not straightforward and there seems to be no info online on how to use them or even what they are. This game is just over a year old and it's clear the Dev(s) care about this game as it receives regular updates. Yet for some reason, major game-breaking bugs still exist. 
So, I touched on the fun of this game. I want to make it clear that I mostly enjoyed playing this game. I have almost 50 hours in this game, I definitely have enjoyed it. But the learning curve of this game is steep. The way and pace at which things are unlocked are not well done, imo. I'm not sure what the intended method of play is, because there is no real info about that. The game throws you in the deep end, expecting you to figure out how to set up amazing engines of play. The quests give you great hints, don't get me wrong, but if you didn't think to do the quests (cus all the quests are optional) then wow. 

TLDR: There are many features of this game that I really enjoy. There are too many features of this game that I don't enjoy. Therefore, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to a new player unless they are willing to learn about this game before they play it. Fun game, but can be incredibly punishing. | The game use to be fun, but everything fun has been nerfed to the point it is boring.

The campaign progression is very slow and boring. the game mode does not even seem to add anything. Just a way to waste your time.

Quick play has such high item bloat that it is hard to get a build you want at all going. You can have multiple runs in a row without seeing a single structure, a bow and arrow, etc at all. But you will keep seeing a few of the same boring items you never want to appear every game.

Boss relics are just not fun anymore. They all have bad downsides and require specific builds to work. So you often do not even pick up a single boss relic. I think they were aiming for a slay the spire style boss relics without understanding them at all (the downsides were minor compared to the power given and STS did not try to balance things like this game).

So I guess this is a game that just changed from 1 8/10 game to a 3/10 for me.
cleaned_review: a few bugs.

Reviews:
I rarely write reviews, but this game is a confluence of my interests. Steam says I played 2 hours so far, and if you'd asked me how much I played last night I would have said 30 minutes. It's that kind of game. (And I know it's accurate because I was playing on the couch on my Steamdeck, and that thing shuts off automatically.) Is this the best survivors game on Steam? No, but it's actually better than probably 50% of the ones I've tried, and I've tried quite a few. And that doesn't even account for the chess angle, which is a palpable part of my interest. Recommended.

Also, this didn't influence my review in any way, but the game's creator is on youtube, teaching folks to make games in Godot. Love it. | I just bought this on a whim without high expectations and this game is criminally underrated. It's quite original and I like that the gameplay lives somewhere between a realtime / turn based game (turn based with a short timer) so there's some strategy involved with movement but not TOO much. I've only played 3-4 runs so far but the roguelite upgrades gave each of the runs a lot of variety. It's the kind of game that's easy to pick up, play for a few minutes, be really entertaining, and then put down.
cleaned_review: I'm not sure if I'm a fan of the game, but I'm a fan of the game. I've played it a few times and I'm still impressed.

Reviews:
å¥½ç©æ˜¯å¥½ç©ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æœ‰ç‚¹å¤ªè´µäº†ï¼Œæ„Ÿè§‰28æ¯”è¾ƒç¬¦åˆè¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç­‰æ‰“æŠ˜å…¥æ‰‹ | Fun tactics/strategy rougelike. Gameplay is turn based along a single axis, but there is a surprising amount of thought that you might have to put into each move. It's easy to get into and satisfying to play, especially when you unleash a multi tile combo clearing the whole screen. The starting kit for each character has enough tools to play through the game meaning that RNG is unlikely to ruin a run compared to other rougelikes. The soundtrack is great and the graphics are charming. There are only a handful of world building/"story" lines, so the main draw here is the gameplay (which is fantastic). My only criticism is that I wish each area had a legend of which enemies+boss are there. It's not difficult to learn after a few runs but it would still be convenient for planning. | I hate to diss a game that's innovative and well-executed, but this needs to be said. I had great fun with this title for about 12 to 15 hours. Beyond that, getting past 'day 4' or 'day 5' difficulty got to be way too frustrating. Making even a single mistake often necessitates restart or outright loss. Getting bad tiles or upgrade statues means mistakes, and the item pool expands with further play. 

Some limited means of replaying a turn, like the turn reset from Into the Breach, might've helped.  But more importantly, the game demands you play each tier of difficulty with each character. Got to day 5 with the Ronin but now you feel the Wanderer would be better? You're looking at maybe 3 hours of playing the Wanderer up to day 5. It feels like a cheap way of tacking on more playable hours to the game. 

It's way more frustrating to see such a cool idea meet these pitfalls than if it had just flopped. I very nearly gave a positive review, but I felt I couldn't be the only one who would have trouble with these aspects. It's still probably worth the money for the first 10-15 hours, but shouldn't we aim higher than that? | The enemy gives you their moves beforehand, and you have to think about how to make the correct moves yourself to obliterate them, or at least to survive. It's like Into The Breach and Slay the Spire in one game | It's good. Real good. Like high five your best friend good.

After playing Civ 7 I was delighted to play a game where obvious attention and care went towards the interface.
Pleasant traditional roguelike with really nice interface+controls and a lot of DnD-esque flavor. Reminds me a bit of DCSS and Incursion. | dev:

maybe too late to add, but I really think a classic RPG interface with visual slots for weapons and so on would add so much to the game and let people instantly connect to it. (look at 'Caves of Qud' which just released last year and has an insanely well done UI for this now, even for characters with 4 arms or nearby floatables)

it feels like such an essential part of immersing yourself into the game... the lines of text may work as a nostalgia play, but scare off anyone who doesn't want to deal with a frankly incredibly clunky way of doing inventory and equipment.

I don't want to give it a bad rating, because the game essentially is exactly what it promises to be, but I simply can't enjoy games that force you to do min-maxy try-hard roguelike experience sans any fun, adventure, exploration and so on.
people already tend to min-max the fun out of games and if you force people into challenge modes that's all they're gonna do. 

if I could just save and reload, I could challenge myself, play more relaxed and not be annoyed when the only reason I died was because I didn't know that X -> bad idea.

I know that there are people that like that, a lot claim to like it, but very few in fact do.

what people do like is to play in this manner in a game they already mastered or understand really well. I play roguelike modes in games, or games with meta progression, i.e. rogueLITEs (capitalization for emphasis. it seems that term isn't used any more, but that's how people called it back then) 

a story mode, or normal RPG mode with just exploration and leveling and so on would have been amazing for this game.... 

I just wanna play *my* character, not do speedruns or no hit stuff or hardcore runs. this stuff is fun to watch others do, but it's just so boring to me because whenever I get attached to my character, I die. it just kills the game for me.

I can't criticize or downvote a game because it said "roguelike" and delivered that and I didn't enjoy it :D -- but if I played through in a normal save scum mode as most people do, I'd way way way more likely enjoy the roguelike experience.

if you only do a challenge mode game (which is what this essentially is), the best way to do these games is simply with heavy meta progression, but that is quite the headache in a genre like this, I suppose. how would you even scale this? I have no idea... but it would at least "sell me" on the idea that this is still "my character". restarting as the same character from 0 does not do that - for me at least.

you can always limit a game mode to be more challenging, or simply have several seemingly equal ways to play a game. limiting the ways you can play a game needlessly seems unwise, even if you yourself are purely interested in a roguelike experience.

the game's incredibly well executed. I like everything except that I can't shoot through people -- but that's kinda personal taste and I guess makes sense, but is a bit annoying when you play a ranged character with hirelings that constantly spawn in their pets and you barely get to fire an arrow.




-----------------

if you play on Linux and 4k, go to .local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Zorbus/Data/Settings.txt 
and change the relevant lines to:

tile_size................ 64

tiles_64_horizontal...... 46
tiles_64_vertical........ 29

zoom..................... 175

otherwise the game will not scale well | Very nice, well modernized, traditional roguelike. If you like DCSS, you'll like this. | Great game. Especially when you like DCSS. | Doidera
cleaned_review: i think it's a good game, but it's not a good game.

The level designs, voice acting and general mechanics combined make this game an absolute treat to play. 

There's so many different difficulties, play styles and builds to choose from too, giving you the freedom of choice to either have a laid back roam through a quick map or a long and twisted rouge-like adventure. Even better, despite it being released back in 2018, it's still getting updates (including new maps)!

. | This game's audio is really broken right now, the characters all sound like they are about half a mile down a tunnel or well, and it's even worse for the character you play as, you can;t hear them at all, just see the subtitles. I have looked everywhere, even dev blogs for a fix to this and there is no fixes found. It is definitely the game itself that has this game breaking bug as all other 250+ games I have on Steam do not have these kind of audio issues. I say game breaking bug, because, for me at least, half the fun of this game is the dialogue between all the characters. Fat Shark you need to fix this issue! I cannot and will not recommend this game right now as audio bugs can really affect how the gameplay runs, do yourself a favor and wait til you see a post saying they have fixed this issue. | I'd really love to upvote this game as it has been great co-operative multiplayer experience whenever it has worked properly. That is, the title bringing a breath of life into the Left 4 Dead genre with extensive character customization abilities. However, the game is let down by its horrible network code. More than half of the random games I've joined have ended up in some sort of desyncronization problems or outright disconnect without any specific reason or warning. Neither does any sort of game recovery from a disconnected host work either. Seven years after the release date the network play of the title is way too unreliable to really allow recommending the title.

My advice: if you are interested, buy the base game without any DLC if it's heavily discounted. If you enjoy it and find the network performance acceptable for your needs, so be it. In my case with the random games being irritating disconnect-a-fest I'm certainly not investing into all DLC's of the game even if they gave me considerable amount of new content to play with.

Dude this game would've skyrocketed if it wasn't for some questionable design choices and questionable marketing. I love the game but the weird middle-school "drama" and increasing friend levels (weird hangouts and trying to please people) was awkward. I'm all for cheesy comic book dialogue from the golden era but let's be real, I really wish it was darker in tone. It's "dark" in the sense that it has that late 90s-early 2000s edgy angst. It's like watching Blade but they took out the cursing and blood.

Let's be real, people were expecting Xcom with Marvel characters. Straight up, bringing in Marvel characters on a tactical map and playing a polished version of Freedom Force mixed with turn-based action and stellar graphics. It's definitely unique and works with what it's got, I almost wish it played like a rogue-lite. And dude, we should've gotten some more obscure characters but I know that doesn't pull in the masses.

That's it for my gripes. This game is addicting and we're kinda strapped for good superhero games, especially ones that let you control a squad of your favorites. Aside from the "hub" slowing down the action, I really love it. Graphics are slick, superheroes can feel powerful if you build the right deck, and though we still have the Avengers in it, it's not just about them and we get to play with characters who deserve a bit more spotlight. Despite what I feel about the tone of the story, I still think it's pretty solid for a superhero game. Throwing some goon into an explosion to wreck other badguys and then slamming down with some crazy AOE attack you've been saving your points for is insanely satisfying. Also, it has Ghost Rider. That was enough to make me buy it right there.

If you picked it up for PC, seriously look into modding as there are some tweaks out there that make the game feel more streamlined. | This game really took me by surprise. Its existence nearly passed me by when it launched in late 2022.

Little did I know: Firaxis Games and the XCOM team had just made a Marvel XCOM Mass Effect Card Battler.

WHAT?

I don't normally click with card battlers, and I am very burned out on superhero multimedia, but Midnight Suns quickly got its hooks in me, and I could not put it down. Maybe I'm just burned out on trash multimedia.

- If you like Marvel content, that's an easy reason to enjoy this. There's a good mix of superstar Avengers heroes and lesser known Midnight Suns heroes in the game.

- All of this game's DNA screams XCOM, the battles have just been converted to a smaller arena based around card battling, rather than a large cover and fog of war-based combat system. All of the management systems at play in your out of combat base, The Abbey, are very similar to XCOM headquarters. Train with your heroes, upgrade your cards, buy items, explore the Abbey grounds to find secrets and loot, and quite a bit more in-between combat missions.

- A friendship and hangout Social system with all of the heroes. Have some beers with Blade or go fishing with Wolverine, and you get battle bonuses for building these relationships, creating a great side progression system.

- I honestly don't play enough card battlers to give an expert gamer opinion on how deep the card strategy and deckbuilding is. But I started the game pretty inept, and by the end I was fine-tuning my hero decks, playing cards for a turn or two ahead, and optimizing my combat action sequences for maximum effect.

- The one DLC expansion that came out before development ended, The Good, The Bad, and the Undead, was just as high quality as the base game and integrated into it seamlessly. It was also amazing near the end when Morbius screamed "ITS MORBIN' TIME"

- This has a LOT of dialogue, in a dialogue system that will be familiar if you've played the Mass Effect trilogy. The writing is never that good, in fact it can be quite comic book hammy at times, but this game is suitably epic. I accomplished a lot, but did NOT "100%" this game, and this was teetering on 90 hours played. That's bigger than the entire Mass Effect trilogy on completionist runs.

Some smaller criticisms of the game that I didn't love:

- They tried to go for a premium currency and loot grading system that just reeks in a single player game. Unacceptable. Alas, development of the game has ceased, and the Legendary Edition of this game includes ALL content.

- Some of the mission variety, particularly Story missions (move critical path/plot forward), left a bit to be desired. I never minded General missions (mostly side/optional missions) having recognisable presets, but to launch into Story missions and often have them padded out by the same presets as General missions was disappointing at times.

- Not a big fan of level scaling enemies, and the enemies in this game will do so until you reach max "normal" levels, after which there are "heroic" levels where you begin to eclipse them. This almost felt like an irrelevance to explain, but I was just shy of max level after finishing the game, so enemies scaled for my whole playthrough.

- That this game fell under the radar so hard, I never got more DLC expansions. We could have had Thor! And Squirrel Girl!

That's about it. I strongly recommend this game. If "Marvel XCOM Mass Effect Card Battler" speaks to you at all, you need to try this. | This game is the closest you can ever get to perfecting the formula of great companion characters.  The cast is the best part of this game, and anyone who says the Relationship building sucks doesn't know what they're talking about.  Each character is written both exactly as you'd expect, and with such a depth that it builds upon that legacy.  It's really fun to be able to leave your mark on the Marvel universe, and make friends and allies with some of the biggest names, cast in the best way.  

I originally wasn't into the Card Game idea, but I really came around to it.  It's really cool to play through them like combat puzzles, with plenty of opportunities for defenestration and environmental damage.  Each hero's card-set is so well designed that they all play a little different, allowing for strategic and flavorful combination.  I haven't played a Marvel game that utilized it's characters so well since Marvel Ultimate Alliance.  

The story is pretty good, but pretty much what you'd expect from a comic book event series.  Think about any of the comic events, these are the vibes.  Characters are transformed and die in interesting ways, that'll certainly be undone by some sort of cosmic force, it's kinda the name of the game here.  What it is, though, is a very fun thrill ride.  Lots of little twists and turns, and the level of dialogue choice can really make your experience *yours*.  

The DLC is pretty worth, I even enjoyed Deadpool, he wasn't annoying and had a really fun play style.  Game is super good, underrated even, especially from the X-Com devs.  Masters of the Strategy genre for sure, they can turn a silly card game gimmick into a really fun tactical puzzle game. 

TL;DR: You want a Marvel RPG with a fun Tactical Card Gimmick and solid representation across the Marvel Universe?  Get this game. | æ˜¯æŒºå¥½ç©çš„ï¼Œä¾æ—§æ˜¯æ¼«å¨ä¸ªäººè‹±é›„ä¸»ä¹‰é£æ ¼ï¼Œåä¸½çš„æ‹›å¼å’Œç‰¹æ•ˆï¼Œè‹±é›„å‡ºä»»åŠ¡çš„åŠ¨ç”»ä»¥åŠå‰§æƒ…è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­çš„é…ä¹éå¸¸ä¸é”™ï¼Œè®©äººè·Ÿç€æ¿€åŠ¨ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯æ€ªçš„ç§ç±»è¾ƒå°‘å’Œè¿‡å¤šæ²¡æœ‰ç”¨çš„å¯¹è¯æ–‡æœ¬ä½¿æ¸¸æˆå˜å¾—æ¯ç‡¥ã€‚å°¤å…¶ç»“å±€ä»“ä¿ƒçš„å‰§æƒ…è®©ç©å®¶çš„æƒ…æ„Ÿå°±åƒåšçˆ±ä¸€æ ·è¿˜æ²¡è¾¾åˆ°é«˜æ½®å°±åŒ†åŒ†ç»“æŸäº†ï¼Œå’Œç¾å‰§ä¸€æ ·è™å¤´è›‡å°¾ã€‚ | This game is so much better than you'd think it would be. Game Name: Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep: A Wonderlands One-shot Adventure
Reviews: This does not need to be a standalone game, should have just left this as a DLC in BL2. the copy and paste achievements are so lazy, and why add the kill a chubby achievement when the spawn rate is extremely rare. just a big waste of time. | This game is jankier than many of the other games in the Borderlands franchises, and while I was prepared to deal with that, it's also more designed around bullet-sponge enemies rather than making it interesting or varied. The fact that there were multiple locations where I completely ran out of ammo for multiple guns tells you the balance was not well-thought-out for this game, and before anyone doubts, I am not bad at FPS games, the enemies are just bullet-spongey. There's also endless backtracking, and many quests you'll be under-leveled for (making them even more bullet-spongey) if you don't do all the side-quests. To top it all off, there is one of the worst game puzzles I've ever seen, a crusher room that many players lose most of their money on and which can take many, MANY irritating attempts to beat. I literally quit the game at that point, and I kept expecting it to be another of Tina's "joke" puzzles only it wasn't. Many deaths later and I just gave up on the whole game, which is not worth beating this puzzle for. And I say that as someone who loves the Borderlands franchise. | For people who are wanting to either purely play the Tiny Tina DLC from Borderlands 2 or for those who want to get into the swing of things before they play Wonderlands, this is incredible, otherwise maybe not worth it to some. Either way, I really enjoyed it! | Borderlands and dnd references.
cleaned_review: This is a great game, but it's not worth the money.

Reviews:
Massively fun game that perfectly captures the feel of space battles from the TV show. | Fun Battlestar game, DLC's do enhance gameplay a lot and add some new ships like the mercury class battlestar and the new cylon besestars. :D
The game has campain levels but you can also make fleets and battle them in a kind of sandbox mode (this is my favorite thing to do in the game).

The game also has a replay at the end of every battle that also allows you to add effects and take pictures, great for making a new battlestar wallpaper ;)


Overall good game | Cool game. It's turn based, but with both sides' moves occurring simultaneously. I had a lot of fun figuring out the different fighting style of each ship as well as their quirks and ideal horizontal and vertical positing. I only wish that there was more to do outside of the campaign. | Engaging space battle strategy, really enjoy the simultaneous turns and cinematic replay at the end. | I've only played the first tutorial so far and I'm already impressed. The gameplay is very intuitive, you get (limited) 3-dimensional movement, the visuals are captivating, the 'replay' feature is a really cool touch, and I can see a LOT of modding potential.
cleaned_review: Great game, but I wish there was more to do outside of the campaign.

Reviews:
Do you remember that beautiful time in the mid 2000â€™s when FPS games were made less to try and siphon every dollar from a community drowned out by ultra-sweaty tryhards and more to provide a fun space to either spend time with old friends or make entirely new friends by just goofing around with guns and a huge variety of substantial content that isnâ€™t almost exclusively made up of dumb weapon skins?

Straftat remembers, and remembers well!

While the 1v1 nature of the game does take some general skill and wit, it is unpredictable enough for it to truly be anyoneâ€™s game most of the time. The rounds go by way too quickly to even think about getting frustrated. Itâ€™s mostly just that â€œOh, dang. Nice one! You got me.â€ feeling and then itâ€™s right on to the next round. My experience playing with randos online has been great! Everyone has been chill and there for a good time and I hope it's kept that way! 

Some of the maps are so unique and clever with their condensed structure and on-map arsenal that it gives me the same feeling I got from Halo 3â€™s custom games. You could be going down an infinitely sliding map one moment, to trying to push each other into landmines the next, to trying to spot each other in complete darkness the next, to naruto running through a jumping puzzle the next, to tossing grenades at each other in a labyrinth of doorways the next, and the next and the next and the next-

The game has bonus points for the aesthetic too! Iâ€™ve definitely fallen in love with the liminal tone of every map. Pairing that with the drum n bass music in the menus and the odd characters in suits, always with a cigarette in the mouth, makes the game almost feel like youâ€™re in some sort of chill club of enthusiasts in the matrix or something. Itâ€™s a very specific vibe that Iâ€™m just drawn to. (Who would have thought Babbdiâ€™s apparent violent societal collapse could be so fun to partake in!)

For a free game, it is miles and miles above expectation. I genuinely want people to buy the $5 DLC (which essentially doubles the content) just to support the devs. Theyâ€™re doing truly fantastic work and deserve way more than theyâ€™ve been asking for! | This game is made with love. It is some of the most fun in an FPS i've ever had. | I found an actual video game no way. | Bring back toxic gaming <3 | cool
cleaned_review: 'Straftat' is a fun, unique, and unique game that is a blast to play.

highly immersive dungeon crawler with a  copacetic but satisfying combat system and light RPG mechanics.

Best of all, toned down the infamous 'torch economy'

Easy recommend for newbies and Vets of dungeon crawlers | Pretty fun first person dungeon crawler with some interesting puzzles and ambush mobs.

I liked it, but it only took about 10hrs to beat, there's no reward for not using guns and there's no new game plus.

I kept thinking a lot of items would have additional uses for secrets but they didnt and i collected every mask type for no apparent reason.

It was still a good game, just hope it gets more content or a sequel. | If you love a good grid based Dungeon Crawler and are a fan of games like Dungeon Master or Legend of Grimrock, this game has some new and fun ideas on the blobber genre. The combat feels snappy and forces you to move around and target foes heads/body. Weapons have durability and multiple weapon sets let you keep powerful items for reserve. The combat is really fun and classic puzzles are enjoyable. There's a sense of risk and the creepy mask theme is really cool. After finishing it, I can conclude that Dragon's Dogma 2 might be the biggest disappointment I've ever experienced in gaming. I could go on for paragraphs about all the things that are bad about it, but I'll just summarize because I've already spent over 100 hours playing this when I could have been doing something else, like plucking my asshole hairs individually.

First and foremost, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen exists. In a world where DDDA didn't exist, this game would stand about where DDDA was - blatantly unfinished, didn't live up to it's potential, lot's of contemplating on how it could be better, but essentially just the skeleton of something great with pretty decent gameplay. [i]However[/i].

DDDA exists. Not only does it exist, Dragon's Dogma 2 is a marked downgrade in nearly every single metric already established by the prior game twelve years ago. Eleven if you want to be generous for the addition of Dark Arisen. There is less enemy variety, there are less vocations, equipment variety is worse, the story is worse, there are both less major characters and they have infinitely less screen time/importance/value, the music is just... nothing. I could keep going. The only measure DD2 is a genuine improvement and not just a side grade is in the graphics department, and this comes at a cost of the game being complete dog ass to run on your average PC. Sure you'll probably get 30-60fps consistently but it will chug randomly for no reason all over the place. Ignore Capcom's nonsense about it being NPCs in town, I was getting 18fps just loading the model in my inventory. Something about REengine or Denuvo has this game in a complete stranglehold and unfortunately it'll probably never get fixed.

If DDDA didn't exist, Dragon's Dogma 2 would just be a kind of stupid action RPG with good gameplay. But instead it's an abysmal sequel to a game with an already kind of stupid plot with better gameplay, and it manages to take that original idea and basically photocopy it with a scanner that was pretty low on ink. This game is so frustratingly undercooked. Let's just use an example. 

In the original game, you took damage and you lost HP and your "loss gauge" increased. This missing HP couldn't be healed for free with Anodyne, so you could either go to an inn or use healing items. Healing items had weight and were limited, and though you'd eventually be swimming in them, the healing your loss gauge meant you wanted to have them just in case. In DD2, you take damage and your loss gauge builds up, and... healing items don't do anything different than Anodyne. Okay, so this immediately makes healing items fucking worthless since they're still making you heavier (and slower) but they do the same thing as Anodyne, which mages can cast for free, all the time. In fact you'd only not have a mage with anodyne because you specifically chose to have no mage in your party. In exchange, you now have to go camping. Camping is so... fucking... NOTHING. It's just completely devoid of anything. Find one of the spots all over the map, use your tent item which can break but not only will this basically never happen you find tents constantly - all so you can cook meat and get an actual video of someone grilling a steak on a pan in real life, and get a buff. You have the same one line of dialogue with your pawn at the camp site and go to sleep. But keep in mind you can only cook meat - not fish, not fruit, not potatoes, and you certainly can't make meals or anything fancy. In fact there are 8 types of meat you can cook for the entire game and they're all just variations of two types of meat, Scrag and Beast Steak. Combining them makes Dried whatever meat and if you let it rot you get Rotten whatever meat (which you can still cook and your pawns will say it's delicious because their canned yummy yummy response is also completely fucking nothing).

This is DD2. It's just so empty. It builds on nothing from DDDA. It's got a bigger world except it's almost exclusively just roads and cliffs that make traveling at night more annoying, and lots and lots of fighting fodder enemies. Which is fun! In fact, the first 20-30 hours of this game are spectacular. But the more you play it, the more and more obviously unfinished it is. Until the final sequence where the credits are rolling and some NPC I maybe met twice in 80 hours and don't care about is literally explaining to me what the Dragon's Dogma is. Holy shit.

I want to live in a world where this game never came out, because at least before I could hope about what Dragon's Dogma 2 could be. Now it's out, and it's too late. We'll never have that, just like we didn't get to have the Dragon's Dogma 1 that "we were supposed to".

At least I got to kill thousands of Goblins. Do not recommend. | Game hasnt been updated in months (sept) Really feels abandoned and needs optimizations badly.
